loaded as a module, and you won't either compile a kernel and you can't
find a kernel for the system that has no usb support, there's not much
you can do. Of course it really isn't a lot of overhead--mostly it's
just a little extra startup time.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Wed Oct  1 06:29:02 2003

 <1064984913.2512.49.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0310010606580.27427@pecos.madboa.com>

On Tue, 30 Sep 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:

> The purpose of DNS is to identify hosts and networks without having
> to know ip addresses.

I want to agree with you here -- in many cases, DNS just doesn't do
what you'd expect any more -- but "purpose of" arguments nettle me.

Who's to say that folks can't find new ways to use an existing tool? I
may not appreciate the end result of some forms of creativity, but
that doesn't mean that all software should do only what its original
coders wanted, and nothing else.

All sorts of cool things are the result of someone using or modifying
an existing tool in a unique way:

* The "purpose of" HTTP and HTML was one-way Internet publication --
  so Slashdot and every other web-based bulletin board that uses them
  for two- or multi-way communication has violated their purpose.

* The "purpose of" Unix was to provide an operating system for
  multi-user login and processing servers. So Linus adapting it to run
  on personal computers, PDAs, and embedded devices has violated its
  purpose.

Like I said, I share your frustration with the way DNS is often
administered -- but I don't think that shoving software into a box and
saying "you can do this, but nothing else" is the answer.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Oct  1 06:38:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Oct  1 06:38:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] pdf file and ocr: closure
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310010630380.13957@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  A couple of days ago I asked for help in disassembling a pdf file. Turns
out that the file was scanned, not generated from the original digital text
file so it's in bitmapped format. I tried printing the file to produce a
postscript output that I ran through 'convert'. But, when gocr chewed on the
output of that step only the first page printed as text.

  I now know the solution and offer it here to close this thread: pdftopbm.
This is a tool found in the xpdf tootbox. It converts each page of the
scanned pdf file to a one-page pbm file, each of which can then be
individually run through gocr. For this pdf file, I'll have 129 output files
so I'll throw together a shell script to process each file.

  This restores my faith in linux/FOSS: there _is_ a way to do almost
everything.

Rich

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Wed Oct  1 08:41:02 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Wed Oct  1 08:41:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Recompiling a kernel without USB
In-Reply-To: <20031001134216.9631.17242.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20031001134216.9631.17242.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20031001153950.GA27060@gate.kl-ic.com>

> Subject: Re: [PLUG] how to remove usb
> 
> Mike De La Mater wrote:
> > RH 7.1, I want usb support out. This server will never need it.
> > I cannot find any package, man file or anything that has anything
> > to do with these. It looks like I could remove all of the usb
> > devices from /dev and the init script would not load it, but that
> > seems crude.
> 
> Recompile your kernel.  The overhead is probably minimal though.
...
> > >Recompile your kernel without USB support, 
> > 
> > I hope to never (never say never) compile a kernel. Isn't there
> > an easier way?
> > 
> > Hotplug is not installed.

I am a chip designer and a hardware weenie - sometimes it seems I
can't write a "hello world" program and get it to compile.  That
said, I have recompiled Linux kernels to add and subtract features -
the procedures described in the Redhat reference manual are pretty
good.  The kernel sources install easily from an RPM (as opposed to
the *.src.rpm files, which are a bit trickier) and the procedure is
a series of simple and reversable (if slow) steps.  The main thing
you need is patience, a good procedure for saving .config files, 
and about 300MB of space in /usr/src .  Redhat 7.1 uses grub, and
that makes it easy to add an alternate kernel for testing, then
switch over once you are satisfied.

Learning how to compile and install a kernel is an empowering thing -
you have ultimate power over the core of your own machine.  It is
kind of like sex;  after your first time, the world looks different.
You will have a much better understanding of *why* GNU/Linux is there
and why so many people spend so much time adding to it.  

The Linux Clinic is probably a good place to do this (if you have
a slow machine, get there early;  this could take a while).  I'm 
sure the folks running the clinic will get the a voyeuristic thrill
out of helping a "kernel virgin" through their first time.  Much
better than helping find some obscure hardware flaw.  Take notes!

Finally, regards USB and Hotswap - the 7.1 Redhat kernel probably
didn't do that very well, it gets better in later kernels.  But it
is handy - I use USB2 hotswap on my server, as part of my disk-to-disk
backup system.  I am running a 2.4.20 kernel with custom mods and
patches, and *.20 does single-drive USB2 hotswap pretty well.  See
my page  http://www.keithl.com/linuxbackup.html  (under development).

I'm not saying you should keep USB - you should learn to compile
it out, then compile and run a more recent kernel (they are usually
backwards compatable), then learn to modify the new one, then add
USB2 back.  Not because any of this is necessary to running an
off-the-CD distro, of course, but because it is *fun*. 

Compiling kernels - do it with someone you love, today!

Keith

Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

I'd guess that kudzu is looking for new hardware, and also that usb is all
done through modules.

Try putting this in your /etc/modules.conf
  alias usb-controller off

Note that I haven't done this myself, it's just my best guess.

This should work, although you may want to run the output through some

find $HOME ! -type d | xargs file | grep script

much trouble with that though.  I'm not just after filtering,
I want to unsubscribe from spam also whenever possible as the
loss of good bandwidth is another issue.  You want the
blocking of a spammer to get as close to the spammer as 
possible.  Even if that means that the local police at this 
person's location visit him/her.

The prupose of wanting correct dns is to be able to detect
where a message is coming from, this doesn't take into account
though that a spammer could forge a valid address of some other
place.  If a site spamming you won't deal with abuse
where else can you send a complaint?  I'm talking UCE or
even worse.

  # The recipient's address
  ENV_TO=$1

:0: fwh
  * ^To: good at host.domain.com
  /var/spool/mail/reported_good

forward the rest of the mail to user at forward_host.domain.com after
having first re-written the "To:" field (remember the "$ENV_TO" variable
I mentioned above. Never mind why...well, okay, it's because Exchange is

  :0 fwh
     | formail -I"To: "$ENV_TO"@"

"$ENV_TO" rule, procmail simply grabs onto the "ENV_TO" rule and
processes it first!

Would anyone like to give me a clue why the latter rule is processed
before the first rule?!!?

From david.fleck at mchsi.com  Wed Oct  1 12:44:01 2003
From: david.fleck at mchsi.com (David Fleck)
Date: Wed Oct  1 12:44:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Shell script syntax
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310011138410.14883@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310011138410.14883@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20031001143620.P22402@grond.sourballs.org>

On Wed, 1 Oct 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   I have 129 files to run through the gocr program; they're all in a single
> directory. Is the following the proper syntax to run the conversion?
>
> for i in *.pbm;
>   do `gocr -o $i.txt -i $1.pbm`;
> done

probably not, because each $i will have a format like 'foo.pbm', and your
do line will try to read foo.pbm.pbm and write to foo.pbm.txt.

Using bash's parameter substitution capabilities, you probably want to do
something like this:

for i in *.pbm; do
	j=${i%%.pbm}.txt
	gocr -o $j -i $i
done

the second line says, "take whatever's in $i, chop off .pbm from the end,
feed the results into $j, and tack on .txt".

--
David Fleck
david.fleck at mchsi.com

From sandy at herring.org  Wed Oct  1 13:05:02 2003
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Wed Oct  1 13:05:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Procmail Ignores Rule
In-Reply-To: <1065035590.23326.306.camel@sparticus>
References: <1065035590.23326.306.camel@sparticus>
Message-ID: <20031001200430.GA759@kippered.herring.org>

On Wed, 01 Oct 2003, Cooper Stevenson wrote: 
> All,
> 
> First, I have an environment variable in /etc/procmailrc that grabs the
> "user" portion of the recipient's email address:
> 
>   # The recipient's address
>   ENV_TO=$1
> 
> I have this rule so that all emails addressed to "good at host.domain.com"
> are placed in the /var/spool/mail/reported_good file:
> 
> :0: fwh
>   * ^To: good at host.domain.com
>   /var/spool/mail/reported_good
> 
> Fine. I know this worked before I added the rule outlined below.
> 
> Now, I want to say, "If the sender's address isn't good at host.domain.com,
> forward the rest of the mail to user at forward_host.domain.com after
> having first re-written the "To:" field (remember the "$ENV_TO" variable
> I mentioned above. Never mind why...well, okay, it's because Exchange is
> stupid:
> 
>   :0 fwh
>      | formail -I"To: "$ENV_TO"@"
>      :0
>        ! "$ENV_TO"@forward_host.domain.com
> 
> The only trouble is that even though the "To:" rule is above the
> "$ENV_TO" rule, procmail simply grabs onto the "ENV_TO" rule and
> processes it first!
> 
> Would anyone like to give me a clue why the latter rule is processed
> before the first rule?!!?

Cooper,

I suspect what's happening is that the To: rule is being processed - but in
procmail's cache. The second recipe doesn't see that change. I believe what
you need to do is let your MDA do the rerouting to the new delivery address.
Try...

    # deliver it
    :0 w
    ! -t

...instead of your second rule. Have your set VERBOSE=yes to see exactly
what's happening?

Sandy

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed Oct  1 13:48:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Wed Oct  1 13:48:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Shell script syntax
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310011138410.14883@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310011138410.14883@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <86pthg3ctj.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Rich>   I have 129 files to run through the gocr program; they're all
Rich> in a single directory. Is the following the proper syntax to run
Rich> the conversion?

Nope.

Rich> for i in *.pbm; do `gocr -o $i.txt -i $1.pbm`; done

a) that's not what backticks are for (if you don't know what they do,
   you shouldn't be using them);

b) $1 is a typo;

c) .pbm is already part of what I assume you intended to be $i; and

d) (as stated elsewhere) $i.txt should probably be ${i%%.pbm}.txt.

From alex at daniloff.com  Wed Oct  1 16:34:02 2003
From: alex at daniloff.com (Alex Daniloff)
Date: Wed Oct  1 16:34:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] No more Red Hat for us reg'lar folks
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310011539120.15602@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200310012327.h91NRRf31147@gate.daniloff.com>

Back in 1998 I was looking for a good Linux distro to settle on.
I've tried almost all Linux distros available at that time, looking
at them from all possible angles. 
Quality of the software engineering, included packages and 
a general philosophy behind the distro.
Red Had has always looked to me as a public American company which
makes hypes out of nothing, mainly to promote its stocks.
Kind'a Red Hat=Linux mantra. 
I liked more intelligent and rational engineering approach to Linux.
I finally went with privately owned German SuSE Linux distro. These
SuSE guys have never made any hypes providing superior to Red Hat
Linux distro for engineers and home users. 
Our whole eng. dept. runs on SuSE Linux since 1999.
Looks like I made a right choice back then.

Just my $0.02

Alex

This isn't a slam on SuSE, they have their good points. I have a couple
of SuSE boxes, as well as RH, Mandrake, Turbo, and various others. 

The only problem I have with SuSE, is that you can't get a "real" set of
CD's from them without purchasing a box. 

The demo they have is a demo iso, and runs from the CD. 

You can install over the net, but that's long and virtually requires
broadband. Not something I have everywhere I want to install. 

I've burned a few coasters, but in the long run, I've had very little
trouble with burned media. Basically, check the MD5 after burning.

From freyley at gmx.net  Wed Oct  1 19:24:02 2003
From: freyley at gmx.net (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Wed Oct  1 19:24:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ACPI and suspend on a Dell Inspiron 4000 with Debian
	unstable
In-Reply-To: <1065039997.671.8.camel@localhost>
References: <1065003437.672.6.camel@localhost>
	 <E1A4jPd-0001Li-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> <1065039997.671.8.camel@localhost>
Message-ID: <1065061397.641.5.camel@localhost>

On Wed, 2003-10-01 at 13:26, Jeff Schwaber wrote:
> On Wed, 2003-10-01 at 09:00, russell-evans at qwest.net wrote:
> > acpid running?
> 
> acpid running, no obvious errors in /var/log/acpid.

Well, I thought I found the problem. The Debian kernel images have the
following config option:

# CONFIG_SOFTWARE_SUSPEND is not set

So I compiled a new kernel, with everything else the same, but

CONFIG_SOFTWARE_SUSPEND=y

But I still get 

cat: /proc/acpi/sleep: No such file or directory

and echo 1 > /proc/acpi/sleep gives me

bash: /proc/acpi/sleep: No such file or directory

So nothing's changed. 

For people curious, the reason I'm harping on this is that with the 2.6
kernel my computer is actually usable again, as far as a desktop is
concerned (in comparison, the 2.4 kernels are slower than beyond belief,
even with the preempt patch applied). Of course, there's still this
problem, and the problem of the Synaptics Touchpads not working because
the only driver for them in XFree86 is experimental, and they stopped
doing the psaux emulation of them in the 2.6 series.

So...for desktop users, try upgrading to 2.6. For laptops, well...good
luck. It's absolutely amazing the difference.

Jeff

You probably want to read the docs on software suspend that came with
the kernel source.  I don't think it has to do with ACPI (or

of the hardware.

Not that this isn't a solution, it just may not be what you expect.

> concerned (in comparison, the 2.4 kernels are slower than beyond belief,
> even with the preempt patch applied). Of course, there's still this
> problem, and the problem of the Synaptics Touchpads not working because
> the only driver for them in XFree86 is experimental, and they stopped
> doing the psaux emulation of them in the 2.6 series.
> 
> So...for desktop users, try upgrading to 2.6. For laptops, well...good
> luck. It's absolutely amazing the difference.
> 
> Jeff

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Wed Oct  1 22:36:02 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Wed Oct  1 22:36:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] No more Red Hat ...
Message-ID: <20031002053452.GB31254@gate.kl-ic.com>

< Redhat becomes Fedora ... >

I buy Redhat for the network effect - my solutions help others, their
solutions help me.  Also, they have from time to time helped me 
resolve problems.  

The move towards Fedora will probably destroy the network built up 
around Redhat - there won't be a lot of newbies asking stupid questions
about Fedora, so I won't be as likely to find the answers I need to
the same stupid questions by searching the web.  I can afford Enterprise,
but most of the newbie network can't.

Redhat has usually been about the right distance back from the
brink of the bleeding edge.  Also, I am one of those benighted fools
who has tried both KDE and Gnome and likes Gnome a little better.  

Suse seems a little more bleeding edge, while Debian-stable seems to
be built like a tank in an age of aircraft.  I know I ought to like 
Debian better.  I tried running Suse for a while;  configs and such
weren't where I expected them to be, and of course Suse is a little
more geared towards KDE.  

So the Redhat move has me a little worried, yes.  But I think it will
create opportunities.  The need for a domestic boxed distro hasn't
gone away, and maybe Debian will move into that slot.  Manual sets?
I assume Tim O'Reilly can do a better job, especially if he buys the
rights to the Redhat set as a starting point.  Also, this makes a
Cygnus Solutions style support business just that much more
attractive.   Perhaps a bunch of you unemployed types should make
contact with the folks out at Stream about setting up a 1-900 Linux
support group for Fedora.  More ideas in a following email.

When it all settles out, the new possibilities will be great, because
open source permits rapid commercial innovation.  But for now, the
uncertainty about new directions is difficult to live with.

Keith

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Oct  1 22:59:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed Oct  1 22:59:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] replacing multipule instances of text
In-Reply-To: <1064906744.13783.101.camel@alexlinux.qwest.net>
References: <1064906744.13783.101.camel@alexlinux.qwest.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0310012255030.29987@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 30 Sep 2003, alex wrote:
>         Ive searched high and low but have not been able to find a
> solution to this problem. For the background, I run a photo web
> server(around 600 pages or so and growing) at my home for a track club
> here in the Portland area. They recently acquired their own domain-name
> and I need
> to replace all the homepage links in the HTML with the updated address.
>
> ex. replace www.foobar.com/RCTC/ with www.RCTC.com/
>
>         My question is..... is there an easy way to do this other than
> the obvious highlight and pasting of text?
>
>         I'm using MDL9.1 and Apache.
>
>         Any help will be greatly appreciated.

The perly ways are probably the ways I'd do it... or use my copy of sed
which includes a friend's patch so that it takes a perl-like -i switch.

Have you considered just sucking down the pages with wget using the -k
option (--convert-links)?

>From `man wget`:
       -k

       --convert-links
           After the download is complete, convert the links in
           the document to make them suitable for local viewing.
           This affects not only the visible hyperlinks, but any
           part of the document that links to external content,
           such as embedded images, links to style sheets, hyper-
           links to non-HTML content, etc.

           Each link will be changed in one of the two ways:

           o   The links to files that have been downloaded by
               Wget will be changed to refer to the file they
               point to as a relative link.

               Example: if the downloaded file /foo/doc.html
               links to /bar/img.gif, also downloaded, then the
               link in doc.html will be modified to point to
               ../bar/img.gif.  This kind of transformation works
               reliably for arbitrary combinations of directo-
               ries.

           o   The links to files that have not been downloaded
               by Wget will be changed to include host name and
               absolute path of the location they point to.

               Example: if the downloaded file /foo/doc.html
               links to /bar/img.gif (or to ../bar/img.gif), then
               the link in doc.html will be modified to point to
               http://hostname/bar/img.gif.

           Because of this, local browsing works reliably: if a
           linked file was downloaded, the link will refer to its
           local name; if it was not downloaded, the link will
           refer to its full Internet address rather than pre-
           senting a broken link.  The fact that the former links
           are converted to relative links ensures that you can
           move the downloaded hierarchy to another directory.

           Note that only at the end of the download can Wget
           know which links have been downloaded.  Because of
           that, the work done by -k will be performed at the end
           of all the downloads.

J.

     Jeme A Brelin

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Oct  1 23:22:01 2003

On Tue, 30 Sep 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> Is there no way to encourage sites to set up DNS
> correctly?  Is dns a hopelessly untested system?

No and yes.

The system works.  It just doesn't do what you want it to do right now.

> It's seems ridiculous that people are giving up on determining intent
> before allowing anyone to connect to their server and inject data or
> programs into it.  Maybe a filter will keep the inbox clean, but
> downloading a message and the deleting it without any intention of
> reading it is downright inefficient.

As I've written a million times before, efficiency is a red herring.

Efficiency is a quality of an entire system.  Your computer is just one
small part of the system.  Accepting the data and then deleting it may not
be efficient in your little closed space, but that approach makes the
whole system of email delivery VERY efficient and effective because it
ensures that all mail gets delivered.  If there is then a failure, it is
your fault in the deleting.

Effective is more important than efficient.

Efficiency isn't something that a person can imbue.  It is something that
is born of complexity and evolves.

J.

doesn't have what you need, then try "testing".  If that doesn't have
what you need, then try "unstable".  FYI, the "old-stable" (potato) is
still getting security updates.

Hash: SHA1

On Thu, Oct 02, 2003 at 02:45:17AM -0700, Russell Senior wrote:
> News to me.  Testing has been around for quite a while (3 years?).

A year and a half, two tops, IIRC.

> Can you point to where you got the idea that "testing" is "temporary"?

Prior experience.  Unstable forks a testing, which rolls over to
frozen, which then becomes stable by bumping the incumbent stable into
the archive.  testing and frozen have been mutually exclusive so far,
and it's usually several weeks to months before a new Testing forks
off.

shouldn't outrun a Pentium III. :-)

blocked from another server I could resolve names quite 
fast.  Why would you block 127.0.0.0/8 addresses?  That

protocol at the expense of multiple files instead of just 
one.  Then again, the sourcing section where I stamp

protocols, which is nice.  I'm not a big fan of long
scripts or programs anyways.  On the upside, my 
add/remove forwarding for a single host command works 
quickly for the first time as I'm not waiting to time out
anymore every time I run it.

BTW, I have the source tree I installed sendmail-8.12.9 from.
Is there an easy way to remove the files sendmail installed

I could do rpm -qf on every file on the hard drive, but

by any rpm.

work right.  I had to replace chkconfig with the
7.3 version along with db3 and db3-devel to get Postfix on
there.  After that, I manually created the same accounts for 
Postfix that were on an actual Redhat 7.3 server right down

From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Thu Oct  2 05:22:02 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Thu Oct  2 05:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] No more Red Hat for us reg'lar folks
In-Reply-To: <20031001235854.GC7264@sthelens.dimstar.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310011539120.15602@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<200310012327.h91NRRf31147@gate.daniloff.com> 
	<20031001235854.GC7264@sthelens.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <1065097141.3543.73.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

I thought the Enterprise Edition, if it's worth the extra money, paid
for the lower cost version.  I've bought boxed sets, do they really
lose too much money?  I think part of the problem is that there has
been too much focus on emulation and not enough on moving people
to new software where your company can program for Linux from
day one and do better programming.

One problem I see is that there needs to be more focus on getting
Linux considered first.  Seems like Linux distributions are unfairly
having to adapt to new hardware at a disadvantage because the
information to do this either has be hacked out of electronic
devices or developers have to wait for it to be made more broadly
available.

A lot of people aren't considering Linux because there is a software
environment where still for the most part only people willing to
go out on the net for software can really get it.  This
becomes more true with the discontinuation of a low cost boxed 
Redhat product.  

The other problem area is how instabilities are integrated into Linux
distributions.  The ideal way to do this is to make any instability  
easily removable or circumventable without making a future fix of
the problem more difficult or cumbersome than it has to be.  I 
wonder what would happen if Redhat did a $100/year subscription 
for a well ironed out, reasonably cutting edge, distribution without
tying anyone in to a proprietary quagmire?  This is about what 
Windows users are shelling out, isn't it?  The focus should be 
not only more stable, but also easier to learn how to administrate 
and reliable local support.  How many people are unhappy about not
having a place to go to take their computer, tell someone what they 
want, and know they can pick it up later with the confidence the 
job was done right?  If it can be shown Linux provides a better
software environment than Windows and the Internet is grounded to
standards that are not Miroshaft centric, Linux really has a
chance to compete.  And not only Linux, but all the other
alternatives as well that have been languishing.  One thing Linux
users should be able to afford is training, but it's going to take
advertinsing to develop demand for any such service and the focus
has to be using the money you save on cheaper licensing and greater
freedom get this training.  

My dad won't try to move to Linux talking
about picking up an expensive subscription for Windows software
even though I have told him have a dozen things have been done
to his computers that are flat wrong by a certified Windows 
system builder who should know better.  I have no MCSE, but
I know this guy is screwing up big time.  I also know my
dad is talking a lot of money for software that probably 
won't be worth what he'll pay for it.

His hard drive failed, but he didn't even come to me to 
get it fixed.   I know what kind he needed and even where 
to get one because I've been working on making his machine 
not only fixable but Linux compatible too.  His complaint 
is that he can't come to me because he doesn't want to rely 
on me.  That said, he got a hard drive his motherboard and 
even on board upgrade card won't support properly where the 
drivers this dork installed are totally the wrong ones.
It cost my dad $140 where I could have gotten the right
hard drive twice as big for $80 and fixed it right.

     --  Michael Robinson

On Thu, 2003-10-02 at 06:24, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Wed, 1 Oct 2003, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> 
> > That's a good idea if you leave out Stream.
> 
>   Didn't LinuxCare try this? Why didn't that make a ton of money?

Because at the time LinuxCare was launched, there was relatively
small amounts of Linux installed in environments that had the
money to pay for support. While there was lots of Linux running
in Corporate America, most of it did not get there as a result
of dictums from upper management. IT staff and middle managers
installed it on their own initiative using existing budgets.

Of course, Linux is more popular now and a Linux support organization
would likely do better. Still, a support
organization will have to be bootstrapped and there may not be
tons of money to be made - at first or ever. But there should
be enough to live on for an organization that's not top heavy
like LinuxCare.

Ed

>i810. So now it runs in VESA mode with ugly 680x480 resolution.
>Could somebody please give me a hint if this laptop's
>graphic chipset is supported in Linux at all.
>How can I fix this issue.

>Many thanks in advance.

>Alex

Alex,

	I'm just going to go out on a limb and assume the laptop is either brand new or
that you have flashed your bios. My 1100 worked fine right out of the box, but the newer
ones have a new bios that really messes up video support not only in Linux, but in Windows.
You probably haven't noticed in Windows because Dell has made their own driver for the card.
The stock intel drivers will no longer work. The good news is that there is a patch for it.
Go to this website for lots of helpful information.
	Once you get that fixed, if you need anything like XF86Config files or Kernel config
files (for the 2.6 kernels, anyway) just let me know. Mine's running quite nice now.

-josh

From freyley at gmx.net  Thu Oct  2 11:08:01 2003
From: freyley at gmx.net (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Thu Oct  2 11:08:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] No more Red Hat ...
In-Reply-To: <3F7BDE88.8080102@spek.org>
References: <20031002053452.GB31254@gate.kl-ic.com>
	 <20031002070245.GD13793@ursine.ca>  <3F7BDE88.8080102@spek.org>
Message-ID: <1065118057.606.8.camel@localhost>

On Thu, 2003-10-02 at 01:15, Brent Rieck wrote:
> Paul Johnson wrote:
> > Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> > > Debian-stable seems to be built like a tank in an age of aircraft.
> > 
> > Stable is maintained for the sake of people who need absolute
>  > stability and new users, unstable is more geared towards the
> > lunatic fringe.
> 
> Is there a Debian that's not old and crusty but also not "geared towards 
> the lunatic fringe"?

Yes. The answer, as some have said, is testing. 

Testing was introduced a few years ago with the intent of providing a
step between unstable and stable. There were no plans, as far as I know,
for it to go away. There will be a frozen (and there has never before
been a frozen and a testing, but there will be now) because testing was
introduced with the intention of providing users who didn't want to
trust unstable with a little testing.

If you want to know what it actually is, here's the current standard:
unstable is where the developers put updates and new packages. Testing
is anything that was in unstable for two weeks and passed the build
system in that time. So testing is two weeks behind unstable. Which is
usually enough.

There is a movement to use experimental more, so code snapshots, things
which are truly the bleeding edge, will more and more be put into
experimental (hopefully), and there is no automatic method for moving
from experimental to unstable.

With that said, I use unstable, generally. Sometimes when you apt-get
update && apt-get dist-upgrade, you'll get caught in a bad place for a
little while. But most of the time, you don't. 

Now, if only someone would rewrite apt-get to allow it to rollback
previous actions. If anyone else is interested in this project, tell me
and maybe we could actually do it. I just don't have the energy to do it
myself.

Jeff




From keithl at kl-ic.com  Thu Oct  2 11:25:02 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Thu Oct  2 11:25:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux support business
Message-ID: <20031002182403.GA3480@gate.kl-ic.com>

This is an elaboration of an earlier suggestion about forming a Linux
support company.  As others have pointed out, places like Linuxcare
haven't managed to fill this niche, and places like Stream are hell
to work for.  The first question to ask before starting any unique
venture is "why hasn't this already been done?"  If the answers seem
to involve dark conspiracies or mass evil, then this indicates a need
for psychiatric help, not a business startup loan.  I won't go into
details of starting a business, there are books out there for that,
and if we can't roughly agree on that information it is a waste of
time to proceed here.  So let's proceed on the assumption that normal
business principles ( legality, profitability, salability, productivity,
scalability, tolerability, etc. ) apply.  If you want to argue with
those, go start your own business, succeed, and write your own books.
At least, start your own thread about the wickedness of commercialism;
we are focused on a different problem here.

Since this is an innovation in software, I would suggest reading the
books "The Inmates are Running the Asylum" by Alan Cooper, and "The
Innovators Dilemma" by Clayton Christensen. The first book is about
product design for use, with a focus on software;  the second is about
how "cheap plus good enough" takes over existing niches.  You can find
out a lot more about these two books by Googling. 

A business solves the problems that others perceive, in return for
their money.  While that process can get mighty distorted, you do
not succeed by betting against it.  So the question is, whose money
do we want, and what problems do they have that we can solve?

Companies and rich people have money.  We want them to give us some
of that money.  They also have problems, some of which have Linux
solutions.  We can solve those problems.  At some point, we can also
solve consumer problems, but consumers have more varied problems and
their individual piles of money are smaller and more trouble to get
at.  It will take a fairly large service company to serve consumers,
and we aren't there yet.  However, when we go after the big piles
we face some competition;  we have to look for those piles where we
face less competition.  If we can manage to keep those simple facts
in mind, we can build a business.

I suspect the biggest available piles with low competition are 5-50
employee companies in the category "other".  They are big enough to
have a company network, there are no targeted software solutions
(restaurants, medical offices, auto shops, etc. already have solutions,
though weak ones), and chances are the owner or manager also spends
time taking care of the damned computers - when they should be growing
the business, so they have more money to pay us.  

So the "avatar" customer (see Cooper) is a middle-aged small entrepreneur,
fairly tight with money, who wants to get more out of her computers
with less time spent.  She doesn't want problems, but she doesn't care
about manuals and RFCs and standards (that's OUR problem).  The company
must be able to share data with suppliers and customers using Windoze,
Mac, etc.  The employees use email and the web (browsing and website),
and most are not computer-hygenic.  While she would probably like
specialized software focused on her individual business, it isn't
there yet.  She probably needs Quickbooks running under Wine, so we
can't afford ideological purity.

All that said, we can keep the machines up, provide basic applications, 
keep viruses out, write little functional scripts to solve point tasks,
and do 24x7 maintenance far more effectively and cheaply than she can
get the same things done with a Windoze solution.  Maybe we don't have
the chrome, or the games, or the industry-specific apps (though many
of those can run under Wine or Win4Lin or even offsite).  We cannot
give a flashy demo, so we will have to trade on our strengths -
FREEDOM, availability, adaptability, and - potentially - attitude. 

Attitude will be the big challenge - software people are intellectually
smart, and this leads to bad attitudes and ego.  Nobody pays for that.
In years past, Microsoft displayed slightly less attitude during the
critical growth period of the industry.  Because they were slightly
less disgusting for users than their competitors (or at least convinced
people of that, which amounts to the same thing in business), they
captured the desktop, and captured the interchange standards, and now
own the commons.  So they are now back to the "screw you, luser"
mentality, and act like they are invulnerable.  This is a hell of an
opportunity for folks who are smart enough to write and support code
that turns lusers into winners.  I think, with some attitude adjustments,
we are those smart people.

The first thing needed are enough friendly, generalist problem solvers
to form a 24x7 2x redundant first-response phone/web team.  Asterisk
might make a good rallying point.  Can Squeak Smalltalk be made to run
as a background process, and drive browser windows?  I understand Smalltalk
is good for rapid prototyping, which will be needed for numerous point
solutions and quick-fixes.  The day team will need folks that can meet
with customers, learn their needs, and code them rapidly.  Of course,
we will have VPN tunnels into customer machines, and some fairly
fine-grained permission systems to maintain customer security.  That will
need some backroom geeks, but not many.  As things evolve and the process
scales, we will need to develop securely accessable customer profiles, so
strangers can help strangers.  And we will need ways to profitably exchange 
point apps and code modules with other service providers, so we can
maintain profitability as we expand downwards towards the complexity
of individual consumers. 

Well, that is an awfully long ramble.  Perhaps we can discuss it more
tonight, at the Lab.

Keith
    
-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From serendipity at pobox.com  Thu Oct  2 12:21:01 2003
From: serendipity at pobox.com (Brian Quade)
Date: Thu Oct  2 12:21:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux support business
References: <20031002182403.GA3480@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <3F7C7774.5000002@pobox.com>

I was just thinking about that same idea only minutes before I got this 
message.  I wonder how much demand there would be for such a service, at 
least initially, because Linux users still tend to be mostly fringe 
people who can solve their own problems and businesses are likely to 
find gurus out there who would gladly work for a reasonable wage right 
now, but that will change some day (hopefully soon) whenever the economy 
picks up.

Linux has only been embraced by certain businesses, although it seems to 
be growing.  Another huge market would be government if anyone can ever 
convince state and local governments that wasting our money on systems 
that are full of problems and then wasting more of our money on 
high-paid "experts" to fix those problems is a bad idea.  I know about 
this first hand, my dad used to be the CIO for another state.  (I never 
heard if the Oregon legislature voted to start using open source 
software whenever possible like they were discussing earlier this year.)

I had another thought too.  While you are right that the money to 
support such a venture would have to come from wealthier individuals and 
companies, reaching out to individual users, non-profits, schools, 
libraries, etc. would affect greater numbers of people.  And the way I 
see it, it is kind of in the open source spirit to make such a service 
availabe to all users.  So I had an idea about how this might be done 
and still remain profitable.

Create a for-profit business that would make money from supporting 
companies, governments, and wealthier individuals.  Create an affiliated 
501c4 (or other type of non-profit?) that could have a few paid 
employees (more like entry level positions, interns, etc.) and charge 
people based on income level, system, type of support/problem, number of 
computers, or some other criteria.  I believe there are ways that you 
can deduct money donated to a 501c4, but if that would be a problem I am 
sure there is some other way around it (a 501c2 perhaps??).  Charging 
people an affordable fee for service would minimize the expense of 
subsidizing the non-profit while providing a deduction for the portion 
that was subsidized.  Then you would have two distinct enterprises and 
two distinct markets and would be supporting the entire Linux community.

I think it is a good idea to make something like this grow out of the 
Linux community rather than letting venture capitalists come in and 
saturate the support market as Linux becomes more popular and try to 
water it down to support their own personal business interests (not that 
they could ever do that, but they would certainly try).

Anyway, that was the idea that I had just this morning.

I'd say the answer is simple: we are computer nerds, not salesmen.

I doubt any of us (okay, I'll admit I'm talking about me) find any
enjoyment calling strangers about 75 times a day, dealing with the
inevitable rejection, in order to get to the one or two interviews
that might actually lead to a sale. And if one doesn't get the sales,
how is one to get the work?

Yes, there are people who hang out a shingle, & get a steady stream
of computer-related work. But their customers are the ones who say,
``Gimme some of that stuff I saw on tv last night." And they're talking
about Microsoft-oriented software & hardware -- which is what gets
advertised.

super-businessmen that they've been portrayed to be.)

Unfortunately, Christensen's book has become something of a cliche. He
presented his thesis in a simple, and convincing manner, but the thesis
can be explained in a few sentences. I'd say that it is describing
the situation Microsoft is facing right now -- that not only is Open
Source less expensive & at least as good as many Windows-based
solutions -- but their own business model has locked them into a
strategy that is growing less effective in competing with Open Source
on a daily basis.

I think it's not a statement of faith to say that Open Source
solutions will eventually push out traditional MS software in all
significant software catagories, but an accurate fact. However,
it's also a fact that unless one of us figures out how to use this
to make a living & shares the secret, none of us will benefit from
this deveopment. (Unless you can afford to short MS stock over a

From drl at drloree.com  Thu Oct  2 14:45:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Thu Oct  2 14:45:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] software RAID
In-Reply-To: <1065119178.1135.5.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <1065119178.1135.5.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <1065131851.698.49.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Thu, 2003-10-02 at 11:26, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> Is software RAID worth doing?
> 
> I've got a situation where it may be a good idea, but I'm not sure. I
> used to use mirrored drives, and liked the idea.
> 
> What do you all think?

Like most things, it depends on the job that needs to get done.  The
Linux implementation of software RAID doesn't have much overhead, which
is good, but it does seem to have some minor problems.  However, I've
found that once the RAID is configured and synced, it works quite well. 
I don't like the hoops that need to jumped through to get a software
RAID device to boot.

The biggest advantage is $$$.  IDE drives are not just inexpensive (the
I in RAID), they are getting to be downright cheap.  This is a very
small cost for an added layer of recoverability (this is not a
substitute for regular backups).  For workstations and low overhead
servers, I have a hard time justifying NOT setting up mirrored
partitions these days.

For robust, busy servers, hardware RAID is the only way to go.

Derek Loree

unstable on my workstation.

Only twice did an 'apt-get update' cause my workstation to break beyond use.  But, I
waited a day (two at the very most), did another 'apt-get update', and everything
was back to normal.

These days I still run stable on my servers (currently woody), and testing on my
workstations.  No issues.  When testing moves to stable I move my workstations to
stable for 6 months or so before going into testing again.

I've also had very good luck with getting testing/unstable deb's to install in
stable.  Sure there was one time where it kicked off an perl dependency upgrade from
hell, but other than that.. ;)

-- 
I'm just a packet pusher.

From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Thu Oct  2 16:39:01 2003

Why has there been so much talk of buying out or controlling Linux?
Doesn't everyone know that Linux cannot be bought out?  You can't
even sell a proprietary system derived from Linux code only being
able to replace the system libraries and utilities.  The kernel if
it's a true Linux system is going to be open.  It's discouraging
that Sun, Microsoft, etc. are focusing more on being able to sell
proprietary systems in place of OSS than providing services for 
users of OSS.  Is it just me or are we hearing software isn't
"profitable" yet the price of it is steadily increasing? 
I'm starting to wonder how much of that is inflation.

I think a proprietary OS can make it but it's time for a different
business model that is Linux friendly, because Linux is the server
now.

     --  Michael

Subject: [PLUG] Controlling the scrollbars of a browser?
In-Reply-To: <36953.68.107.223.201.1065117789.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
References: <36953.68.107.223.201.1065117789.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <1065138177.580.289.camel@kat>

On Thu, 2003-10-02 at 11:03, Matt Alexander wrote:
> Let's say you have an HTML document with two frames, a top and a bottom. 
> A large JPG is displayed in the lower frame and the browser scrollbars
> allow you to move around to see the image.
> 
> Next, would it be possible to have navigation elements within the webpage
> that would move the image to a particular x,y coordinate for you?
> 
> As an example, let's say I have a list of items in a menu.  Clicking on
> each item would scroll to the portion of the image that corresponds with
> the menu item.  There would have to be some logic built in that said "Menu
> item 3 is at x,y coordinate 400x250", of course.
> 

I did this in Java and .gifs in 1996, so there should be a number of
applications that do it.

The tricky thing is that everything must be in Java, since getting
information from one doc (frame) to another, and then into the applet
can proved impossible (esp when you have different browsers, and browser
versions).  "Liveconnect" from Netscape was supposed to fix this, but it
was never rock solid.

I do not know of any browser that scrolls horizontally by anchor.

You might do some trick by breaking the image into tables, and jumping
to a cell.  Or making the "window" of visibility limited to the open
frame, and move when you select or hit the edge, just like mapquest. 
But as you mention it is slow, though with small images, and
precropping, you can speed it up.




> Any ideas?  I'm not too concerned about which language would be needed to
> accomplish this, as long as it can work in a web browser.  I've been using
> ImageMagick to dynamically crop the image to the location I want and then
> display that new image, but that's painfully slow, especially if the user
> wants to move through the menu items at any reasonable speed.
> Thanks,
> ~M
>

Maybe.  Java may well be toast anyway because Sun never let it leave home.  
This has frustrated IBM and other companies that wanted to really push Java 
for years.   Losing its parent could kill it off completely.

I thought that OO.o was more or less independent from StarOffice now and that 
the code base was being hacked by a fairly independent group.

While MS may push C#, I'm not aware of any C# implementations that run on big 
non-Windows backend servers.  Mono is definitely not ready for any kind of 
prime time use.  On Windows platforms, C# will cannibalize VB and C++ more 
than Java I suspect.  Is anyone really deploying much Java on Windows these

Windows because that is where the good IDEs are, but deployment?

licensing is handled by the company that buys it.  I cannot see Sun's 
management selling off anything to MS even in extremis. I'd guess that IBM 
will pick up Java and then throw it over the wall to some other organization.

Linux is taking over the server world, Java really isn't in the picture 
anyway.

Productivity and Sun were the two reasons that made me shift away from Java 
coding four years ago.  I haven't felt that to be a mistake yet.

If Java sails off into the land where FORTAN and COBOL live, will universities 
still use Java as the primary instruction language in CS courses?

how that industry remains in business.

Subject: [PLUG] software RAID
In-Reply-To: <200310021518.29958.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <1065119178.1135.5.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
	 <1065131851.698.49.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

Message-ID: <1065143518.1607.66.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Thu, 2003-10-02 at 15:18, Carla Schroder wrote:
> On Thursday 02 October 2003 2:57 pm, Derek Loree wrote:
> > On Thu, 2003-10-02 at 11:26, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> > > Is software RAID worth doing?
> <snip>
> >
> > The biggest advantage is $$$.  IDE drives are not just inexpensive (the
> > I in RAID), they are getting to be downright cheap.  This is a very
> > small cost for an added layer of recoverability (this is not a
> > substitute for regular backups).  For workstations and low overhead
> > servers, I have a hard time justifying NOT setting up mirrored
> > partitions these days.
> 
> Yup, it's a nice thing to have, for all the reasons you said.
> >
> > For robust, busy servers, hardware RAID is the only way to go.
> >
> 
> Well, I suppose if I wanted to be overly pedantic, I would say "even with a 
> RAID controller, software is running the show." :)  I think for hardworking 
> servers it's more important to have SCSI drives, RAID or not. And I agree 
> that a good hardware RAID controller is a lovely thing to have.

Oops, one of those things that goes without saying.  I don't consider
the IDE "RAID Controllers" to be real RAID cards.

As far as I know, the only "real" hardware RAID controllers are SCSI,
the IDE controllers that claim to be hardware RAID controllers are
actually using software to do the controlling (I think this is inherent
in the IDE control scheme, with most of the control on the drive, not
the card).

For a robust configuration, hot-swap RAID, with SCSI drives is the only
way to go.

Derek Loree




From aaron at speakeasy.org  Thu Oct  2 18:25:02 2003
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Thu Oct  2 18:25:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] software RAID
In-Reply-To: <1065143518.1607.66.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0310021802020.23891-100000@aluminum.bavariati.org>

On Thu, 2 Oct 2003, Derek Loree wrote:
> As far as I know, the only "real" hardware RAID controllers are SCSI,
> the IDE controllers that claim to be hardware RAID controllers are
> actually using software to do the controlling (I think this is inherent
> in the IDE control scheme, with most of the control on the drive, not
> the card).

Some IDE RAID cards do the work on the card and look like one big block
device, just like SCSI RAID cards.  3Ware makes ones like that.  Others
are simply multi-channel IDE cards with a special BIOS to ease booting
from software RAID devices.  Promise makes ones like that.

As an aside, I'd like to note that hardware RAID is not always faster
and easier to manage than software RAID.  It really depends on the card,
driver and application.

> For a robust configuration, hot-swap RAID, with SCSI drives is the only
> way to go.

That is indeed a good way to go when it fits budget, needs and usage.

A "different tools for different jobs" B

From aschlemm at comcast.net  Thu Oct  2 22:47:02 2003
From: aschlemm at comcast.net (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu Oct  2 22:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Speaking of the Termination of Distributions
In-Reply-To: <1065147641.6948.26.camel@halo>
References: <200310022244.h92MiZLs016737@m5p.com> <200310021730.12221.kyle@silverbeach.net> <1065147641.6948.26.camel@halo>
Message-ID: <200310022246.28002.aschlemm@comcast.net>

I did quite a bit of work with Swing for a 3 year period and did some 
fairly complex GUIs that were used in a client/server system that 
manages airliner maintenance data. Initially we were using NT 4.0 
clients with 500MHZ PII and things didn't perform all that well. Later 
one when all of the clients got upgraded to 1GHZ PIII running Win2K it 
was hard to tell the difference between the native Window programs or 
the Java ones as the performance of the Swing clients was quite good. 
We used the Java look and feel "Metal" by default so it was obvious we 
were using Java.

The biggest problem for our UI client was that Swing seems to having all 
of the objects holding references to every other object and so the 
swing objects didn't seem to get cleaned up in a timely manner actually 
causing our client to throw OutOfMemoryErrors. I had to write gobs of 
extra code to try to do things like empty  out all of the Containers 
recursively within a window to try to give the GC enough hints that it 
would actually reap the objects. 

I spent weeks running the client through JProbe taking heap snapshots 
and adding code to get things to be garbage collected. The Observable 
pattern is used extensively in the Swing/AWT so objects are holding 
references all over the place which makes it hard to get GC working 
well sometimes. Anyone that says (and I've heard it) "That you don't 
need to worry about memory leaks and other problems in Java." is 
smoking something.

On the server side, where we had no GUI code and only did DB access and 
business rules, we never saw any huge memory leak problems. I found a 
few minor memory leaks with JProbe but nothing compared to what 
AWT/Swing seems to do on its own. I'll have to look at SWT if I work on 
an other Java-based GUI. Lately I've been only doing a bit of EJB work 
in Java and most of my work has shifted over to C++ using Linix and 
Oracle.

C++ was a bit of shock for me after doing nothing but Java programming 
since 1996. Before that I did 5 years of C++ programming under HP/UX 
and thought I knew C++ but it's changed allot with the addition of a 
Standard C++ library. I had a bit of a rocky start but after a couple 
of weeks I've gotten back into the C++ groove and it's been mostly a 
matter of getting up to speed with the STL for me. I've found the 
Josuttis C++ library reference pretty indispensable and I wouldn't be 
as far along on my C++ project had it not been for that book.

Tony

I don't have a list of browsers that'll work in, but I believe the last 
few version of IE and Mozilla/Netscape support it, though probably not 
in IE for the Mac (because it IE for the Mac sucks).

From aschlemm at comcast.net  Fri Oct  3 08:08:02 2003
From: aschlemm at comcast.net (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri Oct  3 08:08:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Speaking of the Termination of Distributions
In-Reply-To: <20031003065453.259F215915B@kanga.canids.net>
References: <20031003065453.259F215915B@kanga.canids.net>
Message-ID: <200310030807.08346.aschlemm@comcast.net>

Yes Java has weak references. It's been a while since I've looked at the 
Swing code but AFAIK neither AWT or Swing use weak references to hold 
references to other objects. I would expect to see some interesting 
failures if they did since as soon as object only has weak references 
to it, it can get garbage collected. 

For example, if I registered some listener object with a component and 
that component used weak references, I'd have to make sure I didn't 
lose the reference to my registered listener as it would get GC'ed if I 
did. It would make debugging a nightmare as the GUI would quit 
responding to events since the listener I previously registered would 
be non-existent.

At it stands now you can create a listener object reference, add it to 
the list of listeners in a component and then drop the reference to the 
listener in your own code. Everything still works since AWT/Swing 
doesn't appear to use weak references. If the Sun implementers had done 
a few simple things like cleaning up all of the containers of object 
references that are inherent in their GUI components it would have 
helped a great deal in dropping object references thereby forcing 
objects to be reaped by the GC.

JProbe's heap snapshots clearly showed that they didn't do that sort of 
cleanup. It's possible that over time the GUI components would get 
cleaned up. We found that GUI object instead tended to linger around 
far too long and if many windows were opened and closed in a short 
period of time, the huge number of lingering GUI objects caused memory 
problems eventually. 

Just doing simple things like emptying out the Container objects and 
setting object references to null when they were no longer needed helps 
the GC to reap objects more quickly. So for a language that supposedly 
frees the programmer of allot of the responsibility in terms of 
deallocating memory, it's not always the case depending on the quality 
of the classes being used. In may cases I couldn't even find that a 
finalize() method existed on many of the GUI-based classes. :-/ 

Tony

From aschlemm at comcast.net  Fri Oct  3 09:24:02 2003
From: aschlemm at comcast.net (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri Oct  3 09:24:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Speaking of the Termination of Distributions
In-Reply-To: <1065194135.7898.43.camel@halo>
References: <200310022244.h92MiZLs016737@m5p.com> <200310022246.28002.aschlemm@comcast.net> <1065194135.7898.43.camel@halo>
Message-ID: <200310030922.47673.aschlemm@comcast.net>

Funny you should mention that. Yes I remember the ACE library and I used 
it at at the company that I eventually got sucked into doing Java 
programming with the JDK 1.01. Along the same lines, I've also found 
the GNU Common C++ Library pretty nice for some things. It provides C++ 
wrapper classes around many of the common Unix facilities. 

If we needed to do our own communication between our components I'd of 
used ACE. We've got some Java and C++ code and we've been using CORBA 
as a way of avoiding doing any JNI programming to allow the Java code 
to uses some C/C++ libraries we have to use in our system. We're using 
omniORB 4.x for our C++ code and it works quite well. The JDK 1.4.X 
includes a decent IDL compiler and we haven't had any problems 
generating Java code from our IDL.

I've had to use some Mutexes in my C++ code as omniORB deploys services 
that are multi-threaded and I didn't want to have to make pthread 
function calls directly. The Common C++ library provides some nice 
Mutex and Thread classes that make multi-threaded programming much 
easier IMHO. I think I've been "Java-tized" a bit and so having a 
Thread class is real comforting. :-)

Tony

From m at pdxlug.org  Fri Oct  3 11:51:02 2003
From: m at pdxlug.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Fri Oct  3 11:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Controlling the scrollbars of a browser?
In-Reply-To: <3F7D1940.1060707@spek.org>
References: <36953.68.107.223.201.1065117789.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org> 
     <3F7D1940.1060707@spek.org>
Message-ID: <36259.68.107.223.201.1065207003.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>

For anyone interested, here's some simple code for moving around in an
image in an iframe:

<html>
<head>
</head>
<body>
<button onClick="myImage.scroll(0,0)">Top</button><br>
<button onClick="myImage.scroll(500,500)">Middle</button><br>
<button onClick="myImage.scroll(500,1000)">Bottom</button><br>
<iframe src="someImage.png" name="myImage" width=600 height=400></iframe>
</body>
</html>

There are ways to classify (and filter) spam that are about as effective
as simple whietlists, but are much more flexible and involve much less
fiddling.  And keep in mind that the From: address is generally faked,
often with domain names and addresses that belong to legitimate users.

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Fri Oct  3 20:14:01 2003
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Fri Oct  3 20:14:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] spam and white lists
In-Reply-To: <1065235206.31877.665.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0310031942500.16331-100000@aluminum.bavariati.org>

On Fri, 3 Oct 2003, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> On Fri, 2003-10-03 at 19:03, Aaron Burt wrote:
> > There are ways to classify (and filter) spam that are about as effective
> > as simple whietlists, but are much more flexible and involve much less
> > fiddling.  And keep in mind that the From: address is generally faked,
> > often with domain names and addresses that belong to legitimate users.
>
> We're talking about a large volume of mail. One goal is to
> turn away the spammers before they consume our bandwidth.
> Techniques that require us to receive the message before we
> decide that they're spam are not acceptable.

I understand.  There are several techniques that work well at that stage.
I'd recommend you look a little further into modern spam-fighting tools
and techniques (especially RBLs) before you invest too much effort.

One bandwidth-saving technique that I'm told works surprisingly well is to
give a temporary (4xx) error to unknown senders.  Spammers rarely retry
errors, so if the sender retries, it's probably OK and can be whitelisted.
(And have its mail subjected to further classification.)

The important bit here is to do something effective without incurring
excessive costs in programming or maintenance time.


The spammers don't deserve it,
  Aaron

From aschlemm at comcast.net  Fri Oct  3 22:12:02 2003

You might try the "expand" utility which converts tabs to spaces. By 
default it converts each <TAB> to 8 spaces but I believe you can tell 
it how many spaces you want each <TAB> converted to. If you want to 
convert spaces to <TAB> use "unexpand".

Tony

On Fri, 2003-10-03 at 19:53, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> On Fri, 2003-10-03 at 17:57, Schlosser, Ryan wrote:

> > > 
> > > 
> > > I block spam for a number of my customers. There's been a
> > > sharp increase in spam coming from large ISPs such as
> > > comcast.com and rr.com. One customer now wants to block all
> > > e-mail from any Comcast or Road Runner e-mail address or
> > > IP address.
> > 
> > What's ironic about that to  me - is that rr.com and comcast are both
> > getting very active in blocking 'noisy' mail servers, and in fact have
> > blocked our entire half a million ip network based on the mail from a single
> > open relay.  They actually have a good budget for keeping spam out of their
> > network from coming in, but apparently your feeling that the spam
> > originating from their network is too much to handle anymore, hmmm?
> > interesting to me.
> 
> Spam originating from comcast.com IP addresses has increased at least
> tenfold in the past few weeks.
> 
> Ed

Yeah, I'm getting a lot of it!  

I've found out that the numbers in my postfix maillog and in the postfix
defer and deferred queues match up.  So, I figure if I want a deferred
message out of the system that I can just delete the correct numbered
files from the two queues directly.  Seems like some messages got 
stuck in a bounce to sender loop, the sender address probably bogus.  

How this happened in the first place, I'm not certain since I wouldn't
send email to these addresses where I've always assumed that any
transmit attempt eventually ends with success or failure making
transmission certainly a finite operation.  I worry about being
turned into an open relay.

Is there a utility to give a list of and help me detect what program,
etcetera, is acting as an MUA?  Isn't there anything other than a bounce
that can cause an infinite deferred loop?  You can't source address an
email through two email addresses, can you?  Make the receiver send the
message elsewhere?  Is there an easy way to tell in the maillog if the
message is trying to come in or go out?  I've been working on my maillog
daily so I've been clearing it daily in an attempt to understand what
much of the frankly noise is and clear that noise by limiting what's
logged to a small number of current messages.  I wish I could use
something like webalizer on the logs on my log hub and view those 
on a locked web page.  After that the focus would be to keep the 
html logs backed up and just have the system log storage 
implemented in a queue like fashion where the oldest log 
is the first to be thrown out to clear space for more 
logging, LIFO.

Is there something in the maillog that would say mailx
etc. injected postfix offering perhaps enough info to
verify that that's the mailx etc. I installed and not 
a trojan?

One concern of mine with forging is that bouncing off of  
my email server, someone may have a way to spam others and remain 
undetected.  If a message is legit and it bounces, the bounce is 
helpful as it informs the sender of a problem.  Is there a good
way to program Postfix's bounce procedures getting around the 
possibility of bounce being abused by someone?

Bounce is inappropriate if the address to bounce to is wrong.
If the sender won't take replies, I don't know how Postfix is
configured by default to behave.  For all I know, attempting 
to bounce the spam may in fact trigger further transmission 
of garbage as this reveals that I'm still in existence.  The 
best thing to do is to not reply, don't even bounce spam, 
focus on not granting a connection to the spammer if this 
is at all feasible.

     --  Michael C. Robinson

I don't believe TiVo is going under anytime soon, I think I read that

figure out how to hack XMLTV into it.

I do think that the only advantage to making your own PVR (and really 
making your own of almost anything) is flexibility of features.  It's 
not cost or convenience, that's for sure.  Right now you can't skip 30 
second blocks on the TiVo (you can on the ReplayTV I think), nor (out of 
the box) move the files off the TiVo and onto your computer's hard 
drive, both of these were done to keep the lawyers off their backs. 
Being a hobbyist at home nobody is going to sue you for making a 30 
second ad skip, or having the ability to click and burn an ad-removed 
SVCD of a show (now THAT would be a cool feature).

On Fri, 2003-10-03 at 22:14, Michael C. Robinson wrote:

> That's a great list, but what's the sure fire bullet proof way to
> determine that in fact the domains these black hole servers block 
> are ones that should be?

There is no sure fire bullet proof way.

>   Are these blocks fine grained down to
> individual abusive hosts or are they coarser referring to whole
> subnets?

You'd have to ask the administrators of the lists. Many or most
of them refer to individual hosts. But some list blocks of IP
addresses for an ISP's dial-up addresses, for example.


>   What's the cost in network bandwidth of using these
> or is there an effective way to cache them in your own local
> dns, etc?

A local DNS cache can cache these RBL lookups just like any
other DNS answer. There's nothing special about a RBL lookup
from the point of view of a cache.

Ed





From serendipity at pobox.com  Sat Oct  4 05:57:01 2003
From: serendipity at pobox.com (Brian Quade)
Date: Sat Oct  4 05:57:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] boot partition???
Message-ID: <3F7EBEC8.8070207@pobox.com>

I have Red Hat 7.3 installed on one system and am playing around with 
installing Debian 3.0r1 on another system.  Red Hat always recommends 
that you create a boot partition but I can't find any explanation in any 
documentation about the benefit of booting from a seperate partition. 
 Debian's installation guide discusses various partitioning schemes, but 
I haven't found any mention of a boot partition.  Does anyone know of a 
good reason to boot from a seperate partition, or why this seems to be 
only a Red Hat idea?




From heinlein at madboa.com  Sat Oct  4 07:13:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sat Oct  4 07:13:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] boot partition???
In-Reply-To: <3F7EBEC8.8070207@pobox.com>
References: <3F7EBEC8.8070207@pobox.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0310040706310.1461@pecos.madboa.com>

On Sat, 4 Oct 2003, Brian Quade wrote:

> Does anyone know of a good reason to boot from a seperate partition,
> or why this seems to be only a Red Hat idea?

It's a workaround for older BIOSes that can't boot from high-numbered
cylinders on large hard drives. What Red Hat's installer does is make
sure that /boot is the first partition, guaranteeing that the boot
loader can find the kernel. For an explanation, see the LDP's Large
Disk HOWTO:

  http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/Large-Disk-HOWTO.html

If your hardware/BIOS is reasonably recent, it's not an issue.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

> From: Brian Quade <serendipity at pobox.com>
> Subject: [PLUG] boot partition???

> ...Red Hat always recommends 
> that you create a boot partition but I can't find any explanation in any 
> documentation about the benefit of booting from a seperate partition. 

It's outdated advice.  Older kernels couldn't read a boot partition past
a low (1K?, 4K?) cylinder boundary, so it was recommended to put a boot
partition lower.  Recent kernels (past 2.2 or 2.4.x?) removed the limit.
You still might want to define one though, if you want it as read-only.

Regards,
Robert Munro

Brian,
I believe that this concept is intended to overcome the limitation of
booting from a partition beyond the 1024th cylinder. Following this idea,
you place a small boot partition somewhere before the 1024th cylinder, then
place everything else wherever you want. I'll be expecting some additional
comments . . .

From linux at chrisroberts.org  Sat Oct  4 08:50:02 2003

another good reason for the boot partition is that _most_ systems unmount the 
boot partition right after the machine gets up and running. this way, if your 
filesystem corrupts, your boot partition is sitting off by itself, safe and 
unmounted.

chris

  I'll post the solution to this perplexing problem in the hope that others
benefit from what I learned. The problem is that regex search-and-replace

getting no results.

On Fri, 3 Oct 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:

> That's a great list, but what's the sure fire bullet proof way to
> determine that in fact the domains these black hole servers block are ones
> that should be?  Are these blocks fine grained down to individual abusive
> hosts or are they coarser referring to whole subnets?  What's the cost in
> network bandwidth of using these or is there an effective way to cache
> them in your own local dns, etc?

Michael,

  As a broad, simple answer to your question: I dunno. They work for me.
However, let me see if I can provide some more useful information.

  First, for the foreign RBLs, the only time I see -- or expect -- messages
from those countries is on a mail list to which I subscribe and they come
through just fine. As far as I'm concerned, coarse is better (you should see
the size of my badip list: 1701 IP addresses and address blocks -- and
growing).

  Second, I very frequently see individual accounts blocked for the major
cable operators: rr.com, comcast.net, adelphia.com and so on. I know these
RBLs (including SpamCop's) are fine-grained enough for me because I get
messages from folks on those domains without explicit notation on a white
list.

  Third, I am neither sufficiently smart or clever to know of a bullet-proof
way (sure fire or not) to tell if they're good lists. I'm also unqualified
to know how to determine bandwidth cost or ways of effectively caching
locally. I do run a local dns cache; I've not yet finished setting up the
tinydns server.

  About two years ago I had an interesting experience when e-mail from an
out-of-state trade association (of which I am a member) could not get e-mail
through to me. It was rejeted. I could find absolutely no rule in my UCE
checks that was triggered. I ran traceroute and found no blocked IP address
or domain name. However, when I placed that domain name (and that of their
upstream ISP) in header_checks with an "OK" action, the problem disappeared
and has not recurred. Shrug.

HTH,

Rich

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sat Oct  4 09:26:07 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sat Oct  4 09:26:07 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Why create a boot partition?
In-Reply-To: <20031004134332.27957.54729.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20031004134332.27957.54729.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20031004162418.GA15134@gate.kl-ic.com>

> Date: Sat, 04 Oct 2003 05:36:24 -0700
> From: Brian Quade <serendipity at pobox.com>
> Subject: [PLUG] boot partition???
> 
> I have Red Hat 7.3 installed on one system and am playing around with 
> installing Debian 3.0r1 on another system.  Red Hat always recommends 
> that you create a boot partition but I can't find any explanation in any 
> documentation about the benefit of booting from a seperate partition. 
>  Debian's installation guide discusses various partitioning schemes, but 
> I haven't found any mention of a boot partition.  Does anyone know of a 
> good reason to boot from a seperate partition, or why this seems to be 
> only a Red Hat idea?

A separate boot partition can be small, which means it will boot with
old BIOSes.  One of the really cool things about Linux is that it
bypasses the BIOS for normal operation, so you can put a 120GB disk on
an ancient machine that only supports 1GB directly with the BIOS.  
This is true for GRUB at least, I assume LILO is as smart.

If you have a modern BIOS, or use a small disk, this is not an issue.
But I imagine RedHat got enough support calls that were "fixed" by 
using the separate partition that they made this a general recommendation.

I follow this recommendation when I put Linux and Win4Lin on old
Thinkpad 560 laptops; those only support 8GB disks natively, but will
happily talk to a 40GB or larger with Linux.  With Win98 running on top
of Win4Lin, you get a Windoze machine with more space, running faster
(ext2 is better than fat32), rapidly "rebootable", and back-uppable.

Keith

Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993

Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From miken at hotsushi.com  Sat Oct  4 10:08:02 2003
From: miken at hotsushi.com (Mike Neal)
Date: Sat Oct  4 10:08:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Why create a boot partition?
In-Reply-To: <20031004162418.GA15134@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20031004134332.27957.54729.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
 <20031004134332.27957.54729.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <B0072889202@mail.oregoncoast.com>

>A separate boot partition can be small, which means it will boot with
>old BIOSes.  One of the really cool things about Linux is that it
>bypasses the BIOS for normal operation, so you can put a 120GB disk on
>an ancient machine that only supports 1GB directly with the BIOS.  
>This is true for GRUB at least, I assume LILO is as smart.

I think...

The BIOS has a 10 bit address space for the fixed disk cylinder number
which means it can only deal with cylinders below 1024.  The BIOS is used
at boot time to read the the MBR.  With a stock MBR, the active partition
and kernel need to be located below cylinder 1024 (todays drives have tens
of thousands of cylinders). 

If GRUB is installed to the MBR, this is not a problem.  Other
configurations require a boot partition below cylinder 1024.

Cheers,
Mike

On Sat, 4 Oct 2003, Jon Jacob jon-at-manymoons.net |PDX Linux| wrote:

I would get the "lifetime" service since this tends to actually increase
in value.  Should you ever want to upgrade your TiVo, the lifetime service
massively boosts your original unit's resale value.

I.e. I paid $250 for the lifetime service on my Series 1, but on Ebay
units with lifetime service sell for $300 more than units without it.

Of course all this assumes that you sell the TiVo instead of just using it
until it breaks.  I suspect I'll run mine until it can run no more, and
probably have a very, very sad day when it goes.

On Sat, 2003-10-04 at 10:25, Russ Johnson wrote:

> I've been playing with Gentoo a little lately, and they also talk about a /boot partition. The docs I am reading say it's not mounted when your system boots. Sounds like it might be a security measure, but I'm not sure of the ramifications. I haven't thought it through, so to speak...

All the reasons listed so far have been good ones-

Security - it ain't so easy to get in and see what's in /boot, letalone
write to it.
Safety - if you main filesystem is hosed, you might be able to still
boot, a little.  Of course, if your main filesystem is hosed, you have
bigger problems than losing your kernel.  ;-)

I keep my /boot partition seperate and unmounted because that makes it
more difficult to accidentally do damage when I'm playing kernel games.

Rob

On Sat, 4 Oct 2003, AthlonRob wrote:

> I keep my /boot partition seperate and unmounted because that makes
> it more difficult to accidentally do damage when I'm playing kernel
> games.

I can't speak for Debian packages, but none of the kernel rpms I've
ever seen make any effort to mount /boot before copying new images and
updating grub.conf.

On any given system, that's not such a big deal. You just mount /boot
before installing the package. On a larger network, however, it'd be
just that much more work -- mount /boot, do the upgrade, umount /boot.

I think I'd rather stick with a bootable CD recovery disk. :-)

From ehem at m5p.com  Sat Oct  4 15:27:02 2003
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Sat Oct  4 15:27:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Why create a boot partition?
Message-ID: <200310042226.h94MQ3ws045322@m5p.com>

There is a bigger reason that hasn't been mentioned. LILO had a (very)
little bit of understanding of ext2. For a long while if you wanted to
use other filesystems for your root filesystem you needed a /boot which
was ext2 or minix to load the kernel. ReiserFS has fixed their
interactions now, but I don't know about other filesystems.

As to security and safety in case of crashes. Mounting your entire root
and /usr filesystems read-only is far more effective than merely having
/boot unmounted (though why not read-only, gives you similar advantages).
In case of a crash at a bad moment, you're going to need the tools that
are located on the root filesystem (notably fsck). If a cracker comes
they're probably going to be more interested in sticking trojans and
backdoors in /bin than in corrupting your kernel in /boot.
