From heinlein at madboa.com  Sun Oct  5 07:22:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sun Oct  5 07:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Red Hat 8.0 weirdness.....
In-Reply-To: <3F801367.7060508@pobox.com>
References: <3F801367.7060508@pobox.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0310050716440.1461@pecos.madboa.com>

On Sun, 5 Oct 2003, Brian Quade wrote:

>  Does anyone know anything about RH8?  Should I download RH9 and try
> that instead?  I'm glad I didn't upgrade my development system.

With its 8.0 and 9 releases, Red Hat started making a serious push
toward internationalization, trying to use unicode wherever it could.
Once casualty is xterms, which sometimes behave oddly -- though I've
never seen the symptoms you described.

I like 9 better than 8.0, mostly because the font support is superior
in 9. The main 'gotcha' is that the rpm binary doesn't work well with
non-Red Hat kernels. You've either got to a)  recompile rpm without
posix mutexes or b) use LD_ASSUME_KERNEL=2.2.5 in your shell
environment when you run rpm.

Other than that, Red Hat 9 has been stable for me.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From edasher at javelin.net  Sun Oct  5 10:22:02 2003
From: edasher at javelin.net (Erik)
Date: Sun Oct  5 10:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Red Hat 8.0 weirdness.....
Message-ID: <000001c38b65$268712d0$6401a8c0@lemonhead>

Brian,

You ethernet card is maintaining link to the router even when your
machine is off because of some power management settings.  You should be
able to set your machine's BIOS and/or the network card driver to one of
the following behaiviors:
1.	No Power Mangement / Don't maintain link on power off.
2.	Power Management / wake from power off on link change
3.	Power Management / wake from power off on any traffic directed
to NIC's mac address.

Some NIC / BIOS combinations allow for more options.  Some for slightly
less.  I've listed the most common.

The BIOS setting are fairly easy to find.  The NIC settings are entirely
different.  If you are using an Intel based NIC, you can use PROBOOT.EXE
to modify the NIC's settings, but I think you'd have to boot to DOS to
do it.  I'm unsure if intel drivers allow to modify these setting from
within Linux.

Hope that helps,
EcD.





From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Sun Oct  5 11:56:02 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Sun Oct  5 11:56:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Why create a boot partition?
In-Reply-To: <200310042226.h94MQ3ws045322@m5p.com>
References: <200310042226.h94MQ3ws045322@m5p.com>
Message-ID: <1065380021.27996.22.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

Isn't a drive something that can be looked at as a series of writable
locations from 0 to some high number where some of these locations 
need to have partition start and partition end written to them?  Why 
won't Microsoft and everyone else agree that partitioning should be
defined outside any operating system where a recognized hardware API
could then be made to work for everyone wanting to access that drive?  
I would think this would solve a lot of problems with the OS not 
looking at the drive geometry correctly. 
 
What does partition alignment really mean?  Is it like memory 
alignment where you use packing of nibbles to create bytes 
because the architecture has a certain word size or something?  
If these counters were part of the drive controller would we 
ever have had the 10 bit counter limit or 1024 cylinders?
I guess this as a red herring though like the making
everyone implement PTR records in their dns.

It's a shame you can't treat an eighty gig drive as two seperate
drives accessed as drive one and drive two.  This would allow
partitioning in one way on one half and a different way on the
other half addressing the issue of Windoze or dos wants the
drive to be set up differently quite nicely.

An annoyance regarding PC's is that there are assumptions built
into them about drives and such that just seem to needlessly 
lead to trouble.

     --  Michael



From serendipity at pobox.com  Sun Oct  5 12:30:02 2003
From: serendipity at pobox.com (Brian Quade)
Date: Sun Oct  5 12:30:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Why create a boot partition?
References: <200310042226.h94MQ3ws045322@m5p.com> <1065380021.27996.22.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <3F8070FC.6000800@pobox.com>

Michael, if all the different companies could agree on one standard for 
everything, it would all be so much more simple.  But then again, there 
would be less incentive for people to try to come up with alternate 
solutions to old problems.  There is a lot of information about 
partitioning and how it all works, and the different kinds of partitions 
on the Internet (too much for me to list here).  Most operating systems 
are designed to use their own proprietary partitions, but many of them 
recognize others as well.  As far as I know, most distributions of Linux 
recognize up to 100 different types of partitions.

You can have two different partitions types on one drive.  I have a 
dual-boot system (I am using it right now) that has Linux with a big 
ext3 partition and the other boot option is Windows XP Pro (with NTFS) 
that I use for testing Java code on Windows and a few other things for 
which there is not comparable software available for Linux yet.  So I 
created a special partition of type vfat that I use to store files that 
I need to read from both operating systems because they both recognize 
vfat.  That way, no matter which boot option I choose, I have access to 
those files.  I think having a lot of different types of partitions is 
very beneficial.

From ed at alcpress.com  Sun Oct  5 13:44:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Sun Oct  5 13:44:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Why create a boot partition?
In-Reply-To: <3F8070FC.6000800@pobox.com>

	 <1065380021.27996.22.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

On Sun, 2003-10-05 at 12:29, Brian Quade wrote:
> As far as I know, most distributions of Linux 
> recognize up to 100 different types of partitions.

You may be confusing partition types and file systems
depending on what you mean by "recognize". Linux can
mount numerous file systems but nothing close to 100.
Perhaps you're thinking of the long list of partition
types you see when you use the fdisk program. You can
create a partition using fdisk and set it's type to
any of the 200 or so possible values but that does not
mean that Linux will be able to use the file system
normally associated with that partition type.

Ed




From ed at alcpress.com  Sun Oct  5 13:59:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Sun Oct  5 13:59:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Why create a boot partition?
In-Reply-To: <1065380021.27996.22.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <200310042226.h94MQ3ws045322@m5p.com>
	 <1065380021.27996.22.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1065388230.9729.100.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Sun, 2003-10-05 at 11:53, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> Isn't a drive something that can be looked at as a series of writable
> locations from 0 to some high number where some of these locations 
> need to have partition start and partition end written to them?

That's roughly the way it works now.

> Why 
> won't Microsoft and everyone else agree that partitioning should be
> defined outside any operating system 

It already is. It's not the operating systems that impose the
1024 cylinder limit that's been discussed in this thread.


> where a recognized hardware API
> could then be made to work for everyone wanting to access that drive?  
> I would think this would solve a lot of problems with the OS not 
> looking at the drive geometry correctly. 

Didn't we cover this in one of the Linux classes that you
attended?  :-)

PC partition tables specify the start and end of partitions
in two ways:

1. the legacy heads/sectors/tracks method that is geometry
   specific.

2. using sector numbering that is independent of drive geometry.

 
> What does partition alignment really mean?  Is it like memory 
> alignment where you use packing of nibbles to create bytes 
> because the architecture has a certain word size or something?  
> If these counters were part of the drive controller would we 
> ever have had the 10 bit counter limit or 1024 cylinders?
> I guess this as a red herring though like the making
> everyone implement PTR records in their dns.

Two completely different things. When IBM designed the PC BIOS
they thought that the product would have a short lifetime. They
had no idea that it would be with us decades later. They
designed the BIOS for hard disks of the day, where a 10-bit
cylinder count was reasonable.

When technology moved past that, we should have replaced PC
architecture with something better. We didn't. Whose fault
is that?


> It's a shame you can't treat an eighty gig drive as two seperate
> drives accessed as drive one and drive two.  This would allow
> partitioning in one way on one half and a different way on the
> other half addressing the issue of Windoze or dos wants the
> drive to be set up differently quite nicely.

Why two? Why not 4, 8, 16, 32, etc?

You can treat it as separate drives. That's what partitions do.


> An annoyance regarding PC's is that there are assumptions built
> into them about drives and such that just seem to needlessly 
> lead to trouble.
> 
>      --  Michael





From ian at znark.com  Sun Oct  5 14:14:01 2003
From: ian at znark.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Sun Oct  5 14:14:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Why create a boot partition?
In-Reply-To: <1065380021.27996.22.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <200310042226.h94MQ3ws045322@m5p.com> <1065380021.27996.22.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <3F80894C.7010607@znark.com>

Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> Isn't a drive something that can be looked at as a series of writable
> locations from 0 to some high number where some of these locations 
> need to have partition start and partition end written to them?  Why 
> won't Microsoft and everyone else agree that partitioning should be
> defined outside any operating system where a recognized hardware API
> could then be made to work for everyone wanting to access that drive?  
> I would think this would solve a lot of problems with the OS not 
> looking at the drive geometry correctly. 
>  

There is a standard on PCs for partitioning drives.  It has some 
restrictions, like 4 primary partitions, and cylinder alignment, but is 
used by most PC operating systems.  Other platforms and some OSes like 
the BSDs have other schemes.

There are also two BIOS hardware APIs to access the hard drive.  One is 
the old CHS method that uses the drive geometry.  This is the one with 
the 1024 cylinder limit and 8 GB drive size.  DOS and Windows 95/98 are 
limited by this because they are old.  The other is the LBA method that 
Linux and Windows 2000 uses.  The BIOS does not care one bit about 
partitioning.

> What does partition alignment really mean?  Is it like memory 
> alignment where you use packing of nibbles to create bytes 
> because the architecture has a certain word size or something?  
> If these counters were part of the drive controller would we 
> ever have had the 10 bit counter limit or 1024 cylinders?
> I guess this as a red herring though like the making
> everyone implement PTR records in their dns.
> 

Partition alignment means that the partitions are aligned to cylinder 
boundaries.  The old disk access mode used the disk geometry of 
cylinder, head, and sector (CHS) to address sectors.  For the most part, 
the partitions needed to start on cylinder boundaries.  The CHS access 
mode went all the way to the drive controller.

All modern hard drives and BIOS support the linear block access (LBA) 
mode which treats the drive as a linear sequence of sectors.  The drive 
hides its real geometry.  The partition table also stores the begin, 
end, and size in sectors.  It is usually a good idea to keep the 
partitions aligned with cylinders so older programs (like Windows) don't 
get confused.

  - Ian

-- 
ian at znark.com
http://www.znark.com/

your systems at once.  One change I'd like to see is allowing
the primary partitions to each have their own extended chain so that
it's easier under Ranish and other tools to tell what goes to what.

with a certain percentage of the real drive's total disk space.

and hdd perhaps.  Now performance would be fine if each simulated
drive represented a different OS where you boot one at a time.
However, performance would not be good if you need to use
hda and any of hdb, hdc, and hdd at the same time because these
are just on one drive with one data connection that is
shared.

I mean that literally where you would indicate in a bios program what
part of the drive is drive 0 and what part is drive 1 you fool
Linux fdisk and other tools purposely that one drive is two 
physical drives: hda and hdb say.  The only way to get that is to buy
two hard drives where half of one will easily host an OS for me.

In Von Neumann arhitecture, instructions and data flow in together
and there's a bottleneck as far as I/O, if I remember right.
If the CHS bios had simply been upgraded to work in say 20 bits
or another multiple of 10 bits I would think a CHS scheme could
be extended to today's drives while being downward compatible
without the patches we've accumulated from translation schemes.  
A software solution means running a program on the cpu.  Isn't 
IO slow enough on PC's?  The processors are at 2 plus gigaherz, 
but the drives can't catch up.

In the rare occasion I have worked with a sub 500 meg drive, it is
so nice to not have to worry about bios issues.  Sometimes I think
hard drive technology on the PC is so preposterous that had I the
factory and the engineering nohow I'd consider building a new type
of controller and drive and release the source code to 
drivers that would make the combo work under Linux.  Microsoft 
probably wouldn't port it to Windows, but oh well.  Imagine 1 
terabyte addressing in hardware hard drives that are Linux 
compatible and between scsi and ata or at the cost of ata drives.  
To make these drives boot fast one could replace the first 100 
megs or so with nonvolatile high speed ram.

It would be nice if you pay about the same as you do for an 80 gig
drive for four twenty gig models new but that's not available as
far I know.  I'd rather have four smaller drives than one big one.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sun Oct  5 16:53:02 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sun Oct  5 16:53:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Drive economics ( was: Why create a boot partition?)
In-Reply-To: <20031005220202.11007.14966.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20031005220202.11007.14966.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20031005235216.GA7716@gate.kl-ic.com>

> Subject: Re: [PLUG] Why create a boot partition?
> From: "Michael C. Robinson" <michael at goose.robinson-west.com>
...
> In the rare occasion I have worked with a sub 500 meg drive, it is
> so nice to not have to worry about bios issues.  Sometimes I think
> hard drive technology on the PC is so preposterous that had I the
> factory and the engineering nohow I'd consider building a new type
> of controller and drive and release the source code to 
> drivers that would make the combo work under Linux.  Microsoft 
> probably wouldn't port it to Windows, but oh well.  Imagine 1 
> terabyte addressing in hardware hard drives that are Linux 
> compatible and between scsi and ata or at the cost of ata drives.  
> To make these drives boot fast one could replace the first 100 
> megs or so with nonvolatile high speed ram.
> 
> It would be nice if you pay about the same as you do for an 80 gig
> drive for four twenty gig models new but that's not available as
> far I know.  I'd rather have four smaller drives than one big one.
> 
>      --  Michael

While it is not clear to me what you are asking for, the LBA28 to
LBA48 transition seems to match your description.  LBA28 was restricted
to 2^28 sectors, 512 bytes each, or approx 137GB.  LBA48 will address
2^20th more sectors, or 144PB (P=Peta=1,000,000Giga).  I figure that
will last for the next decade or so, when it is replaced by some
other scheme.  

CHS died a deserved death, because modern drive platters store more
bytes on outer tracks than inner ones.  A sector based address is far
more universal than one that assumes a fixed physical architecture.
LBA48 will die when drives get smarter about managing their own data.

As far as why the cost of 80GB and 4x20GB are not the same, I suppose
it is the same principle that makes a 480 pound girlfriend different
from four 120 pound girlfriends.  Four small girlfriends are more fun,
but a lot harder to acquire (YMMV).   4 drives cost more than 1 because
it takes more effort to make them and sell them, given current technology.
Given October 2003 technology, you can get a 250GB drive for about the
same price ($208, pricewatch) as four 60GB drives ($52), but that is
because it is still somewhat difficult to build a 250GB, and the market
is still growing for drives that big.  A year from now, about the same
prices will purchase a 500GB drive or four 120GB drives.   The optimum
drive size in Oct 2003, in price per GB, is hovering around $102 for
160GB.

That said, I would be glad to sell you as many 80GB hard drives as
you want for $156, four times the current cost ($39) of a 20GB drive.

A different way to look at drive cost is that a 0GB drive costs $33 ,
and this doesn't change much over time for a given form factor.  Right
now, the cost of additional chunks of 20GB put into the drive go like
$6 for the first 20G, $7 for the next 20G, $8 for the next, etc.  The
curve isn't really straight like that, but it does fit within 10%.  This
time next year, the 0GB drive will still cost $33, and the additional
chunks will be 40GB instead of 20GB, at the same prices as above.

It's kinda scary.  If it keeps going at this rate, in about a decade
I will be able to digitize my waking life to hard disk, in stereo
video, for about 10 cents/day.  But an 80TB drive for $61 will still
cost less than four 20TB drives at $39 each.

Keith

From ed at alcpress.com  Sun Oct  5 20:56:01 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Sun Oct  5 20:56:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Why create a boot partition?
In-Reply-To: <1065391137.28299.135.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <200310042226.h94MQ3ws045322@m5p.com>
	 <1065380021.27996.22.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
	 <1065388230.9729.100.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	 <1065391137.28299.135.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1065413252.9729.125.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Sun, 2003-10-05 at 14:58, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> > Why two? Why not 4, 8, 16, 32, etc?
> > 
> > You can treat it as separate drives. That's what partitions do.
> 
> I'm suggesting equivalent to plugging one of two 40's in as opposed to
> one 80 gig drive under fdisk.  If you unplug one and it has something 
> on it you protect that something.  Yes you can partition the 80 but 
> you see all the partitions and as far as I know you can't delete the
> first partition and redo it without dumping everything.

The last sentence is ambiguous. I don't know what "dumping everything"
means. I think you may be saying that if you delete the first
partition, you'll lose data in the other partitions. This is not
normally the case. Disk partitioning programs, like fdisk, don't
allow you to redefine new partitions that overlap other partitions.

Note also that repartitioning a hard disk does not alter the
data on the partitions. You'd have to write to the disk with other
programs to modify the contents of the partitions.


> It can be hard
> to tell which partitions you want seeing all of them from all of
> your systems at once.

I guess you want a comments field in the partition table.


> One change I'd like to see is allowing
> the primary partitions to each have their own extended chain so that
> it's easier under Ranish and other tools to tell what goes to what.

There's nothing stopping us from doing this now as far as the
partition table is concerned. All we need is cooperation from
the computer's BIOS and boot loader programs.

But this is solving the wrong problem. Extended partitions are
a band-aid to the limitation of four primary partitions. The
better solution is to extend the number of primary partitions.

Subject: [PLUG] cdrw won't mount or write, wrong /dev link, don't know how to change
 it
Message-ID: <3F80F59E.30700@pobox.com>

I am running RH7.3 and I am pretty sure that my cdrw drive is set up 
incorrectly.  I changed my grub.conf for scsi emulation which seems to 
work fine because cdrecord "looks" like it is writing to the cd.  But no 
data goes on to it.  I read somewhere that if you can mount your cdrw, 
then it should be set up correctly to write to it (I did not try to 
mount it before writing though).  But after testing that, I can not 
mount it and I think that is the problem.  fstab lists it as hdd, but my 
RedHat Hardware Browser lists it as hdc.  There is a link called 
/dev/cdrom1 that points to /dev/hdd, but as far as I can see my system 
does not have a /dev/hdd.  Anyway, I used ln to create a link called 
/dev/cdrw to point to /mnt/cdrw and I created /mnt/cdrw and deleted 
/mnt/cdrom1, which was there before.  I also edited fstab to reflect 
those changes, which I discovered since then is not the way to do it. 
 Then I restarted the system, and it restored everything to the way it 
was.  I used grep to try to find any files that contain 'hdd' or 
'cdrom1' but could not find any.  So I am at a loss as to how to let the 
system know that my cdrw is on /dev/hdc (which the Hardware Browser and 
some of my software packages already know), and change the link that 
points to it to 'cdrw' rather than 'cdrom1'.  I read a little bit about 
fsck and mkfs, but I am not really sure those are what I need to use 
either and I don't want to screw up anything really important in my file 
system.  Any advice?

> Mr CLISP tells me, when asked:
>

> "one hundred and forty-four quadrillion, one hundred and fifteen
> trillion, one hundred and eighty-eight billion, seventy-five million,
> eight hundred and fifty-five thousand, eight hundred and seventy-two" 

Mr CLISP wasn't paying attention in math class.

There shouldn't be any ands in there unless you're dealing with
decimals/fractions.

One hundred forty-four quadrillion, one hundred fifteen trillion, one
hundred eight-eight billion, seventy-five million, eight hundred fifty
thousand, eight hundred seventy-two.

Then if you have decimals, you'd add "and fifteen hundredths" to the end
of it.  :-)

On Sun, 05 Oct 2003 22:04:28 -0700
Brian Quade <serendipity at pobox.com> wrote:

> Oops, I meant to say that I created a link from /dev/cdrw that points to 
> /dev/hdc like it should, not /dev/hdd which has not device on it.

When this has happened to me, it turned out that I had the drive set up as slave. It was the only drive on the chain, but because it was jumpered as slave, the system and linux both said it was the fourth drive. I had no second or third drive in the system. 

Another thing to keep in mind. Burning will happen on /dev/sgX, where X is the device on the "scsi" bus. 

Are you burning in "test" mode?

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sun Oct  5 23:45:02 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sun Oct  5 23:45:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] cdrw won't mount or write ...
Message-ID: <20031006064341.GC11272@gate.kl-ic.com>

> Brian Quade suffers sundry ide-scsi cdrw indignities.

I have things working.  It is hard to tell what is unconfigured on
Brian's machine, so I will tell how things are set up on mine.  There
are things about my setup I don't understand (hdd in some places, hdc
in others), and no doubt things that need fixing, but it works.

----------------------------------------------
On my machine, the cdr is on /dev/hdc.  In grub.conf, a typical section is:

   ...
   title Red Hat Linux (2.4.20-19.9)
           root (hd0,0)
           kernel /boot/vmlinuz-2.4.20-19.9 ro root=/dev/hda1
           initrd /boot/initrd-2.4.20-19.9.img
           append="hdd=ide-scsi"
   ...

-----------------------------------------------
In /dev, I have a symbolic link:

lrwxrwxrwx    1 root     root            9 Aug  2 23:02 cdrom -> /dev/scd0

-----------------------------------------------
/etc/fstab contains the line:

  /dev/cdr       /mnt/cdrom              iso9660 noauto,owner,kudzu,ro 0 0

-----------------------------------------------
/etc/modules.conf contains:

   alias scd0 srmod
   alias scsi_hostadapter ide-scsi
   options ide-cd ignore=hdc dma=1

-----------------------------------------------
My redhat 9ish /etc/rc.d/rc.sysinit contains, out of the box:

   ...
   # If they asked for ide-scsi, load it
   if LC_ALL=C grep -q "ide-scsi" /proc/cmdline ; then
        modprobe ide-cd >/dev/null 2>&1
        modprobe ide-scsi >/dev/null 2>&1
   fi

-----------------------------------------------
On earlier versions of redhat, I had this in /etc/rc.d/rc.local:

   /sbin/insmod ide-scsi

(it is now commented out)
-----------------------------------------------
When I do an lsmod, I see:

   ide-scsi      12176   0
   scsi_mod     107512   7  [sg sr_mod usb-storage ide-scsi aic7xxx sd_mod]

-----------------------------------------------
When I do a "cdrecord -scsibus", I see:

   Cdrecord 2.0 (i686-pc-linux-gnu) Copyright (C) 1995-2002 J?rg Schilling
...
   scsibus0:
        0,0,0     0) *
        0,1,0     1) *
        0,2,0     2) 'EXABYTE ' 'EXB-10i         ' '3.1 ' Removable Juke Box
        0,3,0     3) *
...     
        0,7,0     7) *
scsibus1:
        1,0,0   100) 'TOSHIBA ' 'DVD-ROM SD-R1202' '1026' Removable CD-ROM
        1,1,0   101) *
...     
scsibus2:
        2,0,0   200) 'Inclose ' 'MobileDockUSB2.0' '1.01' Removable Disk
        2,1,0   201) *
...     
scsibus3:
        2,0,0   200) 'Inclose ' 'MobileDockUSB2.0' '1.01' Removable Disk
        2,1,0   201) *
...     

( ... = deleted.   I also have an Exabyte SCSI Jukebox and two removable
                   USB2 connected drive docs ).

The setup on my laptop is very similar (except I don't have the extra
peripherals, and "cdrecord -scanbus" doesn't show them).

Now, I can't say for sure what is causing problems for you, Brian, but 
perhaps a clue resides in the above observations.  Good luck!

----
BTW, for the rest of you, when I load a blank CDR media into my drive,
I get an empty automount window popping up with ///burn or something. 
Annoying.  Any way to kill that, without killing a normal automount?

Keith

From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Mon Oct  6 00:26:02 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Mon Oct  6 00:26:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Why non aligned cylinder boundary fdisk or d druid errors...
In-Reply-To: <3F80894C.7010607@znark.com>
References: <200310042226.h94MQ3ws045322@m5p.com>
	<1065380021.27996.22.camel@goose.robinson-west.com> 
	<3F80894C.7010607@znark.com>
Message-ID: <1065425007.28299.243.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

Why then if CHS is deprecated because hard drive data 
density is greater on the outside tracks than inner 
ones do fdisk and disk druid check for CHS alignment?  
If CHS is based on equal density across a platter 
which is long gone than I would think that 
partitioning software shouldn't check CHS anymore.  
I've had anaconda crash because of nonaligned 
partitioning schemes, but why?  I wondering if 
Ranish is deprecated by not showing everything 
in terms of sectors first to last instead of in 
terms of CHS.  The only other possibility is that 
I had partition hiding active but I wonder if 
that is something standard where Linux should 
be able to get around it.

As far as the jokes about Word, what part of I don't
have a choice here don't a number of people understand?  
The lab uses a certain program that outputs a Microsoft 
data file which as far as I know can only be opened by 
Word.  If your so smart, be my guest and replace the 
Windows science workshop made by Pasco porting all the 
probes etc.  While your at it, maintain the same feel 
so that the port doesn't introduce a learning curve. 
I have no need for smart aleck comments as they neither 
amuse me nor change the situation one bit.  I do think 
it's silly to do scientific work in Windows, especially
98 considering how frequently it crashes, but then 
it's not my call.

Back to the CHS, clearly you don't want one partition
to contain the sectors in another, but this whole be on 
a cylinder boundary concept makes no sense at all.  Why
would a software program ever be concerned about 
cylinder alignment?  Are there gaps between writable
spaces on a hard disk leading to the whole cylinders 
concept?  From what I've looked at it appears that a 
hard disk maps where writable media is by it's own 
internal standard.

It seems like a hard disk if it is set up in a CHS
will register as a CHS drive but how is this happening?
Is this OS dependent or is there something at the start
of the drive that records it is in CHS format?  And this
16383,16,63 patch, how exactly does that work?  Is xosl
not large drive or linear addressing compatible?  Why
does it try to create a zero length partition between
each partition or have I run into a problem with how
disk druid is reading the partition table?  Why with 
large drives sometimes is it impossible to get the 
last meg or so of the drive into a partition? Why
under disk druid do you often times not get the 
exact size partition you request?  What is the
the difference between fdisk and cfdisk?  If cfdisk
reads large disks correctly, why do the Redhat

On Mon, 2003-10-06 at 00:35, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> What is difference to the computer bios of a primary partition verses an
> extended partition verses a logical volume?  

This is a question that's best answered by the BIOS makers
and computer makers. I've often wondered why BIOS are so
restrictive. Most BIOS will only boot an operating system
from a primary partition but there's no difficult challenge
in booting from a logical drive in an extended partition. To
boot from a logical drive, the BIOS just needs to follow the
chain until it discovers where the logical drive starts. This
is no big deal considering that any disk partitioning program
can do it. 


> Does the bios just assume
> to start reading at sector zero or is there more reason than that why
> certain systems have to be installed at the beginning of the drive?

The BIOS assumes that sector zero contains the boot loader and
partition table. This has nothing to do with the 1024-cylinder
limit. The limitation is caused by the partition table's cylinder
value being limited to 10 bits.

> Why was a limit of four primary partitions imposed?

Because:

1. At the time IBM created the BIOS, Winchester hard disk
drives were weighing in at 5, 10, and 12 megabytes of total
capacity. How many pieces would you want to chop a 10 MB
drive in to? IBM decided that four was enough. I probably
would have made the same decision because I never would have
thought that the design would still be in use over 20 years
later.

2. IBM put both the boot loader and the partition table into
the same 512-byte sector. There wasn't enough space for more
primary partitions. If it was me, I would have used one sector
for the boot loader and another for the partition table. That
would have allowed 16 (primary) partitions. There would have
been no need for the insanity of extended partitions.

Remember that hard disk technology in 1981 was very different
than today's technology. Back then, disk space was expensive.
Using 1 sector rather than 2 was not considered an irrational
design consideration.

You're asking questions about why computers manufactured today
have the same limitations as computers designed in 1981. In
addition to partition table limitations we also have a
limit on the number of video cards that can be supported.

It's because today's computers are the same basic design as
the 1981 computers. The PC design should have been retired
years ago. Instead, it's kept alive by, well, inertia I guess.

Imagine if today's space probes used the same basic design as,
say, Voyager. Now imagine the PC.

Ed

On Mon, 2003-10-06 at 01:00, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> If you can't tell what partitions are what, you basically have to
> start over.  That's what I meant by dumped.

That's a bit dramatic. You'd start over rather than mounting
the partition to see what was in it? Chances are that if you
looked at a partition's contents your memory would do the
rest. 

You can always run the fdisk program to see the partition
types. It's easy to see the difference between FAT16, FAT32,
NTFS, ext(2/3), Linux swap, LVM, etc. 

As I mentioned earlier, a comments field in the partition
table would do the job but we don't have that.

Perhaps anytime you create a partition and place a file
system on it, you create a text file in the root called
.whatami that describes the partition's purpose.

>   If xosl was installed but
> the partition it was installed to is gone, that can be hairy too.

It's bad news if _anything_ is installed in a partition that is gone.

physical hard drive make the system run slower or faster, or make no 
significant difference at all?

/boot?  What about /var?

Any input is welcome.

From drl at drloree.com  Mon Oct  6 09:57:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Mon Oct  6 09:57:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] swap space on separate physical drive?
In-Reply-To: <3F819952.3090503@pobox.com>
References: <3F819952.3090503@pobox.com>
Message-ID: <1065460205.27454.46.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Mon, 2003-10-06 at 09:33, Brian Quade wrote:
> I am reinstalling Linux on a machine that has a 120G and a little 3G 
> drive.  I was trying to figure out what to do with the 3G drive and I 
> thought I could use it as a really big amount of swap space.  I have 
> heard that the swap space should be twice the amount of memory, and I 
> have 256M of memory.  So my questions are:
> 
> Would 3G of swap space be overkill or a waste of hard drive space for a 
> system with 256K of memory?

Yes, that much swap (if you ever start to use it) would be detrimental
to system performance.  With more than 512 Megs, the system can
potentially spend too much of its time swapping, instead of running.

>   Or might it actually be a great idea since 
> I have the extra space?  Would having my swap space on a separate 
> physical hard drive make the system run slower or faster, or make no 
> significant difference at all?

This depends on the other hardware you have hooked up.  If you have a
somewhat modern motherboard, then the 3G drive will probably not run at
the full speed the controller is capable of running.  If you are going
to have to share an IDE controller with the something else and the 3G
drive, then the drive itself will slow down your system (IDE controllers
run at the speed of the slowest device on the bus; even when accessing
the fast device).  Even on its own controller, it may still slow down
your system, just because it is an old, slow drive.
> 
> What would be the pros and cons of using the separate 3G drive for 
> /boot?  What about /var?

If you are doing a complex boot scheme, you have a pro.  The performance
issue is what really matters.  I think that you will be much happier
without the 3G slug. Save it for a test box, or a fancy router, or a
fancy paper weight.

HTH,

Derek Loree

Message-ID: <20031006171357.GA15568@gate.kl-ic.com>

This is a metaquestion about the plug digest mailing system.

I sent out a response to Brian's cdrw question, and included some
config file fragments.   What came back in digest form was loaded
with "control-escaped" characters, which screws up the examples,
at least if you read mail with an ASCII mail reader.  For example,
double quotes (") and equal sign (=) are getting turned into
equal-22 (=22) and and equal-3D (=3D).  If a newbie tried using
those configs as the mailer munged them, chaos would result.  This
nonsense is going into the html archives, so we are capturing the
screwed-up examples forever.

I can bounce mail off other mail reflectors and I don't see
this;  the problem is specific either to plug's mail server or
the digesting system.  Folks that get un-digested mail may see
the characters un-munged, I can't tell.

Is anybody else seeing this?  Am I plug-incompatable?  Is
this ancient news, and I'm cluelessly restarting an old
argument?  Please respond directly to me at keithl at ieee.org
to save wear and tear on the list.  I will summarize and
post the results.

*** Please include this line:  (=) equals   (") doublequote

Whatever the source, we do post config files, so whatever
software is munging characters should be re-configured or
replaced, IMNSHO.  Hmph!

Keith

From garl.grigsby at plms-eds.com  Mon Oct  6 10:16:01 2003

Message-ID: <159441354A896D4A8886543D5043BC315E56C0@uscimplm001.net.plm.eds.com>

If you were using cdrdao (or a frontend for it) try:

	cdrdao unlock --device 2,0,0

where the '--device 2,0,0' matches your system. You can use 

	cdrdao scanbus 

to find out what device your cd writer is. All commands should be run as root.

Garl

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Mon Oct  6 10:43:02 2003

Date: Mon Oct  6 10:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Setting up network in Slackware-9.0
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310060631570.17288@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310051705130.13855@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	 <1065406553.21030.27.camel@dell.linux.box>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310060631570.17288@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1065462190.4518.3.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Mon, 2003-10-06 at 06:50, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   Just went through the process. But, when netconfig probed for the NIC it
> couldn't find one. Strange. It's a run-of-the-mill NetGear card.

Ok, we're looking at a kernel issue, then.

We need drivers for the network card.

For that, we need to know exactly what kind of card it is...  :-)

Do a 'cat /proc/pci' and see if anything in there sticks out as being
your network card, then we can google for that and hopefully find you a
driver.

>   Then a half-dozen lines probing for a 3c503.c-enabled card. Anyway, it
> tries just about everything and finds no card.

The way most (all?) network card autoprobe scripts work is they just try
and load all the network card modules, one at a time, until one sticks
and says "I can run a network card installed in this machine!" and that
one is kept.

That's why you're seeing a plethora of modules go zooming by in dmesg. 
That's normal, unless the card gets hit by the first module, anyway.

Rob

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Mon Oct  6 12:24:09 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Mon Oct  6 12:24:09 2003
Subject: [PLUG] swap space on separate physical drive?
Message-ID: <20031006192227.GB16010@gate.kl-ic.com>

>  I am reinstalling Linux on a machine that has a 120G and a little 3G
>  drive.

I suggest you get two mobile-dock drive tray systems, put both
drives in trays, and normally use only the 120G.  Copy the critical
portions of the 120G to the 3G, (hence the second slot) and keep the
3G on a shelf somewhere.  3G is plenty for a "recovery" system if
you leave out most of /home and /opt .   Make sure it is bootable.

Now, when something nasty happens, you can try booting off the 3G
with the 120G mounted but not critically active.  You can do some
of the same things with a Knoppix CD, but the 3G drive permits
you to customize and match your existing working system, and copy
files that may have gotten trashed on the 120G.   If something
goofs up your BIOS-CMOS settings, then the 3G may boot when the
120G does not.  It certainly makes rebuilding the 120G from backups
a whole lot easier.

Using the 3G to enhance performance probably isn't wise.   It
consumes more power, and is just another item that can fail or
hang.  While it might help to have /swap on a second spindle, a
big /swap is not advantageous, for reasons others have mentioned.

Keith

Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993

From heinlein at madboa.com  Mon Oct  6 13:42:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon Oct  6 13:42:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] NFS and/or alternatives
In-Reply-To: <1065471827.5307.6.camel@localhost>
References: <86wubkclz5.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <1065471827.5307.6.camel@localhost>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0310061335420.2702@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 6 Oct 2003, Jason Van Cleve wrote:

> Also, NFS development, at least at that time, was very active,
> working out some minor issues; so I'm guessing it's in good shape by
> now.

The NFS mailing list (nfs at lists.sourceforge.net) is quite active, with
patches flying left and right nearly every day. :-) The most
frequently mentioned bugfix issues these days concern a) diskless
clients and b) interoperability with other other operating systems.
The biggest development issue is NFSv4, and that's still in early
alpha stages.

In general, 2.4.2x offers reasonable NFS performance and stability
from both the server and client side. I don't think it's as good as
Solaris, but the margin is mighty narrow.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

get cached so you don't have to repeat them yourself.  What does it say
about Comcast's DNS that a local DNS that has to do each lookup all the
way from the root servers is faster?

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Mon Oct  6 14:43:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Mon Oct  6 14:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] swap space on separate physical drive?
In-Reply-To: <3F819952.3090503@pobox.com>
References: <3F819952.3090503@pobox.com>
Message-ID: <16150-57796@sneakemail.com>

On Mon, 6 Oct 2003, Brian Quade serendipity-at-pobox.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> I am reinstalling Linux on a machine that has a 120G and a little 3G
> drive.  I was trying to figure out what to do with the 3G drive and I
> thought I could use it as a really big amount of swap space.  I have
> heard that the swap space should be twice the amount of memory, and I
> have 256M of memory.  So my questions are:
>
> Would 3G of swap space be overkill or a waste of hard drive space for a
> system with 256K of memory?  Or might it actually be a great idea since
> I have the extra space?  Would having my swap space on a separate
> physical hard drive make the system run slower or faster, or make no
> significant difference at all?
>
> What would be the pros and cons of using the separate 3G drive for
> /boot?  What about /var?
>
> Any input is welcome.

In my experience the 2.4.x kernels manage swap very poorly.  In
particular, they seem overly willing to swap things out just since they
haven't been used in a while-- even if there is plenty of memory
available.

All of my desktop/workstation systems with 256MB or above have zero swap.
Servers will get 1x memory up to 512MB since poor interactive performance
on seldom-user applications is less of an issue on them.  (I.e. on remote
servers having your fourth X desktop pane repaint slowly since it was
swapped out a half hour ago isn't an issue...)

Supposedly, 2.6 will be better on this, but for now commenting out all
swap from /etc/fstab and running "swapoff" has helped my workstation
performance a great deal.

A 3GB /var, or /tmp would be handy-- or you could create a 3GB /home/<you>
on the main drive and software mirror it to limit your losses in the event
the hard drive dies.

  -- Steve

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Mon Oct  6 15:04:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Mon Oct  6 15:04:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DLT tape drives
In-Reply-To: <20031006215035.B5E528F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
References: <20031006215035.B5E528F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <18287-75397@sneakemail.com>

On Mon, 6 Oct 2003, Galen Seitz galens-at-seitzassoc.com |PDX Linux|
wrote:

> I'm looking to replace my DDS2 tape drive with a DLT unit.  I need more
> capacity, and I would like to get the increased reliability that I
> believe the DLT format offers.  Does anyone here have any thoughts
> relative to the merits of the DLT7000, DLT1, and VS80 drives?  This will
> be my first foray into the world of DLT.

I've found DLT to be in general one of the most reliable tape formats I've
used.  In particular, the tapes seem to go bad in storage far less
frequently than 4mm (DDS), 8mm, or AIT have.  (Though for true archival
data, I'd suggest that you use 2 copies onto optical media, even if it's a
couple stacks of CD-Rs.)

About the only trick with DLT is to be sure that you're streaming data to
the drive.  You want whatever is writing to send an uninterrupted stream
of data to the DLT since that keeps the tape off the heads.  If the stream
dries up, the DLT is forced to stop, back up to where it stopped writing,
and start over again.  This kills performance and wears out tapes/heads
much faster than normal.

Also, you'll want to clean the DLTs more regularly than you might be used
to with DDS.  Let your drive vendor be your source for the exact frequency
since they'll be the ones replacing a drive whose heads have been worn
down from overcleaning.  ;-)

If I were choosing a drive right now, I would go with DLT8000.  DLT7000s
are outdated at this point.  I have no experience with SDLT, so I can't
comment directly on them.

  -- Steve

From kyle at silverbeach.net  Mon Oct  6 18:51:02 2003
From: kyle at silverbeach.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Mon Oct  6 18:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] time difference
In-Reply-To: <20031006235403.GA17309@themontagnes.com>
References: <20031006235403.GA17309@themontagnes.com>
Message-ID: <200310061850.49877.kyle@silverbeach.net>

On Monday 06 October 2003 16:54, Michael Montagne wrote:
> I just noticed a cron job I set to run at 1AM ran at 4PM.  So I looked
> in syslog and all the timestamps are 9 hours ahead.  Same as
> /va/log/messages.  Yet the "date" command yields the expected
> results and /etc/localtime is a symlink to
> /usr/share/zoneinfo/America/Los_Angeles.  I'm running Knoppix.
> This could really mess me up but I'm sure the fix is simple.  If I
> could only figure it out.

If it was 7 hours, then I'd say that your system thinks that it is in UTC/GMT, 
but the hour is really set to PDT timezone.

I always set the hardware clock to GMT, but then I don't dual boot anything 
other than other Linux distros.  If you have Windows dual booted, then you'll 
need to set the hardware clock to the local timezone I think.

I find that ntpdate is the perfect tool for getting the clock back in sync 
regardless of how whacked it is.  xntp will fail to sync if the local time is 
too far off of the reference time server.  ntpdate will sync the time back in 
one shot (but does not track it like xntp).

Try something like this (as root):

# export TZDIR=PST8PDT
# ntpdate bigben.cac.washington.edu
# hwclock --systohc

Replace bigben.cac.washington.edu with an appropriate open NTP server.  That 
one works for me, but I try not to hit it more than once a week.  The U of 
Washington provides that service freely and I don't want to abuse their 
generosity.

The first line is possibly necessary if you've got a bizarre timezone set, or 
it is really whacked.  My local configuration (SuSE) doesn't seem to have it 
set at all, so I'm not sure where it will be set, but this should set it 
sufficiently for glibc to figure out the time.

The last line, hwclock, is usually a good idea for PC hardware.  Often the 
hardware clock will continue to drift off into the weeds even though the 
system time is OK.  I have had the misfortune of having servers that drifted 
more than eight hours between reboots.  It screwed up database timestamps 
really well after reboot.  Since then, I always sync the hardware clock with 
the system time.  Note that the above will probably set the hardware clock to 
PST8PDT timezone.  You may need to add --utc to the hwclock command line in 
that case.

I am not a system admin, nor do I play one on TV.  YMMV.  Void where 
prohibited. Tested model price $23,596.

Best,
Kyle

One possibility is that the fsb bus speed is set wrong.  I've seen 
similar behavior to what you describe with Athlon XP's on motherboards 
with jumpers to set the fsb speed, and the jumpers were set to 100 
instead of 133.

From kyle at silverbeach.net  Mon Oct  6 19:30:02 2003
From: kyle at silverbeach.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Mon Oct  6 19:30:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] /proc/cpuinfo
In-Reply-To: <1065493176.5243.44.camel@dell.linux.box>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310061800270.18827@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <200310061852.15520.kyle@silverbeach.net> <1065493176.5243.44.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <200310061929.02023.kyle@silverbeach.net>

On Monday 06 October 2003 19:19, AthlonRob wrote:
> On Mon, 2003-10-06 at 18:52, Kyle Hayes wrote:
> > Uh, that doesn't sound right.  The actual MHz might be measured, but the
> > CPU model number definitely should not be.   It should say "AMD Athlon XP
> > 2100+".
>
> Actually, the kernel knows a lot about the processor it's running on,
> including often the specific model.
>
> cat /proc/cpuinfo to see all the stuff it knows about it...

What I was trying to say is that the OS should be reading one of the special 
registers in the chip for the model number.  That should never be changable 
from any outside source.  It is part of the CPUID stuff.  Thus, if Rich is 
seeing his CPU reported as a slower model, he's got a slower model, not what 
he bought.

The actual MHz that the chip is currently running at might be measured in some 
manner via multipliers/BIOS etc.  That could be a range of valid frequencies.  
I.e. you could have an XP 2100+, but for some reason be clocking it at 
1.3GHz.  Should still work (if the multipliers and FSB speed work out).  But, 
when the model number is different...

Best,
Kyle

Marvin/Dave, et al.:

  I _really_ appreciate all that I learn from you folks! My system is a bit
different, but using the 'del' key (rather than 'esc') I got to the BIOS. I
looked at each category, but there was nothing about the FSB. Toward the
bottom of the right side was an item "Enable High Performance Features"; no
explanation. But I selected it anyway, saw a message that warned me enabling
whatever was going to be enabled might be dangerous and could have
catastrophic results and ... (gulp!) ... I pressed the [Enter] key. Saved
and exited.

  The system rebooted, I logged in a root and ran 'less /proc/cpuinfo'.
Ta-da! The cup is recognized as an Athlon 2100+, the speed is 1.86GHz and
there are about 3600 bogomips.

  Whew!

  This was a great lesson and I'm honored to learn from you.

Thanks,

Rich

From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Mon Oct  6 22:46:02 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Mon Oct  6 22:46:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] booting weirdness
In-Reply-To: <1065491870.1093.4.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <1065491870.1093.4.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <1065505393.1416.55.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

On an Intel D815EEA2, a Pentium III system, there's an option to tell 
it which drive or device to boot from in whatever order you specify.
It may be that when the other drive is plugged it was always set as 
the primary boot device so it boots instead of the other drive that 
really should be booting instead.

Another possibility is second drive controller only one on or maybe
the original boot drive has failed so it is switching to the second.
Is the bios interpreting controller 1 and controller 2 as the same
ones you are?  Check boot device priority and where the bios thinks
drives are plugged in, on some systems these can be set differently.
Maybe they should do like the Alpha on the PC and move the bootloader
into firmware on the motherboard.  The other thing that seems to
cause this sometimes is connecting the cables in wrong.  It may
be a drive issue where some drives don't work correctly when plugged
in in certain positions on your controllers, though I'm not certain 
why.  One would hope at least this part of the ATA nightmere would
get fixed right.

     --  Michael

I'm not totally sure how hardware works with processor architectures,
but the impression I've always had is as long as there are drivers for
the hardware that will compile under the architecture in question,
you're good to go... so, I *think* most SCSI cards should work for it.

On a 386, you pretty much want to avoid any kind of encryption... even
just ssh keys can take upwards of thirty seconds to authenticate with. 
They're great packet routers, though!  :-)

A 386 should be able to do iptables with 2.4.22 without too many
problems... it won't do too much more, but it does iptables nicely.

drive to any other system.  Just plug 'er in.  Although, I could see
maybe if the BIOS is different or something with the Alpha hardware?  I
haven't had the pleasure to play with any non-x86 hardware yet.  I'm
keeping my eyes peeled for some old Sparc hardware or something,
though.  :-)

FWIW, if I were putting Linux on the sucker, I'd go with Gentoo.  I
don't like RedHat or Debian, and Slackware's alpha port slipped back
into non-existence several months ago.. which doesn't leave a lot of
options open.  It sure would be slow compiling on that sucker, though.

> That never installs the kernel.

> >From there, mount /boot, then cp arch/i386/boot/bzImage /boot/vmlinuz
> (or whatever you named your kernel in your grub config - assuming you
> went with the [default?] grub).
> 
> Rob

It's a good idea to set up a second boot option in your
/boot/grub/grub.conf if you use grub or /etc/lilo.conf if
you use lilo for your new kernel in case it doesn't boot
so that you can get back up on your old one.  I wouldn't
overwrite the old kernel until you know the new one at 
least boots.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Mon Oct  6 23:07:02 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Mon Oct  6 23:07:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Disk backups (was: DLT tape drives)
Message-ID: <20031007060527.GA21469@gate.kl-ic.com>

Galen Seitz writes:
> I'm looking to replace my DDS2 tape drive with a DLT unit.  I need more
> capacity, and I would like to get the increased reliability that I believe
> the DLT format offers. ...

I may be sounding like a broken record here, but consider switching to
disk-to-disk backup.  Faster, cheaper, more reliable, more capacity,
less system load, easier swapping.  I can do full level-0 equivalents
on all the machines on my network (80GB worth) in 40 minutes, without
needing to bring anything down to single user.

I am working up a web page for drive-to-drive backups:

http://www.keithl.com/linuxbackup.html

I still need to write up the software I use for backups (dirvish) and
write up doing a bare-metal recovery with rsync.  I do have pointers
to the software, hotswap drive cages, and the like.  This approach will
get even cheaper and easier when Alan Cox finishes writing more IDE
hotswap drivers; for now I use a USB2 connected cage.  But it is 
already much cheaper and faster than tapes and a drive.

I have, on-line, two weeks worth of complete virtual backups, and
more on the swappable drive in the fireproof safe.  This setup is
REALLY COOL. 

I will have some Exabyte drives for sale (cheap) pretty soon now.

Keith

From lamsokvr at xprt.net  Mon Oct  6 23:13:02 2003
From: lamsokvr at xprt.net (Marvin J. Kosmal)
Date: Mon Oct  6 23:13:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] time difference
In-Reply-To: <200310061850.49877.kyle@silverbeach.net>
References: <20031006235403.GA17309@themontagnes.com> 
	<200310061850.49877.kyle@silverbeach.net>
Message-ID: <1065507143.690.84.camel@farm-libranet>

On Mon, 2003-10-06 at 18:50, Kyle Hayes wrote:
> On Monday 06 October 2003 16:54, Michael Montagne wrote:
> > I just noticed a cron job I set to run at 1AM ran at 4PM.  So I looked
> > in syslog and all the timestamps are 9 hours ahead.  Same as
> > /va/log/messages.  Yet the "date" command yields the expected
> > results and /etc/localtime is a symlink to
> > /usr/share/zoneinfo/America/Los_Angeles.  I'm running Knoppix.
> > This could really mess me up but I'm sure the fix is simple.  If I
> > could only figure it out.
> 
> If it was 7 hours, then I'd say that your system thinks that it is in UTC/GMT, 
> but the hour is really set to PDT timezone.
> 
> I always set the hardware clock to GMT, but then I don't dual boot anything 
> other than other Linux distros.  If you have Windows dual booted, then you'll 
> need to set the hardware clock to the local timezone I think.
> 
> I find that ntpdate is the perfect tool for getting the clock back in sync 
> regardless of how whacked it is.  xntp will fail to sync if the local time is 
> too far off of the reference time server.  ntpdate will sync the time back in 
> one shot (but does not track it like xntp).

OR rdate

as root

# rdate time.mit.edu

Good luck

> 
> Try something like this (as root):
> 
> # export TZDIR=PST8PDT
> # ntpdate bigben.cac.washington.edu
> # hwclock --systohc
> 
> Replace bigben.cac.washington.edu with an appropriate open NTP server.  That 
> one works for me, but I try not to hit it more than once a week.  The U of 
> Washington provides that service freely and I don't want to abuse their 
> generosity.
> 
> The first line is possibly necessary if you've got a bizarre timezone set, or 
> it is really whacked.  My local configuration (SuSE) doesn't seem to have it 
> set at all, so I'm not sure where it will be set, but this should set it 
> sufficiently for glibc to figure out the time.
> 
> The last line, hwclock, is usually a good idea for PC hardware.  Often the 
> hardware clock will continue to drift off into the weeds even though the 
> system time is OK.  I have had the misfortune of having servers that drifted 
> more than eight hours between reboots.  It screwed up database timestamps 
> really well after reboot.  Since then, I always sync the hardware clock with 
> the system time.  Note that the above will probably set the hardware clock to 
> PST8PDT timezone.  You may need to add --utc to the hwclock command line in 
> that case.
> 
> I am not a system admin, nor do I play one on TV.  YMMV.  Void where 
> prohibited. Tested model price $23,596.
> 
> Best,
> Kyle

From drl at drloree.com  Mon Oct  6 23:23:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Mon Oct  6 23:23:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] booting weirdness
In-Reply-To: <1065491870.1093.4.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <1065491870.1093.4.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <1065508511.27446.76.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Mon, 2003-10-06 at 18:57, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> I'm trying to salvage some data off an old drive, so I hook it up as
> HDC, secondary master on my IDE system. I check the boot order and it is
> clearly set to HD0, the primary master. I set all boot devices to HD0,
> just to be sure. (Options are 0, 1, 2, 3)
> 
> BIOS finds the extra drive as the secondary master, but for some strange
> reason, my system boots to it. I tried another HDD with Linux on it,
> same. I went into fdisk and removed the boot flag from the extra drive,
> same. 

Boot flag won't matter, its a DOS kind of thing.
> 
> What's going on here?

Double check you jumpers, remember that WD drives have no jumper if they
are standalone, all others need a Master jumper.

What happens if you switch the drives, so that your old drive is in the
HD0 slot, and your good boot drive is in the HD2 slot?

If HD2 boots, and you have selected HD0 as the first boot device, then
I'd say you have a broken BIOS.

Another work around is to put the old drive in a box that boots to
CD-ROM, and use Knoppix (or other CD based OS) to copy data over the
network.

HTH,

Derek Loree

From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Mon Oct  6 23:51:02 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Mon Oct  6 23:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Disk backups (was: DLT tape drives)
In-Reply-To: <20031007060527.GA21469@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20031007060527.GA21469@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <1065509274.1414.96.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

Good job.  I've been thinking about this too.  I figured I could unmount
a second forty gig drive I want to use for backup on one of my machines
and then unlock and remove it from it's tray.  The idea being to take it
out while the system is up, but this causes infinite drive activity. 
The latter can be done for floppy disks, why not hard disk drives?  The
only other approach I can think of is to take a dedicated computer
filling it with drives and substitute disconnecting the ethernet cable
for taking the drives out.  The latter may be better because it involves
avoiding the purchase of trays where I'm afraid I'll drop a hard drive,
something I have done in the past.  Tapes are more likely to work
after being dropped, though a system that does away with loading
altogether is very attractive.  For safety, the backup box filled
with drives can be placed in another room on a different circuit.  
I guess a simple light switch could be wired to a circuit that 
connects and disconnects the backup box from the network where 
putting it on a non externally routed ip subnet would make it 
even safer.  Closets would make good places for this box where 
it would make sense to have two in two different locations.

     --  Michael Robinson



From seniorr at aracnet.com  Tue Oct  7 00:00:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Tue Oct  7 00:00:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Disk backups (was: DLT tape drives)
In-Reply-To: <20031007060527.GA21469@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20031007060527.GA21469@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <86k77hpm80.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Keith" == Keith Lofstrom <keithl at kl-ic.com> writes:

Keith> I may be sounding like a broken record here, but consider
Keith> switching to disk-to-disk backup.  Faster, cheaper, more
Keith> reliable, more capacity, less system load, easier swapping.  I
Keith> can do full level-0 equivalents on all the machines on my
Keith> network (80GB worth) in 40 minutes, without needing to bring
Keith> anything down to single user.

You don't need to bring anything down to single user to do tape
backups either, at least not the way I do them (tar).  Whatever you
lose doing "live" backups to tape, you also lose doing "live" backups
to disk.

There are still some advantages to tape, one being size.  The external
drives I just put together occupy about the same space as 32 4mm tape
cartridges.  At DDS3 densities, an 80gig disk in an enclosure loses by
a factor of nearly 5.  Tapes are easier to carry off-site.  Not sure
about your "less system load" or "easier swapping" claims either.
Color me sceptical.  _Less_ swapping, certainly.  But otherwise, I am
drifting inexorably towards disk backup too, mostly because practical
tape solutions are too expensive.  I am guessing that an IDE drive is
probably able to survive heat (e.g. from a fire) better than a tape
cartridge also.

BTW, Dirvish is using the same strategy that I invented independently
(and that probably existed long before I thought of it) two years ago:
basically, exploiting hardlinks to save disk space on unchanged
portions of snapshots.  Even before rsync got the explicit support for
doing this, you could fake it by first doing a tree copy using
hardlinks:

  cp -al <src> <dest>

where <src> was the last snapshot, and then rsyncing a new backup to
<dest>.  Since rsync 2.5.6, you can just use the --link-dest option to
do effectively the same thing in one shot.

The tricky thing about these is keeping people from changing anything
in the mounted snapshots.  Because they are hardlinks, a write to the
shared inode changes _all_ the snapshots.  Allowing the file system to
be accessible for reading/recovery and writable for making new
snapshots at the same time is a challenge.

Keith> I will have some Exabyte drives for sale (cheap) pretty soon
Keith> now.

Let me know, I may be interested.

From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Tue Oct  7 07:04:01 2003
From: svanhoosen at yahoo.com (Scott Van Hoosen)
Date: Tue Oct  7 07:04:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] bulk addition of users
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.53.0310062326020.28190@antares.mpcu.com>
Message-ID: <20031007140308.12192.qmail@web40812.mail.yahoo.com>

I'm no shell script expert, but here's a script that will read a text
file with "firstname lastname" and create users by their first name, 
with password of their first name. I'll bet someone can come up with
something better, but this might get you started:

  #!/bin/bash
  cat users | while read first last
  do
    useradd $first
    echo $last | passwd --stdin $first
  done

The text file is called "users" and could be something like this:

  fred flintstone
  barney rubble
  betty rubble

Hope this helps,

-Scott

Peculiarly enough, the Athlon XP will show a CPU identification not its
own when over or under clocked.  The popular overclocking of the Athlon
XP Barton core 2500+ chip to a 200 MHz FSB will result in a BIOS
responding Athlon 3200+ at a nice price savings.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Tue Oct  7 15:20:03 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue Oct  7 15:20:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Kernel problems
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310071445120.20794@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310071445120.20794@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0310071512480.6814@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 7 Oct 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   Reconfiguring the BIOS to "high performance" let the kernel see
> the Athlon 2100+ for what it is (but at 1.77GHz rather than the
> 1.83GHz it's supposed to be), but now I have other problems.
>
>   The network does not come up after booting. There have been two
> kernel panics (a new experience here), and now when I try to invoke,
> 'ifconfig eth0 up' I see:
> kernel BUG at page_alloc.c:100!]
> invalid operand: 0000
> <info on the cpu and registers>
> eth0: unknown interface: No such device.

This doesn't smell like a kernel problem to me -- more like a hardware
issue related to the reconfigured BIOS. My hunches include, in no
particular order,

* overstressing memory
  - marginal RAM
  - RAM that's not rated for the higher bus speed
* overheating the CPU
* overheating something else on the motherboard

The overheating theory can be tested by turning the machine off for
long enough that its components settle to room temperature. Do
something stressful like a kernel build (my hunch is it'll succeed).
Let the machine heat up for an hour or so in regular use. Repeat the
stress test (my hunch is it'll fail).

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

>   Reconfiguring the BIOS to "high performance" let the kernel see the
> Athlon 2100+ for what it is (but at 1.77GHz rather than the 1.83GHz it's

My guess is your BIOS is now over-optimized for your hardware.  I would
return to the old settings and see if you can identify the particular BIOS
setting that allows the Athlon to run at full speed.  The "high
performance" preconfigured set probably made some unintended changes that
are incompatible with your hardware.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Tue Oct  7 16:09:02 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Tue Oct  7 16:09:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Disk backups 
Message-ID: <20031007230802.GA27870@gate.kl-ic.com>

Michael C. Robinson writes:
> ...
> avoiding the purchase of trays where I'm afraid I'll drop a hard drive,
> something I have done in the past.  Tapes are more likely to work
> after being dropped, though a system that does away with loading
> altogether is very attractive.

The trays ($12 @ Fry's) have handles - makes them harder to drop.  
Someday I'll make a padded foam storage box for a bunch of trays.
But the trays don't even have to be moved.  With the USB2 cage
(and probably with the Alan Cox IDE hotswap) you simply turn off the
cage power, and the drive is pretty much inert in place.  I change
the drive out with the drives in the fireproof safe for the very
slight possibility that the backup server gets stolen - and just in
case the current drive fails, so I don't lose as many days of backup.

Michael C. Robinson writes:
> ... For safety, the backup box filled
> with drives can be placed in another room on a different circuit.

Another good idea.  I am moving more activity to laptops, so data from
the laptop and the backup server are almost always in two different
locations.  Right now, the backup server is also the mail server, so
I don't have separation, but I can probably rsync the mail between
mail server and laptop, and keep that data in two places, too.


Russell Senior writes:
> ...
> There are still some advantages to tape, one being size.  The external
> drives I just put together occupy about the same space as 32 4mm tape
> cartridges.  At DDS3 densities, an 80gig disk in an enclosure loses by
> a factor of nearly 5.  Tapes are easier to carry off-site.  

The hard link through multiple copies means that one drive is doing the
job of many, many tapes.  Tapes don't support this random-access 
directory-based structure.  So indeed, you can hold a tape in your hand
with one 80GB backup on it (and that tape will cost about as much as
a hard disk these days),  but no tape can have the virtual equivalent
of 100 backups.  

The reason we even bother with backups at all is for later restoration
after a small or large disaster.  Single files come off a hard drive in
seconds; most of the time is spent physically getting the drive inserted
and the partition mounted.  Pulling a single file off a tape is very
slow - especially if you don't know for sure what tape it is on!  Bare
metal restores take a while for either process, but by putting a boot
partition on the backup drive, I can boot it with all the necessary
recovery information in place.  A configured CDROM might be as fast
as a disk partition, but it takes a while to build a CDROM, or plug
the right info into Linux-BBC or Knoppix. 

Russell Senior writes:
> ...  Not sure
> about your "less system load" or "easier swapping" claims either.

I don't think you can rsync to a tape.  Rsync is very smart about
moving data;  thus, I back up 50GB of networked systems in 30 minutes
or so, with rsync throttled so it leaves bandwidth for other tasks.
Swapping?  Sure, it takes about as much time to move a hard drive
to storage as to move a box of tapes.  But it is easier to look
through multiple virtual images on a hard drive than load and unload
helical scan tapes.  As above, finding files is MUCH faster.




Russell Senior writes:
> The tricky thing about these is keeping people from changing anything
> in the mounted snapshots. 

The backups are accessed through a few levels of directories with
permission 700, and the backup drive itself is normally unmounted.
If I get root-cracked, that doesn't stop someone from diddling the
backup drive, of course.  Or a loaded tape ...

If I was paranoid, I could power off the backup drive between uses. 
One method might put an old appliance timer on the power feed to the
backup hard disk - if backups normally run at 3am and take 40 minutes,
then the timer is set to power on at 2:50am and power off at 5:50am
(an hour of slop to allow for daylight savings time, and lazy clock
setting).  At the same time, the timer could oppositely power cycle
the cable router, so the backup drive is never connected to the net.
But frankly, I am not that paranoid.  I am more worried that someone
will social-engineer my wife into allowing physical access so they
can steal a backup drive. So maybe it is good that hard drive trays
are bigger than tapes.  :-)
 
---

This is all very much a work in progress.  As a pioneer in this
one small way,  I expect a few arrow wounds,  but the feedback I
am getting here might help me avoid some mistakes.  Again, keep
a watch of the page at  http://www.keithl.com/linuxbackup.html ,
and contribute ideas and tools where you can.    Current projects
involve changing from mbox to maildir, and moving to Suse style
"dateext" logrotate, so accumulating files backup more densely.

The backup-to-disk process still lacks some tools - I would like to be
able to prepare a virgin dirvish bank more quickly, and it would be
cool to have an individual-file-restore tool that builds a chronological
history of the changes to a file.  I would like a bare-metal restore
process that was a lot more automatic (Oh, the main hard drive blew
up?  Load new drive, load backup drive, boot, start automatic restore,
go to movie, come back, swap drives, reboot).  I figure I get more
tools when I convince more competent people to use this approach. 

Ah, at last the hidden agenda ... Keith wants to see more movies,
so he wants his friends to write code that panders to this habit.
"Third main drive failure this week.  Darn, I ought to be more 
careful with hammers.  What's at the Fox Tower today?"  Obviously,
the first task of a world-class bare-metal restore tool will be
to download movie schedules ... but I digress ...  :-)

On Tue, 7 Oct 2003, Paul Heinlein wrote:

> This doesn't smell like a kernel problem to me -- more like a hardware
> issue related to the reconfigured BIOS. My hunches include, in no
> particular order,

  I do believe that it was a BIOS mis-configuration.

  Couldn't find the manual (which I know is here, somewhere, but not in the
file where it should be) so I downloaded one from the MSI Web site. It shows
two jumpers to toggle the FSB clock among 100MHz, 133MHz and 166MHz.
Unfortunately, no such jumpers are on the motherboard.

  Called ENU. Tech says that he recalls it being in the BIOS, not on the
board itself. So, back to the BIOS I go. Finally found the clock setting! It
doesn't toggle among those three speeds, but increments/decrements by 1MHz.
So I moved it up to 133MHz. Saved and rebooted.

  Now, as the POST flashes by I see a SDRAM speed of 333MHz rather than the
266MHz I had seen. When I could log in and check /proc/cpuinfo, it read
'2100+' with a clock speed of 1766 MHz. Good enough.

  I just finished compiling the kernel (that was quick -- I started it just
before starting to write this message. It's done before I am.

  So, it appears that I finally found the correct place in the BIOS to make
the system run at the rated speed of the CPU and RAM. Whew!

  Thanks to everyone!!

  To close an earlier thread, I returned the Fellowes "Micro Trac" and
replaced it with a Belkin two-button/wheel mouse. The latter works just fine
on the console. Half the price, too.

Rich

That looks like window manager data, but not application properties.  Stuff 
in .Xresources is like,

!# NEdit
NEdit*text.Translations: #override\n\
Shift<Btn4Down>,<Btn4Up>: scroll_up(1)\n\
Shift<Btn5Down>,<Btn5Up>: scroll_down(1)\n\
Ctrl<Btn4Down>,<Btn4Up>: previous_page()\n\
Ctrl<Btn5Down>,<Btn5Up>: next_page(1)\n\
     <Btn4Down>,<Btn4Up>: scroll_up(3)\n\
     <Btn5Down>,<Btn5Up>: scroll_down(3)\n
NEdit*text.selectBackground: IndianRed1


Pretty sure case matters too.  Nice programs document this stuff.  Bad 
programs need to be punished.

From holger at selover.net  Tue Oct  7 21:35:02 2003
From: holger at selover.net (Holger Stephan)
Date: Tue Oct  7 21:35:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Javascript question
In-Reply-To: <44706.68.107.223.201.1065570418.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
References: <44706.68.107.223.201.1065570418.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <1065587696.454.76.camel@halo>

Matt, 

When you dynamically create the page on the server side you don't have
to use JavaScript to determine which text field you want to put the
focus on. Just create the correct focus() dynamically. Otherwise this
may do the trick on the client side: 

...
<script type="text/javascript">
function setFocus()
{
	if (document.form1.textfield2.value == "two")
		document.form1.textfield2.focus()
	else
		document.form1.textfield1.focus()
}
</script>
</head>

<body onLoad="setFocus()">
<form name="form1">
    <input name="textfield1" type="text" value="one">
    <input name="textfield2" type="text" value="two">
...

- Holger (top posting subersive)

On Tue, 2003-10-07 at 16:46, Matt Alexander wrote:
> Does anyone know how I would send the focus to a text field based on its
> contents?  For example, I dynamically create an HTML table (containing
> input text fields) from an SQL query and I want to have the cursor
> automatically go to a certain field containing a certain string of text.

From kens at kens.cad2cam.com  Tue Oct  7 21:46:02 2003
From: kens at kens.cad2cam.com (Kenneth G. Stephens)
Date: Tue Oct  7 21:46:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mandrake 9.1 Install - Boot Menu Not Avail.
In-Reply-To: <01C3841B.B6F0BE80.drcaldwell@cablerocket.com>
References: <01C3841B.B6F0BE80.drcaldwell@cablerocket.com>
Message-ID: <1065588321.23994.21.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>

On Fri, 2003-09-26 at 10:48, da.haole.boy wrote: 
 
> With this partitioning set up, I assumed the /boot would be the 
> partition that all boot-related files would go into, however, when I 
> bootup, I don't get any OS choice.  To switch from Win2k to Linux, or 
> vise versa, I have to either edit the default hdd in my BIOS, or leave 
> 
> Thanks for any & all serious help... humor can come later, please... all 
> I'd need is tongue-in-cheek being taken as sound advice...  :-)
> Dave
> 
You probably boot right into Windows.  You don't say.  You need to edit
the boot.ini file on your C: drive.  Add the line: 

c:\bootsect.lnx="Linux" 

Also copy dd if=/dev/sda of=/bootsect.lnx bs=512 count=1 

as root when you have your linux system booted.  Copy that to a floppy
or if you can mount your C drive copy the file there. 

The the next time you boot, you will get a choice
