From freyley at gmx.net  Tue Oct  7 22:48:01 2003
From: freyley at gmx.net (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Tue Oct  7 22:48:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] About alpha and what to do with mine...
In-Reply-To: <1065588123.6426.42.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: 
	 <OFEE7191AE.3C486203-ON88256DB8.00614927-88256DB8.0061AA6E@hb.fcpa.fujitsu.c om>
	 <1065586398.637.7.camel@localhost>
	 <1065588123.6426.42.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1065592039.635.19.camel@localhost>

> What went wrong?  Why did alpha seemingly fall out 
> of favor?  For a while it was difficult to find a 
> copy of Redhat for the alpha and even the alphalinux 
> site disappeared for a time.  Has Intel bought up 
> alpha or is it owned by HP?

Alpha was created by Digital, aka DEC, which was bought by Compaq, which
merged / was bought by HP. HP/Compaq declared the alpha line of
processors dead a few years ago, though there were engineers working on
it so that an update would be available to customers who were committed
to VMS and Digital Unix. But publicly, HP stated that future servers
would be Itaniums, because they were faster, and customers would be
migrated to Itanium asap. In addition, they said they were working to
port VMS and Digital Unix to Itanium. But when the EV7 came out, which
would have been the new Alpha, sometime last year, all benchmarks for it
were suppressed, and the alpha was again declared dead, with HP stating
that all servers would be Itanium based. A few folks I know at HP tell
me that that the EV7 kicked the Itanium II's ass so badly that HP higher
ups were rather embarrassed because they'd been touting the Itanium as
faster, which it wasn't. Though of course, HP denies any such things,
and claims no benchmarks were ever run.

All hail the Alpha. 'Tis dead. 

> Anyone have tips on finding programs for it?  You could
> get Windows NT for it for a while, but few programs
> worked where Microsoft oddly stopped supporting 
> NT4 alpha.  2000 was never officially released 
> on alpha, though I've heard it existed as a beta.
> I got mine from Enorex Microsystems which went out of
> business two years or so later.  Can alpha systems
> even be purchased anymore?  Mine was three years old
> in 1998, apparently it had been on the shelf that 
> long.  Just seems these systems didn't compete 
> affectively with the Pentium II, but why?

Debian is committed to the idea that all packages will run on all ports,
so that's your best bet. Anything in Debian stable will run on alpha, as
well as most stuff in testing and much of unstable. I had problems with
Gaim crashing fairly frequently when I ran debian testing on my alpha,
an EV56, but no major issues.

As for competing -- intel kicked their ass in price. Alpha was always an
expensive architecture, meant for servers, and intel was cheaper.
Despite the fact that an Alpha EV56 500 mhz can usually beat an Intel P3
at 1 Ghz, and an AMD Athlon at 1.3 Ghz[1], they were popular enough. Add
to that the fact that only some programs ran on them, and they were
esoteric enough to be barely profitable.

[1] I had all three of those systems last year, and used them
simultaneously. Those are personal observations of compile times, as
well as personal benchmarks achieved from running my own code on all
three machines.

Jeff

On Tue, 2003-10-07 at 23:04, Russell Senior wrote:
> but WTF?

Sounds like a resource allocation issue. I'd try telling the BIOS to
reallocate resources by resetting configuration data after turning off
all unneeded stuff like extra serial and parallel ports, IRQ for PCI
video. That mey free up needed resources. If the card has specific
requirements like DMA or a certain IRQ, I'd check toi see if they are
free before inserting the card.

That's all I can think, of. Unless, of course, the card is trash. Did it
come from Fry's? :0

Why do companies try to buy out and kill certain technologies
if they in fact turn out to be better than what they're being
replaced with?  I think the alpha's higher cost was well worth
it, at the time in 1998 only P233's were common.  

This thing runs at 366Mhz and you could get a 500Mhz model 
then where if the megahertz can be doubled for comparison
purposes against x86 models, that's even more impressive.

In all the hype about megahertz, have hardware engineers
poorly engineered many of the new computers coming out
failing to use more accurate measurements of 
performance?

It's sad that a new competitor other than Apple was
developing to take on the PC, yet it has been all but
scuttled.  I wonder if more of these alpha's can be
picked up cheap.

What it would it take for someone friendly to producing
the alpha to line up the specifications
for the EV7 as well as plants to produce it?
It's a stable architecture it seems if you know how
to program it correctly.

The beauty of Alpha is that it isn't Itanium, 
no messed up IA32 architecture behind it.  It's
a family of machines that just seem to have been
better thought out from day one.

     --  Michael C. Robinson

>

> annoying.
> 
> When I close mozilla I have to HUP a hanging process.

I have the same problem with Mozilla 1.4 on RH9.
I found a couple bugs in Bugzilla:

http://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=193827
http://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=188332

It looks like the Mozilla resolver hangs when the DNS TCP request times 
out.  Firewalls and resolvers that don't support TCP like djbdns make it 
worse.  Certain sites, like story.news.yahoo.com, with long responses 
seem to be the worse.

The "root=LABEL=/" doesn't look right either. It looks like grub will
search for anything that makes sense and work down from there.  This
means that you were booting off the first drive, but grub found a
configuration on the other drive that made more sense and loaded it
instead.

Fun with boot loaders.

Derek Loree

From heinlein at madboa.com  Wed Oct  8 07:02:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)

Subject: [PLUG] NFS and/or alternatives
In-Reply-To: <1065588284.23994.16.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>
References: <86wubkclz5.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>  <Pine.LNX.4.58.0310050714150.1461@pecos.madboa.com>
 <1065588284.23994.16.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0310080648490.28433@pecos.madboa.com>

On Tue, 7 Oct 2003, Kenneth G. Stephens wrote:

> Also, if you are mounting stuff NFS, use the nfsvers=3,tcp options.
> The version 2 client sucks, to put it mildly.

Mostly: v3 is poorly implemented in the 2.2 kernel series.

Whether or not you have to specify it, however, is pretty much up to
your distro's version of mount. Red Hat and Debian both seem to
default to v3; I can't speak for other distributions. To see which
nfs version(s) you're using, do

  nfsstat -c # for client-side usage
  nfsstat -s # for nfs servers

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From garl.grigsby at plms-eds.com  Wed Oct  8 09:32:01 2003
From: garl.grigsby at plms-eds.com (Grigsby, Garl)
Date: Wed Oct  8 09:32:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Anyone have experience installing Maple 9 Linux edition?
Message-ID: <159441354A896D4A8886543D5043BC315E56E0@uscimplm001.net.plm.eds.com>

I am far to familiar with Flex. So what exactly is your problem. 

FlexLM is a licensing software system that works by encrypting a license string to the MAC address of the NIC on the license server. The clients then connect, via TCP to the license server to "check out" a license. 

It was originally written by a company called Globetrotter. They have since been bought out bye Macrovision. Here is a link to the FlexLM homepage which has decent documentation. http://www.macrovision.com/products/flexlm/index.shtml

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Wed Oct  8 12:26:01 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Wed Oct  8 12:26:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] flexlm and Linux
Message-ID: <20031008192448.GA5239@gate.kl-ic.com>

I run a bunch of expensive electronic CAD.  Some of the programs
are Windoze running under Win4lin and using Rainbow parallel-port
dongles.  One runs under Linux, and uses the Aladdin HASP parallel
port dongle.  I have to jump through some hoops to make this all
work (like compile custom kernels with security code, feh) but the
dongles do work.

I believe flexlm is used in some way by both of these.  If you
have an Aladdin dongle, you can download the latest drivers from
their website,  http://www.ealladin.com/support/hasp/enduser.asp

The Windoze Rainbow stuff came on the application installer disks.

Keith

On Tue, Oct 07, 2003 at 09:44:32PM -0700, Kenneth G. Stephens wrote:
> On Sun, 2003-10-05 at 07:15, Paul Heinlein wrote: 
> > On Sat, 4 Oct 2003, Russell Senior wrote:
> > 
> > > What are people using these days?  Is it still NFS uber alles these
> > > days or are there workable/preferable alternatives?  If NFS,
> > > kernel-space or userland?  Thanks for pointers/recommendations.
> > 
> > I haven't tried any of the NFS alternatives (Coda et al.) so I may not
> > be the best source of info -- but the kernel-space NFS stuff has
> > worked very well for me.
> > 
> > --Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>
> Also, if you are mounting stuff NFS, use the nfsvers=3,tcp options.  The
> version 2 client sucks, to put it mildly. 

You might want to test the tcp option.  On a LAN, performance can be greatly
degraded by using tcp instead of udp.  I always specify tcp for VPN or WAN
mounts.

Here are my standard mount options:

-o rsize=8192,wsize=8192,hard,intr,proto=udp

This is the environment I use for amd on rh7-9 going to an Auspex NFS filer
(Solaris 6 based).

I'm just a packet pusher.

Years ago, I took a bunch of old computers over to Strut.  A giant
warehouse full of old computers and not much activity.  I was
reminded of the warehouse at the end of Raiders of the Lost Ark.

Intel to donate their money, IMHO.  In an age of tight budgets, Strut
may not be the best way to spend very limited money.  If you don't
like it, make a very large donation to Strut and I'm sure they
would consider re-opening.

  Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers (IEEE)
Oregon Computer Society Chapter + Communications Society Chapter
                               presents
                                                                                
"The Keyhole Problem: How Gratuitous Constraints Decrease Software Quality"
                                                                                
Speaker: Scott Meyers, Software Development Consultant
                       www.aristeia.com
                                                                                
When: October 16, 2003, Thursday
             6:00 PM - Networking & food/refreshments
                        (sponsored by AZAD  www.azad.com)
             6:45 PM - Technical Lecture
Cost:    Free and open to the public (Reservations required)
                                                                                
RESERVATIONS:  By 12 NOON October 15, 2003, Wednesday
                                                                                
                                                                                
Location:
   Oregon Graduate Institute of Science and Technology (OGI)
             Wilson Clark Center, main dining room
           20000 NW Walker Rd., Beaverton, OR 97006
         Campus map: www.ogi.edu/maps/campus_map.html
 Host: OGI Center for Professional Development www.cpd.ogi.edu
                                                                                
ABSTRACT:
  Far too much software imposes unnecessary constraints on
  what you can see or express, essentially forcing you to see
  the world through a virtual keyhole.  Some keyholes are
  visible (i.e., part of a GUI), others are invisible (e.g.,
  an unnecessary restriction on a data value).  Keyholes  are
  sometimes comical, always irritating, and occasionally quite
  literally deadly. This talk demonstrates a number of
  different kinds of keyholes and explains how they decrease
  usability, increase inconsistency, and can lead to system
  failures.  It will help you improve the software you develop
  by opening your eyes to keyholes, demonstrating why they are
  undesirable, and discussing how to eliminate them.  The
  content of this talk is based on the work Scott Meyers has
  been doing on his book of the same name.  You can read about
  the book project at www.aristeia.com/TKP.
                                                                                
BIOGRAPHY:
  Scott Meyers is an independent software development
  consultant focusing on techniques for developing
  high-quality software.  He wrote the best-selling Effective
  C++ series (Effective C++, More Effective C++, and Effective
  STL), wrote and designed the innovative Effective C++ CD, is
  consulting editor for Addison Wesley's Effective Software
  Development Series, and is a member of the advisory board
  for Software Development magazine. He also sits on technical
  advisory boards for several start-up companies. A programmer
  since 1972, he holds an M.S. in Computer Science from
  Stanford University and a Ph.D. from Brown University.  Scott
  offers consulting and training services to clients worldwide.
                                                                                
  His web site is www.aristeia.com.
                                                                                
For information on this lecture, contact:
                          Alex Harkins   harkins at ieee.org
                                                                                
For information on the IEEE Society Chapters, contact:
            Computer: Hadi Asgharzadeh    hadi at azad.com
      Communications: Pradeep Kumar       pradeep at ieee.org
                                                                                
Check out these sites for joining information:
               IEEE: http://www.ieee.org/membership/join/
           Computer: http://www.computer.org/join/
     Communications: http://www.comsoc.org/member/index.html

> shudder.  Not the behavior I'd expect from a weak power supply.  Then
> again... WTF!  I mean, conflicting interrupts aren't going to prevent an
> AT power supply fan from spinning.  This is pre-ATX.  The power supply
> knows diddly about the motherboard state.  All it knows is that Mr Thumb
> just pushed the Big Red Switch.

Even AT power supplies are switching, so they control the output based on
load.  If you disconnect the AT power supply from the motherboard does it
power up?  It shouldn't.

If something is FUBAR enough then conceivably the AT supply won't power
on.  This would probably be something like the card/bus causing a short.
Have you tried another slot?  What does the card do in other systems?  I
doubt that an IRQ issue would prevent the system from coming up.

I've plugged all kinds of wierd stuff into my old junker Pentium 233 PCI
system just to see what the PCI IDs are, and haven't had a power-on
problem.  (I.e. cards made for Sun/HP systems, etc...)

  -- Steve



From bmabbott at riverdale.k12.or.us  Wed Oct  8 13:17:02 2003
From: bmabbott at riverdale.k12.or.us (Ben Mabbott)

Subject: [PLUG] Strut
In-Reply-To: <20031008193156.GB5239@gate.kl-ic.com>

Keith Lofstrom wrote:

>Years ago, I took a bunch of old computers over to Strut.  A giant
>warehouse full of old computers and not much activity.  I was
>reminded of the warehouse at the end of Raiders of the Lost Ark. 
>I imagine my computers were still sitting in that warehouse when
>they closed.
>
Actually, your computers are probably being put to good use in a rural 
school right now.  Yes, Strut tended to have stacks and stacks of old 
computers that seemed to languish there, but they didn't go to waste. 
Once a year they would have a conference during which all the schools 
that were too far away to come on a regular basis would show up and take 
stuff by the truckload.  There are many rural schools out there that 
aside from a few ancient Macs would have no computers to speak of if not 
for Strut.  That alone made it a worthwhile program, not to mention 
their excellent recycling program, and the classes they taught.

Not that FreeGeek isn't great too, but Strut was definitely a worth 
cause to donate to.

-Ben

I effectively ran the StRUT program at Lincoln when it started, while
many other schools have probably seen greater benefit (due to the
source of the average LHS student), StRUT played a major part in
bringing computers to all the classes at LHS.  It also lead to
adopting Linux in many parts of the school also (servers and desktops,
if I remember correctly).

Besides all that, I learned a hell of a lot setting up desktop
machines from bare parts, and stripping windows/office to fit on
sub-200MB drives ;), or building ftp-install floppies for win98 w/out
documentation. (The linux movement happened after I graduated :().

memory a vague recall that either or both of R or Octave would have eigen
functions. They do.

  The R statistical system is the FOSS equivalent of S/S-PLUS in the winduhs
world. It is a _huge_ statistical programming language (as Gri is a plotting
language) and it has an 'eigen' function that handles both sparse and full
matrices. R functions can be called from other programs; I've done this with
GRASS to run statistics on spatial maps.

  Octave is the FOSS equivalent to MatLab. It, too, will calculate
eigenvectors and eigenvalues of square matrices.

  I think that Octave would be good for stand-alone calculations while R
will be the way to incorporate the calcuations into a larger model.

Thanks for looking and replying,

Rich

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Oct  8 16:09:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed Oct  8 16:09:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DNS Resolution Problems - 5 second delay
In-Reply-To: <1065653249.5586.14.camel@dell.linux.box>
References: <1065651941.5586.7.camel@dell.linux.box>  <9054-25148@sneakemail.com>
 <1065653249.5586.14.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <4998-72373@sneakemail.com>

On Wed, 8 Oct 2003, AthlonRob AthlonRob-at-axpr.net |PDX Linux| wrote:

> Is that what we're looking at?  It waits five seconds then re-sends the
> packet?  That would explain it, then...
>
> It would also explain why, very rarely, it waits ten seconds before
> timing out altogether.

Yep, you'll see little quantii of time spent when DNS times out because of
packet loss.  This depends on the number of DNS servers listed in your
resolv.conf.  The default timeout in /usr/include/resolv.h is (big
surprise) 5 seconds.

> I'm on a wifi link, but only a few feet from my AP.  ifconfig reports 18
> dropped TX packets of 4MB sent, with one error.  iwconig reports 15
> 'missed beacon' but no other errors.
>
> How else might I determine if the packets are being sent, only to be
> dropped somewhere along the line?

First, set up both the client and server to be NTP time synced.  This
makes comparing packet traces easier.

Then start tcpdump on both systems.  I use "tcpdump -i eth0 -p -s 2048 -w
/tmp/<hostname>_dns.tcpdump".  Refer to the man page for details.  The
"2048" is not magic, but it needs to be bigger than your media maximum
transmit unit including all MAC/MAC-equivalent headers.

Run your test for a minute or so, then cancel both tcpdump captures.  Copy
to a convenient Linux host that has "ethereal" installed and look at them
using:

ethereal -t a -r <tcpdump capture file>

The filters in ethereal allow you to show only DNS packets, which is
likely to be helpful if your network is at all busy.

Now that you say you're on wireless I'm not at all surprised you get
ocassional DNS timeouts.  If your server is local you can work around this
typical packet loss by cranking down your DNS timeout to something like 1
second.  See "man resolv.conf" for details on this option.

  -- Steve

PS: To test your overall packet loss on the wifi link, I've had good luck
getting "netperf" from http://www.netperf.org/netperf/NetperfPage.html and
tcptrace from http://www.tcptrace.org/.  I'll run netperf while tcpdump is
running on the server end, then use tcptrace to analyze the connection and
measure the percent packet loss.  Anything over 5% will be noticable,
though this is a matter of opinion.  ;-)

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Oct  8 17:10:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Oct  8 17:10:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Matrix manipulation code in C or FORTRAN
In-Reply-To: <159441354A896D4A8886543D5043BC315E56E8@uscimplm001.net.plm.eds.com>
References: <159441354A896D4A8886543D5043BC315E56E8@uscimplm001.net.plm.eds.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310081657030.25040@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 8 Oct 2003, Grigsby, Garl wrote:

> So what is it you are attempting to calculate EigenValues for, if you
> don't mind me asking? It is so rare for me to run into people in a
> non-work setting that have ever heard of an eigenvalue, much less want to
> calculate one.

Garl,

  Sorry to disappoint, but this is work related ... for me.

  I have two related applications: ranking alternatives that are not equally
attractive and as part of a multiobjective, multicriteria decision support
system under conditions of uncertainty.

  In the first application, one has the stakeholders or decision makers do a
binary pair-wise comparison of all alternative combinations: of the two,
which is preferred. Then the amount of preference is scored on a ratio scale
of 1-9. The preference is placed in a matrix of alternatives for each paired
comparison. The eigenvalue of the matrix is found and the associated
eigenvector is generated. This represents the rank of each alternative. The
eigenvector values can then be multiplied by the number of alternatives to
normalize them to the problem size.

  In the second application, a similar process is used to produce exponents
for fuzzy sets that are then aggregated using an ordered, weighted average
(OWA) set operation. Because the pair-wise values are generated for both the
objectives and the criteria (constraints), they can be used to prioritize
alternatives.

  All of this is explained in the book I'm writing and incorporated into the
fuzzy system/approximate reasoning modeling system I'm developing for
environmental impact assessments.

Rich

Hi folks.  Sometimes real people have answers when google searches
fail us.

I just acquired a Netgear WAB102 wireless access point.  This is
just the access point; no firewall, broadband sharing, switch, etc.
An ethernet jack and a couple of antennas.

I know I could set it up for a fixed IP, but it has the ability
to request it's own IP address via DHCP.  I left it enabled that
way, and I have one of my Linux servers configured as a DHCP server.
The problem is I get this:

Oct  8 18:47:25 xxx dhcpd: DHCPDISCOVER from <mac addr> via eth0
Oct  8 18:47:25 xxx dhcpd: DHCPOFFER on 192.168.100.128 to <mac addr> via eth0

Worked fine in the P3, so call off the fire engines.  Only a couple
surprises, which should have been anticipated:

  a) box is a print server with two printers, the second parallel port
     being provided by an even older ISA I/O card.  Gong!  No more ISA
     slots in the newer motherboard.  Fortunately, one of the printers
     is newer and had an USB socket.  Recompiled the kernel for USB
     printer support (got *lots* of USB ports these days), edit
     /etc/printcap and back in business.

  b) keyboard is an old-style AT keyboard.  Could find an adapter, but
     I think I'll just spring for another $10 PS/2 keyboard.

Old P200 box is off to free geek.

That's the ticket. Thanks

From griffint at pobox.com  Fri Oct 10 07:15:03 2003
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Fri Oct 10 07:15:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Kernel question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310100625190.32066@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310100625190.32066@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200310100714.06254.griffint@pobox.com>

On Friday 10 October 2003 06:29 am, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   What is the relationship between bzImage and vmlinux (with an 'x')? I
> know that vmlinuz (with the 'z') is a soft link to the desired version of
> vmlinux.
>
>   I built the new kernal for slack-9.1 with 'make bzImage'. I copied that
> to /boot, but I'm not sure what to do about the vmlinux still in
> .../arch/i386/boot/. Do I copy that to /boot with the version number
> appended, then recreate the vmlinuz soft link?
>

vmlinux is the uncompressed kernel. It comes in handy for
kernel debugging. It is not generally useful for non-developers.

If you do wish to save vmlinux, it is normally copied to /boot with the
kernel version suffix added.

Terry

line with Verizon and Hevanet. So I called Hevanet and asked for case
studies or statistical material we could use to determine the
reliability. Nothing available. Do any of you run commercial sites on
DSL and has it worked out for you?

Hello all,

I'm running a web server and have all the good stuff going on it such as DNS, Web,
FTP, Mail, etc.  I have a second machine else where that does secondary DNS.

This all works fine but would like to know if there is a way to set up some logic in
that I can have the first machine backup up to the second and if the first goes down
that the second will become the active machine?  I know that there is something in
Mail that will do reduntant delivery or something.  Some DNS MX record setting?

Is there some DNS setting that I can achieve this for HTTP, FTP, and other internet
services?  I want to know if there is something in DNS that if it can't find one web
server that it will go to another.  Or maybe if it can't find one IP it will go to
another to try to resolve services.  I will be backing up all the data remotely over
rsync and such and would be nice to set up reduntant fall over systems via DNS.

Is this possible?  Do I make sense?

Josh

Well, I use my DSL for some commercial secondary DNS only.  Thinking of maybe using
it for reduntant systems if I can.  But you should know.  The phone company has no
obligation to put the DSL up if it fails.  Well they do, but it is a last priority
item.  Meaning that if the phone lines go down, they will fix high speed access then
ISDN then DSL.  We use to have an ISDN line be reduntant before DSL because the
phone company would fix that long before they fixed voice or DSL.

So, the question may be, how important is it that the site always be up for your
customer and will they be upset if it is down for a long time?

That said.  My DSL for the last 7 years has been down about 2 days.  So I'd say, it
is pretty reliable. ;-)

Josh

From kyle at silverbeach.net  Fri Oct 10 12:59:01 2003
From: kyle at silverbeach.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Fri Oct 10 12:59:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] high speed filesystems
In-Reply-To: <1065812918.1886.3.camel@kokopelli>
References: <1065812918.1886.3.camel@kokopelli>
Message-ID: <200310101257.52328.kyle@silverbeach.net>

On Friday 10 October 2003 12:08, Brian Beattie wrote:
> I'm investigating options for very high speed data logging.  I'm
> wondering if anybody knows of any work on filesystems in this area.

Hmm, XFS is supposed to deal with large multimedia data well.  That seems like 
a close match.  I.e. it will stream it continuously and at high rates (I 
assume both reading and writing) very nicely.   I haven't used it, but I've 
read this in the XFS papers and seen it posted in other venues.

If you want really high speed, do you need a filesystem?  I.e. could you just 
blast it to a raw partition in block-sized chunks?  You'd need a partition 
(or at least a block device) per log "file".  Sounds like a lot more work, 
but the speed can't be beat.

Best,
Kyle

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Fri Oct 10 14:07:02 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Fri Oct 10 14:07:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Finding the full path of a program
Message-ID: <20031010210700.GA13560@sapphire.CS.ORST.EDU>

First off, apologies for breaking this thread. I accidentially deleted
the previous messages.

The symlink /proc/<pid>/exe appears to point to the executeable that
started the process with ID <pid>. So, 'ls -l /proc/<pid>/exe' should
give you the path, although you may want to hack a script to do it for
you. (Perhaps a patch to ps?).

Starting emacs as 'emacs -nw', then looking it up in proc gave
/usr/bin/emacs-21.1, which is at the end of a symling chain starting
with /usr/bin/emacs.

-Rogan

From ed at alcpress.com  Fri Oct 10 14:50:03 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Fri Oct 10 14:50:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Redundant and backup
In-Reply-To: <1341.134.244.174.87.1065814411.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <1341.134.244.174.87.1065814411.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <1065823374.1050.294.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Fri, 2003-10-10 at 12:33, Josh Orchard wrote:
> Hello all,
> 
> I hope your days are going well.
> 
> I'm running a web server and have all the good stuff going on it such as DNS, Web,
> FTP, Mail, etc.  I have a second machine else where that does secondary DNS.
> 
> This all works fine but would like to know if there is a way to set up some logic in
> that I can have the first machine backup up to the second and if the first goes down
> that the second will become the active machine?  I know that there is something in
> Mail that will do reduntant delivery or something.  Some DNS MX record setting?
> 
> Is there some DNS setting that I can achieve this for HTTP, FTP, and other internet
> services?  I want to know if there is something in DNS that if it can't find one web
> server that it will go to another.  Or maybe if it can't find one IP it will go to
> another to try to resolve services.  I will be backing up all the data remotely over
> rsync and such and would be nice to set up reduntant fall over systems via DNS.
> 
> Is this possible?  Do I make sense?

The mechanism for doing this is DNS SRV (service) records. SRV
records are just like an MCX records except that they're
protocol-independent. MX records are only used with SMTP (so far),
while SRV records can be used with any protocol including HTTP.
Unfortunately, Web browsers do not support SRV records even
though we've been trying to get the designers to support them for
about 5 years.

Ed

> Josh

On Fri, 2003-10-10 at 15:14, Josh Orchard wrote:
> > On Fri, 2003-10-10 at 12:33, Josh Orchard wrote:
> >> Hello all,
> >>
> >> I hope your days are going well.
> >>
> >> I'm running a web server and have all the good stuff going on it such as DNS, Web,
> >> FTP, Mail, etc.  I have a second machine else where that does secondary DNS.
> >>
> >> This all works fine but would like to know if there is a way to set up some logic
> >> in
> >> that I can have the first machine backup up to the second and if the first goes
> >> down
> >> that the second will become the active machine?  I know that there is something in
> >> Mail that will do reduntant delivery or something.  Some DNS MX record setting?
> >>
> >> Is there some DNS setting that I can achieve this for HTTP, FTP, and other
> >> internet
> >> services?  I want to know if there is something in DNS that if it can't find one
> >> web
> >> server that it will go to another.  Or maybe if it can't find one IP it will go to
> >> another to try to resolve services.  I will be backing up all the data remotely
> >> over
> >> rsync and such and would be nice to set up reduntant fall over systems via DNS.
> >>
> >> Is this possible?  Do I make sense?
> >
> > The mechanism for doing this is DNS SRV (service) records. SRV
> > records are just like an MCX records except that they're
> > protocol-independent. MX records are only used with SMTP (so far),
> > while SRV records can be used with any protocol including HTTP.
> > Unfortunately, Web browsers do not support SRV records even
> > though we've been trying to get the designers to support them for
> > about 5 years.
> >
> > Ed
> >
> >
> 
> So, besides setting up yet another system inbetween the first two I do not have a
> choice it seems.  The Linux-HA concepts appears to need a server in front to do like
> a load balancing concept.  I was hoping for something like the DNS SRV records
> concepts.  It does make the most sense.
> 
> Hmm, I'll have to think about another solution.  The two computers I have are not on
> the same network and are located in two different places.

One solution is to lobby the designers of Web browsers for SRV
support. There have only been a few of us pushing for SRV
support until now. When I contacted the Opera folks, they had
never heard of SRV records before but still said that they would
not support it. The Mozilla folks said that if I wanted SRV
support, I should contribute the code. One other (I forget which)
said that they'd add SRV support when DNS supported SRV - they were
referring to the fact that few people use SRV records, which is, of
course, a chicken and egg problem.

Ed

From jason at vancleve.com  Fri Oct 10 19:22:01 2003

In-Reply-To: <1065827723.11159.4.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>

On Fri, 2003-10-10 at 18:15, Alan wrote:

> Does anyone have any recomendations on a GUI DVD burning program for
> Linux.  I have not found one yet, but I expect I am missing something. 
> I could use the command line, but with the amount of data I need to back
> up, it would be a royal pain.

I've been hearing lots of praise for k3b, which is a front end for
cdrtools (as is x-cdroast, I suspect).  But I didn't install it, because
it has too many dependencies, and I'm on a dial-up.  Looks splashy,
though.

On the other hand, a script can make those CLI tools pretty agreeable. 
My system is fast enough to pipe the mkisofs output directly to
cdrecord, so I can do this:

mkisofs -R $* | cdrecord -v dev=ATAPI:0,0,0 speed=12 -

And here $* can be files or a directory, so it's handy.  Of course, it
may or may not be so simple with a DVD burner.

--Jason Van Cleve

From brmiller at kudzuforest.com  Sat Oct 11 01:06:01 2003
From: brmiller at kudzuforest.com (brmiller at kudzuforest.com)
Date: Sat Oct 11 01:06:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Continuous DHCP lease request by Netgear WAP?
In-Reply-To: <20031008190357.D4807@kudzuforest.com>; from brmiller@kudzuforest.com on Wed, Oct 08, 2003 at 07:03:57PM -0700
References: <20031008190357.D4807@kudzuforest.com>
Message-ID: <20031011010509.C10488@kudzuforest.com>

> It looks like it's asking for a new DHCP lease every minute or so.  Is this 
> normal?  My default and maximum lease times are 6 hours and 7 days, respectively.
> Why all the DISCOVER/OFFER/DISCOVER/OFFER/REQUEST/ACK traffic?
> 
> As near as I can tell, there is no way to make the access point "shut up".

Thanks for the help/tips guys.  Don't want to jinx myself, but it looks
like a firmware upgrade has solved this problem.  It got itself a lease
15 minutes ago, and hasn't asked again yet.

Doing the firmware upgrade was painful though.  These little WAPs have a
web interface to upload the new firmware file through some cgi and http
send.  All magic hidden stuff.  Problem is that it would only get 80%
through and then it would lose its ethernet connection (I had it set
to static IP for this).  I would watch the lights on it, and the ethernet
light would be flashing like gang-busters while the transfer was going on,
then all the lights would go off, and the ethernet and power light would
start flashing--yep, rebooted.  Duh.  Over and over and over.

The thing has a telnet interface which is completely undocumented.  I'm
familiar with a few of these, but I couldn't figure out how to get a
firmware update that way.  Then I found the ftp command.  Tried to ftp
to my machine to get the firmware file, but no go--always said the ftp
connection died.  FINALLY, I got smart and ftp'd by IP address instead
of hostname (duh), and that worked.  Got the new firmware file in a temp
file, but now what?  No idea how to swap the new firmware in place.

Then I got real brave:

   mv tempfw apimg1

If this didn't work, I'd have a nice paper-weight with antennas!  I rebooted
and voila!  Now have v1.2.3 instead of 1.1.  Yee-haw!  Fixed the annoying
DHCP issues, as well as some speed improvements for the 802.11a Turbo
mode and other reliability fixes.

Thanks for listening. :)

Brendan

Ideally I was looking for a way that I could keep two machines in two different
locations but with identical services and files and if one IP from the DNS record
was not found that the host would resolve to another IP address.  There are many
reasons why that one host may not be found.  Cut phone line, building burnt down,
power failure, computer died.  By placing the two computers in different locations
on two different systems you would then have a reduntant backup and running computer
that would go online and no one would ever see down time.

The only service between the two computers you would need is a syncing tool to sync
files and you have rsync to achieve that.  It is just odd to me that the industrial
hasn't used SRV at the DNS level to achieve this.  Makes great sense.

I'll just work with what I find.  Just too bad that what seems like the most logical
and easy solution isn't being used.

Josh

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Sat Oct 11 09:03:01 2003
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Sat Oct 11 09:03:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Cat 5 cable question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310110803120.2696@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0310110852110.549-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Sat, 11 Oct 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   I'll ask this both ways to make myself clear:
>
>   Are all _orange_ cat 5 cables wired cross-over? Or, are all cross-over
> cables covered in _orange_ plastic?

No. Cat 5 cabling comes in every possible color. And I happen to own a
cross-over cable that is yellow, made by the seller. You only need to
worry whether it's a cross-over cable if & only if it has jacks on both
ends.

If that is the case, a quick sanity case is to compare the color of the
wires inside the jacks -- assuming the jacks are made of transparent
material. Performing a sanity check on my own collection of cables, if
the wires connecting one jack are the mirror image of the other, the cable
is a straight-thru. On my cross-over, the wires 1 & 2 in one jack match
with 3 & 6 on the other jack.

Geoff

> cross-over cable that is yellow, made by the seller. You only need to
> worry whether it's a cross-over cable if & only if it has jacks on both
> ends.

Oddly enough, all my cross over cables are yellow as well.  I bought them 
premade.

> If that is the case, a quick sanity case is to compare the color of the
> wires inside the jacks -- assuming the jacks are made of transparent
> material. Performing a sanity check on my own collection of cables, if
> the wires connecting one jack are the mirror image of the other, the cable
> is a straight-thru. On my cross-over, the wires 1 & 2 in one jack match
> with 3 & 6 on the other jack.

If you've got a hub with a cross-over port (often port one and often has a 
little switch to uncross it) you can plug it in to a computer and the hub and 
see which port makes it happy.  Check the link lights.

Best,
Kyle

The cross-ever is about termination. The cable is the same. You can make a 
standard cable cross-over and vice-a-versa, by removing one end and terminating 
it differently. I keep a drawing with my terminating crimpers to keep it 
straight...

From drl at drloree.com  Sat Oct 11 10:28:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Sat Oct 11 10:28:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Cat 5 cable question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310110803120.2696@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310110803120.2696@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Sat, 2003-10-11 at 08:20, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   I'll ask this both ways to make myself clear:
> 
>   Are all _orange_ cat 5 cables wired cross-over? Or, are all cross-over
> cables covered in _orange_ plastic?
> 
>   I have a small roll I'd like to use to connect my developing new box to
> the network, but not if it's cross-over cable. The markings are: UNICOM
> B8I12 TYPE CM 24AWG 75oC (UL) E151955 CSA LL79189 TIA/EIA-568A CATEGORY 5
> VERIFIED

The cable is just a bunch of twisted pairs of conductors, the way the
cable is connected to the connectors on the ends are what makes it
cross-over or not.  As it so happens, all of the orange cables in my
shop are cross-overs, but only because I made them that way.  Some of
them started life as straight-through, I cut one of the ends off and
made them into cross-overs.
> 
>   All I learn from googling on these numbers is that "CM" stands for "cable
> master" (whatever that is), and that the TIA/EIA standard refers to patch
> panels. Does this mean the answer to my questions is "yes"?

The general answer is no.  I've used this type of cable for
straight-through ethernet, cross-over ethernet, Cisco's special
roll-over cables, null modem cables and as phone line.  I also have
equipment that will place 12 Volts across two of the conductors, leaving
the ethernet conductors intact (the personal telco  guys do something
like this when they put their access points up on poles).

HTH,

Derek Loree

On Sat, 2003-10-11 at 07:51, Bill Thoen wrote:
> I would like to write a simple filter in C to move obvious spam
> messages from my INBOX file to another folder before reading them
> with Pine.
> 
> The question I have is how do I lock the file while I'm screwing
> around with it, and what happens should another message arrive
> during that time? Or should I use a different technique altogether?

This is what procmail was designed for.  I've had very good results from
a bayesian (sp?) filter called spamprobe. Spamprobe only scores the
mail, procmail is used to feed the mail into spamprobe, then to sort it
into the different directories, depending on the scoring.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

From ed at alcpress.com  Sat Oct 11 10:53:01 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)

Subject: [PLUG] Redundant and backup
In-Reply-To: <3F879E0B.8080307@spek.org>
References: <1341.134.244.174.87.1065814411.squirrel@sautez.com>
	 <1065823374.1050.294.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	 <2121.134.244.174.87.1065824067.squirrel@sautez.com>
	 <1065835951.1050.330.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	 <2186.216.99.218.67.1065839300.squirrel@sautez.com>
	 <3F879E0B.8080307@spek.org>
Message-ID: <1065895551.1050.359.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Fri, 2003-10-10 at 23:07, Brent Rieck wrote:
> Josh Orchard wrote:
> > Well that really just doesn't make much sense to me.  Everyone has a problem with
> > reduntant systems and if you could do it at the router or DNS record part then why
> > doesn't everyone do that?  Would save a lot of people some headaches.  Then again
> > maybe the load balancer and router folks wouldn't have a market then. Ok, LB guys
> > would but gateway and routers maybe less.
> 
> Delaying email a few timeouts here and there isn't any big deal, but I'd 
> guess that for interactive things (like browsing the web) it wouldn't 
> make for the finest user experience - is that the case?
> 
> But SRV appears to be only for failover not load balancing,

SRV records do have a load balancing mechanism but it's up
to the DNS client to honor it and it tends to be static
unless you engineer a way to update the records based on
load. Given that SRV records are not yet implemented in
popular browsers, it's a moot point right now.

One hack that might be acceptable for crude load balancing is
to always answer with a single A record that's updated as
the load on the servers change. Unfortunately, you gain
load balancing at the expense of fault tolerance - a trade off
I would never make. 

Ed

>  I'm no 
> expert but assuming you can place the boxes next to each other (and not 
> across the country from each other) failover has no additional hardware 
> costs beyond the cost of a serial cable I believe.
> 
> --Brent

From jeme at brelin.net  Sat Oct 11 12:47:01 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)

On Sat, 11 Oct 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> My .forward...
> "|IFS=' ' && exec /usr/bin/procmail -f- || exit 75 #user"

Why are you doing this instead of just using procmail for all local
delivery?

> So this sets the internal field seperator to ' ' and puts a new
> timestamp in an email as far as the from?  What's the exit 75
> #user about?

'exit 75' sets the exit code in case procmail fails (hence, the or [||])
to 75.

The #user is a comment.

> My .procmailrc	...
> :0fw: spamassinin.lock
> | /usr/bin/spamassassin
>
> I assume this just forwards to spamassassin.

And sets a lockfile.  man procmail.  It's very handy.

> I seem to be getting duplicate messages under evolution now, any tips?

Dunno what kind of voodoo you're attempting, but I just use procmail for
all local delivery and my rc.general (under .procmail) starts with this:

:0fw
| /usr/bin/spamc

:0:
* ^X-Spam-Status: Yes
IN.spam

And it works beautifully.
J.

On Sat, 2003-10-11 at 11:49, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> I've gotten install Mail::SpamAssassin to work, now what?  Where did
> this thing install and how do I actually use it?

Adjust your MTA to pipe through it and do the proper thing with the
result, your MDA to pipe through it and do the proper thing with the
result, or your MUA to pipe through it and do the proper thing with the
result.

I'd go with the MTA if you're running your own email server, or the MDA
(procmail, right?) if you want to do a more per-user thing.  Google for
it, there are howto's for using SpamAssassin with Procmail, it's pretty
easy, really.

Message-ID: <1065906159.10214.23.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Sat, 2003-10-11 at 13:28, Kenneth G. Stephens wrote:

> For the rest of us who setup spamassassin "by the book/gui", how does it
> work?  sendmail receives the email and then procmail distributes it.
> Procmail sends it to spamassassin?  Or. . . .

Did you actually use a GUI for it?

The way it works with the .forward file containing | procmail is
sendmail receives the mail, sees the user wants it piped through
procmail, sends it to procmail, which sees you want it piped through
spamassassin then delived to your inbox *if* it doesn't match the Spam
header line, added by spamassassin if it thinks it is spam.

Rob

On Sat, 2003-10-11 at 18:18, Kenneth G. Stephens wrote:

> Where is procmail configured to put it through spamassassin.

I have my procmailrc call it derectly-

<snip>
:0H
* ^From:.*DirectDaily.com
/dev/null/

# this runs spamassassin on anything not already killed above
:0fw
| /usr/bin/spamc -f
:0
* ^X-Spam-Status: Yes
/var/spool/mail/sa-caught/

When I'm feeling like I like the setup, I switch the sa-caught line to
/dev/null/

I've also played around with individual .procmailrc files, but decided
that sp_am was sp_am, and that nobody really needs it. I have 30 to 40
domains that I toss like the one mentioned above.

From clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com  Sat Oct 11 21:16:02 2003
From: clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com (Evan Heidtmann)
Date: Sat Oct 11 21:16:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] CGI scripting...
In-Reply-To: <1065918406.7225.2.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1065918406.7225.2.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <3F88D53F.7050609@adnap.no-ip.com>

I'm probably not at all qualified to be giving advice, but here goes...

I also apologize for any misestimations of prior knowledge.

Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> I've been looking into this to create a simple radio button for
> recording that a host's Internet access needs to be enabled...
> 
> Is there standard CGI script collection under Redhat 7.3?

Not that I know of, but there are many such collections scattered around 
the web.

> When a form tag is used is that just calling up a normal program
> or does it display a web page inside a web page or what's the idea?

Putting a form tag in an html document only makes the browser display 
the form widgets.  When the user presses the submit button, the data in 
the forum is sent to the cgi program identified in the <form> tag in the 
fashion identified in the <form> tag.

The data is passed either as an HTTP GET or POST.  In a GET, the data 
appears in the url.  In a POST, it does not.  The following section of 
the 'Writing HTML' tutorial did a pretty good job teaching me the basics 
of forms:

http://www.mcli.dist.maricopa.edu/tut/tut28.html

And this is a general overview of CGI:

http://hoohoo.ncsa.uiuc.edu/cgi/

If you write your CGI programs in Perl, make sure to:

use CGI qw(param);

Evan Heidtmann

Michael,

If you put your form fields in a <form></form> tag it will work. Also,
it'll be good to add the document type "<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC...", the
character encoding and it will also help to properly start and end
<p></p> tags.

You can check your html page upon sanity here: http://validator.w3.org/.
It will point you to a few more markup errors in the sources of this
page.

Holger

From holger at selover.net  Sun Oct 12 09:20:03 2003
From: holger at selover.net (Holger Stephan)
Date: Sun Oct 12 09:20:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Writing a CGI scipt.
In-Reply-To: <1065946111.17976.9.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1065946111.17976.9.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1065975565.12687.46.camel@halo>

Michael,

There are some corrections you can do to your script and w3.org
validator will list them all. I.e. all tag attributes (WHITE, PURPLE,
POST, ...) are to be quoted, the document type comes before the <html>
and stuff. The validator may not point this out, but it is good to get
ready for proper XHTML markup and close a body less tag with /: <img
..../>.

Do you plan to use your script to change the configuration of the
machine it runs on? Note that the HTTP server (i.e. Apache) is normally
run using a user account that won't allow editing or maybe even reading
the system configuration files. Last year we developed a HTML based
system configuration for a Linux network appliance and had to jump
through some hoops to get it to work. We used Boa as HTTP server, C++
CGI scripts and called a setuid'd C program which would broker the
system changes. 

I don't quite understand your other questions. Do you want to reflect
the current values in your form? In that case you'd have to set them in
your script. 

Holger

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sun Oct 12 10:22:01 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sun Oct 12 10:22:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] marking spam from your MUA
Message-ID: <20031012172047.GA14652@gate.kl-ic.com>

I use bogofilter with procmail and mutt, and use the following addition
to my .muttrc file to mark spam.  Perhaps you spamassassin folks can
use something like it:

excerpt from $HOME/.muttrc :
---------------------------------------------------------------------

#from Linux Journal "Busting Spam with Bogofilter, Procmail, and Mutt"
#by Nicky Moffitt Nov 11, 2002  (on the web)

macroindex s "<enter-command>unset wait_key\n<pipe-entry>bogofilter -N\n<enter-command>set wait_key\n<save-entry>"
macropager s "<enter-command>unset wait_key\n<pipe-entry>bogofilter -N\n<enter-command>set wait_key\n<save-entry>"

macroindex r "<enter-command>unset wait_key\n<pipe-entry>bogofilter -n\n<enter-command>set wait_key\n<reply>"
macropager r "<enter-command>unset wait_key\n<pipe-entry>bogofilter -n\n<enter-command>set wait_key\n<reply>"

macroindex g "<enter-command>unset wait_key\n<pipe-entry>bogofilter -n\n<enter-command>set wait_key\n<group-reply>"
macropager g "<enter-command>unset wait_key\n<pipe-entry>bogofilter -n\n<enter-command>set wait_key\n<group-reply>"

macroindex l "<enter-command>unset wait_key\n<pipe-entry>bogofilter -n\n<enter-command>set wait_key\n<list-reply>"
macropager l "<enter-command>unset wait_key\n<pipe-entry>bogofilter -n\n<enter-command>set wait_key\n<list-reply>"

macro index X "<enter-command>unset wait_key\n<pipe-entry>bogofilter -S\n<enter-command>set wait_key\n<save-message>=zzspam\ry" "save in spam folder"
macro pager X "<enter-command>unset wait_key\n<pipe-entry>bogofilter -S\n<enter-command>set wait_key\n<save-message>=zzspam\ry" "save in spam folder"
---------------------------------------------------------------------


$HOME/.procmail :
---------------------------------------------------------------------
i:0fw
| bogofilter -u -e -p -o 0.300
 
:0e
{ EXITCODE=75 HOST }
 
# file the mail to spam-bogofilter if it's spam.
:0:
* ^X-Bogosity: Yes, tests=bogofilter
Mail/zzspam
---------------------------------------------------------------------

Note that all of this occurs at the user level.

For you bogofilter fans, bogofilter shipped with a threshold of 0.900 .
After watching what it did for a few weeks, I tuned it down to 0.300 ,
since out of a few thousand messages only 11 real messages exceeded
a threshold of 0.2 and none exceeded 0.25 .  I now get about 400 spams
a day stored in zzspam, and about 10 make it through to disturb me.
My peace of mind is greatly improved.

Bogofilter is a Baysean text recognizer.  I like the ability to tune
it, but it is a one-trick pony and uses only the one algorithm. 
I would like to add additional programs to the pipe that recognize
such spam classics as random strings in the subject line, and
strange HTML in the body of the text, then a Baysean scoring engine
at the end of all the pipes.  I do not like the Spamassassin "all
in one" approach - it does not have Unix nature, and it is hard
to add third party modules to, if I understand it.  So for now,
I'll just use bogofilter and hope the world wises up.

Keith

--
KeithLofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC--- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
DesignContracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

> is having trouble talking to RAM.  Every power on I see a different
> quantity of detected RAM.  This is fresh, newly arrived DDR SDRAM from
> crucial.com, 512meg on a stick.
> 
> Now, that all seems to superficially point to the RAM being the
> problem.  Howver, I have tried removing one stick, trying different
> sockets, all permutations and have not seen an improvement.  What is
> the probability of getting two bad sticks at once?  Not large.
> Secondly, Intel's website says that my processor (actually, _any_
> processor isn't supported until BIOS P02).  So, how am I supposed to
> get said BIOS onto the box unless it will run long enough to load it?
> 
> Any ideas?  
> 

I'd be very surprised if the memory was bad.  If it doesn't run with the
speed turned down, there must be something fundamental wrong.  Are you
certain you've got the memory installed in the correct sockets?  Does
the board require memory to be installed in pairs?

If the board has a socketed flash device, and you are truly desperate,
it would be possible to update the BIOS using a standalone programmer.

galen

> The only thought I have is that maybe an email address I'd recognize 
> is resolving to these ones.

These may be bounce messages.  Those log entries only show the messages 
leaving your server.  See if you can find where those messages came 
from.  My guess is that you will find incoming spam messages from those 
addresses.  And errors were those messages couldn't be delivered and 
bounce messages were generated to the return addresses.

> If it came from me wouldn't relay be goose.robinson-west.com?
> How can I be relaying this message if that's what's going on
> considering I don't have these servers in my Postfix relay 
> domains?
> 

For mail going to aol.com, the relay is AOL's incoming mail server. 
mailin-04.mx.aol.com is one of those.

Isn't the ordinary bounce behavior of Postfix to send the content of
the original message in the bounce?  This is porno that s spammer fired
at me which could be being bounced to the wrong place for all I know.

A proprosal to fix this is to have postfix take a list of anyone it has
bounced to so that it will only bounce the same message once, unless
spamassassin can sink it.  The other change I want to do to Postfix is
modify how bouncing is done, I consider it entirely inappropriate to
bounce body and/or attachments since there's no gurantee the bounce 
will go where it should, bounce messages can clog up the Internet, 
and the sender if legit doesn't need what he/she has sent me anyways
to know it didn't get through.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sun Oct 12 12:13:01 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Sun Oct 12 12:13:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mbox to Maildir
In-Reply-To: <20031012172649.GB14652@gate.kl-ic.com>

>>>>> "Keith" == Keith Lofstrom <keithl at kl-ic.com> writes:

Keith> In order to improve the efficiency of my backups, I intend to
Keith> change how I store email.  Currently I am using venerable
Keith> mailbox/mbox to store email, and I plan to change over to
Keith> Maildir .  I plan to keep using mutt and sendmail/procmail
Keith> (which are Maildir compatable), and have no plans to convert to
Keith> qmail .  I've found tools that can convert the old, stored
Keith> mail.  The configuration change is apparently pretty simple.  I
Keith> think I know how to do this, but it is what I don't know that I
Keith> don't know that scares me.

Keith> Does anyone have any experience with Maildir, or with
Keith> converting to Maildir from mbox?  What stupid newbie mistakes
Keith> should I watch for?

Not keeping a copy of the mbox while you are figuring out if it is
working reliably?

Personally, I use qmail to deliver to a Maildir, then use (I know:
"how archaic") pop3 to retrieve the mail to a different host, where it
gets absorbed by Emacs/Gnus and put into nnml folders, which is also
one message per file, sort of like a newsgroup spool with a .overview
index and all (nnml even uses hardlinks to connect "crossposted"
messages like a news spool).  It's been configured like this for the
better part of 8 years, it works for me, I haven't given it a lot of
thought recently, FWIW.  It'd be nice to cut out the pop3 part, and it
looks (from a brief review) like Gnus has support for retrieving
directly from remote maildirs now.

Another thought here is that if you are keeping *lots* and *lots* of
email, make sure your filesystem has enough inodes (df -i).  Reiserfs
might be a good choice on that score (or it might be overkill).

From mikedela at theplatinumrule.com  Sun Oct 12 14:10:03 2003
From: mikedela at theplatinumrule.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Sun Oct 12 14:10:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] booting weirdness RESOLVED
In-Reply-To: <1065544311.27450.631.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
References: <1065491870.1093.4.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
	<1065508511.27446.76.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
	<1065511223.1063.3.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com> 
	<1065544311.27450.631.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <1065992985.9709.14.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>

Sorry all, I got lost in the thread, and I didn't want to incorrectly
attrib an idea, so there's no quote for me to bottom post. Top posting,
when mixed in with bottom posting /is/ confusing.

Somebody said that booting to a label was okay. It was okay, until I
installed another drive with the same labels. Not being aware of this, I
went ahead and reconfigured grub to boot to the correct device and
partition. AFTER booting to the right kernel, I was able to change the
labels of the old drive and restore sanity and the data I wanted from
the old drive.

The working gurb config now looks like this, as it could for lots of
folks: (I left the label oriented version of the old kernel below for
comparison, and so I didn't screw myself when I got the config wrong)
Also note that there's a sym link between /boot/vmlinuz and
/boot/vmlinuz version 2.4.20-20.8

/boot/grub.conf

title Red Hat Linux (2.4.20-20.8) Mike's
        root (hd0,0)
        kernel /vmlinuz ro root=/dev/hda2
        initrd /initrd-2.4.20-20.8.img
title Red Hat Linux (2.4.20-20.8)
        root (hd0,0)
        kernel /vmlinuz-2.4.20-20.8 ro root=LABEL=/
        initrd /initrd-2.4.20-20.8.img

Hope that can help someone in the future, it was driving me nuts.

-- 
Mike De La Mater
Small Business Networks and Consulting
503-702-6749
mikedela at ipns.com

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Sun Oct 12 15:18:02 2003

On Sun, 2003-10-12 at 15:02, Brent Rieck wrote:

> That's an excellent price for a tiny notebook I think.   Do you (or 
> anybody else listening in) have any experience with the Crusoe 
> processor?  Is it really "as good" as an Intel or AMD in terms of 
> performance?

I don't have any personal experience with the Crusoe processors... but
have read up on them (and most other x86 CPUs) at every opportunity I
get.

I remember when Transmeta announced the fruits of their labor after so
many years of no substantial information getting out.

Anyway - the CPUs are amazing when it comes to power consumption.  They
are, however, slower than just about anything you can buy today, in
actual performance.  If you think you'll do a lot of compiling, any 3D
gaming, or other CPU-intensive tasks on it, go with an Intel or AMD.  If
you'll not be doing very much of that stuff, it'll work great for you,
at a great amount of battery life savings.  Get a faster hard drive and
you'll get a bigger boost in day-to-day application speeds.

Rob

You know... all the info I have on them is with Windows.

My understanding of the Transmeta processors is they are essentially non
x86 CPUs emulating x86 instruction sets.  That's where the performance
drain comes from.

So, perhaps, with Linux's multi-architecture setup, the case is a little
bit different for Linux than for Windows?

Although I don't think you'll be able to achieve the performance level
you'll get with a nice Intel or AMD chip.  If you want the laptop to
last, I'd maybe see if I could find one of the Athlon64-based models
that are just now entering the market.  If you went with one of those,
new software will start to run faster on it than on a 32-bit chip
instead of newer software running slower than older software... as
things get ported to x86-64.

Rob

To run spamassassin on a per user basis, you would edit ~/.procmail. If you wish to send all inbound mail on that server through spamassassin, edit /etc/procmail. 

This is outlined in the spamassassin docs.

From info at pasa.portland.or.us  Sun Oct 12 18:40:02 2003
From: info at pasa.portland.or.us (Wil Cooley)

Subject: [PLUG] ANNOUNCEMENT: PASA Meeting 21 Oct 2003

PASA Meeting 21 Oct 2003
========================

PASA, the Portland Area Sys Admins, invites you to our next meeting to 
be held on Tuesday, the 21st of October 2003 with Matrix Networks.
Please visit our meetings page at and RSVP so we can have an estimate of
attendance.  The RSVP is NOT mandatory, but appreciated!
See our meetings page for more information and RSVP:
http://pasa.portland.or.us/meetings

Schedule
=========

7:00 - 7:30 Pizza / Welcome / Introductions
7:30 - 8:00 Nigel Ballard - Director of Wireless. Discusses Wi-Fi for
	    corporate users,convenience over security worries.
8:00 - 8:30 Mark Bilton-Smith - IP Telephony Sales. Discusses the 
	    benefits of migrating existing systems or installing new systems
            using a wholly IP-based phone solution.
8:30 - 10:00 Networking, discussion over beer. Location TBD.
About Matrix Networks
=====================

Matrix Networks has been serving Portland's voice and data needs for
thelast twenty years. Within the last two years Matrix has had a shift
of emphasis as the market has moved. New directions involve installing
pointto point wireless links thus circumventing lengthy and costly fiber
orcopper runs between buildings. Matrix has also been providing Wi-Fi
solutions for enterprises, hotels and marinas and more recently
IP-basedphone solutions have provided a new and exciting focus for the
staff at Matrix


About PASA 
==========

PASA is an informal support group for Portland Area Systems
Administrators. We currently have members from the east and west sides,
Vancouver, and Portland proper. Members are UNIX, NT, NetWare, and Network
administrators -- sometimes a combination of the four. Someday we may
get around to building some structure into the group, but that hasn't
happened yet. (Of course, there are no membership dues either.)

We are also an official USENIX SAGE local group.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sun Oct 12 19:03:02 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sun Oct 12 19:03:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Buying a laptop
Message-ID: <20031013020153.GB26195@gate.kl-ic.com>

When considering a laptop purchase, keep in mind that you are buying
a lot of high power technology in a small, mobile box.  Laptops are
very easy to *break*, which means rapid repair is a must.  I have had
very bad luck with Dell (3 month repair turnaround), and very good
luck with IBM (1.7 day repair turnaround).  A local dealer that does
3y warranty on-site swap repairs would be ideal;  are there any?  
Consider long-term support if you buy Brand X.  I've seen plenty of
orphan laptops that are unrepairable.

I run a 1.8GHz Pentium IBM T30.  These are now $1250/2GHz, under
warranty, from IBM on ebay.  5 pound largish, barely fits on an
airplane tray table.  The built-in Winmodem doesn't work with an
unmodified distro (and who wants a lightning pickup going straight
into the laptop anyway, PCMCIA modems are cheap and expendable). 
Note: T30's are real common at among Redhat employees.  The new T40
is fewer GHz, for some reason. 

You probably won't get good performance in something small.  I 
sometimes run multi-day CAD runs or numerical computations.  I've
been tempted to go to one of the 3GHz boat anchors.  I've also been
tempted to spend real money on a faster compiler than GCC.

IBM only ships with Windoze(ptooey) so I ordered with small drives,
and replaced them with 40GB drives on arrival (BTW, the virgin W*
drives are available for massive DMCA infringement).  Hitachi is
selling 80GB Travelstars now.

I really like the Ultrabay peripheral slot (CD-R or Floppy or 2nd
drive slot).  Laptops from a number of manufacturers use some version
of the Ultrabay.  The second drive tray is real handy for on-the-road
backups (drop to single user, dd if=/dev/hda of=/dev/hdc ), and you
will find it useful for moving data from your old laptop.

Get a DVD/CDR drive;  you may not need to write DVDs, but writing
600MB CDs on the road is really handy (floppies are starting to go
away at some client sites, and an ISO CD is readable on most platforms).
Make Knoppix disks at PLUG meetings!  I have 4X write (no rewrite),
and I probably should have gotten much faster.

Built-in WIFI;  probably not fully Linux compatable.  My wife has
a Cisco Aironet on her T30, which works but has closed-source drivers.
I prefer a Senao PCMCIA, using the PRISM chipset with external antenna.
PRISM is best right now, but it looks like Atheros chipset will soon
overtake it in Linuxland.  Many other chipsets do not have Linux drivers.

Inexpensive memory can be had from www.kahlon.com . You Will Need More.

Spare chargers can be handy.  Wait for a sale and order a bunch,
leave them all over.  Price spare chargers and batteries when you
compare laptop prices.

My, I do ramble on.  Main message:  repairability first, compatability
second, performance third.  A fast computer does you know good if it
is in the repair shop or not booting correctly.

Keith

Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993

Mike De La Mater wrote:

>I'm running spamassassin in the daemon mode, via spamc and spamd. Are you telling 
>me that both /etc/rpocmailrc and ~/.procmailrc are run against incoming mail? If 
>that's the case, I could bloak spammers globally and run spamassassin on a per-
>user basis.
>
>Is that the benefit to using the .procmailrc?
>

I'm running it via spamc/spamd as well. I run it system wide, so it's 
called via procmail in /etc/procmailrc.

You'd want to do one or the other. I block much spam via RBLs and then 
let spamassassin sort it out if it doesn't get rejected outright. :)

/etc/procmailrc is run against every email.

~/.procmailrc is run against all mail for that user.

Russ

From ian at znark.com  Sun Oct 12 19:25:03 2003
From: ian at znark.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Sun Oct 12 19:25:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Weird log in my maillog...
In-Reply-To: <1065985615.26213.8.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1065950564.18318.41.camel@goose.robinson-west.com> 	<3F899673.3000103@znark.com> <1065985615.26213.8.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <3F8A0CCA.6090703@znark.com>

Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> 
> Isn't the ordinary bounce behavior of Postfix to send the content of
> the original message in the bounce?  This is porno that s spammer fired
> at me which could be being bounced to the wrong place for all I know.
> 
> A proprosal to fix this is to have postfix take a list of anyone it has
> bounced to so that it will only bounce the same message once, unless
> spamassassin can sink it.  The other change I want to do to Postfix is
> modify how bouncing is done, I consider it entirely inappropriate to
> bounce body and/or attachments since there's no gurantee the bounce 
> will go where it should, bounce messages can clog up the Internet, 
> and the sender if legit doesn't need what he/she has sent me anyways
> to know it didn't get through.
> 

The bounce_size_limit controls how much of the undelivered message is 
included in the bounce message.  This could be set to zero to not return 
any of the message.  I think it just counts body content; if it includes 
  headers in the limit, then setting it to 1000 gives enough size to 
include the header.  Lots of bounces I have gotten recently don't 
include the message to limit the spread of

Also, there is an option to send unknown user bounces somewhere else. 
There are also options to control if bounces are also sent to the 
postmaster address.

  - Ian

ian at znark.com
http://www.znark.com/

If you want to look at Thinkpads, there are good deals on their Ebay store, 
http://www.stores.ebay.com/ibmauthorizedauctions. They sell several different 
models. Some are "buy it now", some are auctioned. They are brand-new with 
full warranty & manuals. What you have to be careful of are the built-in 
modems, and built-in wireless NICs. IBM, the Great Friend of Linux, doesn't 
seem to care about Linux compatibility on their notebooks. I've purchased 
several Thinkpads for customers from them, you can get good deals. Sometimes 
good enough to warrant spending $60 on a PCMCIA modem if you need one.

The Emperor Linux site has a nice chart of notebooks that support Linux well. 
Certain models of the Sony Vaio are completely supported, and I have some 
clients who use Vaios with Linux. Works just fine, even modems.

Michael,

  First thing to do is fix the above. All you need to do is
	cp /etc/services /var/spool/postfix/etc/
and you'll synchronize the files.

  I see domains in my pflogsumm report that I believe are rejected when they
try to relay through here. There's a lot of traffic that tries to use our
networks to pass on messages.

  Of course, when I see a domain name I know is that of a spammer I add it
to /etc/postfix/badaddr.

From ian at znark.com  Sun Oct 12 22:39:02 2003

Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> 
> Everything in it is illegit and looks like trash trying to
> bounce.  Is there a way for me to suspend the queue to
> purge, delete, all queued deferrals and bounces?
>  
> I'm trying reject_invalid_hostname and reject_unknown_hostname
> now.
> 
> There shouldn't be anyone sending me email that doesn't have a 
> public A or MX record to look them up at even though hardly 
> anyone runs a PTR zone anymore.
> 

Check why the trash are is being bounced.  Some of the spam checks like 
reject_invalid_hostname and reject_unknown_hostname will reject email 
before it is even accepted by your SMTP server.  The bounces must be 
getting through those.  Spamassassin can be setup to save the spam in a 
trap or throw it away without any bounces.  Postfix can be setup to 
reject email to non-existant addresses before it is accepted which means 
no bounce messages.

  - Ian

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sun Oct 12 23:44:01 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Sun Oct 12 23:44:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] New kernel won't boot
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310122148250.19370@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310121843080.18823@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<86y8vpga0u.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.56.0310122148250.19370@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <86llrpab8m.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Rich> On Sun, 12 Oct 2003, Russell Senior wrote:
>> What is wrong with "make install"?

Rich>   The kernel-HOWTO recommends against it.

But fails to say why.  BTW, who _is_ Alavoor Vasudevan?  

"make install" works fine for me and presumably millions of others
around the world.  It is in the kernel README file.  "make install"
invokes[1] /sbin/installkernel, which your distribution probably
provides to do the right thing.  /sbin/installkernel (at least on my
boxes) not only copies the kernel to the right place, but also puts a
config-<version> and System.map-<version> in /boot, adjusts symbolic
links so that /boot/vmlinuz points at the most recently "installed"
kernel (and System.map and config likewise), and /boot/vmlinuz-old to
the next most recently installed, etc.  You still probably need to
adjust /boot/grub/menu.lst (or /etc/lilo.conf) yourself.

[1] a) the top-level Makefile includes arch/$(ARCH)/Makefile

    b) arch/i386/Makefile includes the "install" target to call,
       effectively:
  
         make -C arch/$(ARCH)/boot BOOTIMAGE=bzImage install

       which, effectively calls "make" as if from arch/$(ARCH)/boot.

    c) arch/i386/boot/Makefile's "install" target calls
       arch/i386/boot/install.sh with various arguments.

    d) arch/i386/boot/install.sh checks for, in order: 
 
         i) a user-specific script: ~/bin/installkernel; or

         ii) a system-wide script: /sbin/installkernel; 
   
       found, they are exec'd.  If neither is found, it moves existing
       $(INSTALL_PATH)/vmlinuz and $(INSTALL_PATH)/System.map aside
       (to foo.old) and copies the new ones into $(INSTALL_PATH)

Note also, the build system has been revamped a bit for 2.6.  Check
the README for details.

--

seniorr at aracnet.com      mrlosh''  -- Bashgali Kafir for ``If you have
                         had diarrhoea many days you will surely die.''

Details of second case follow:

An oldish ASUS P2L97-DS motherboard, for dual-processor slot-1
pentium-II's is giving me trouble flashing the most recent BIOS I can
find.  ASUS's website says it is version 1008 from 02/12/1999.  There
is also an older version 1005 available.  The AFLASH.EXE utility they
provide to flash the BIOS gives me a "data compare failure" when
trying to flash either one of these (BB instead of FF at byte 1, or
vice versa).  Luckily, following the directions, I saved the
originally installed BIOS and can reflash it successfully.  So, I am
stuck on version 0106.

There doesn't seem to be a jumper to enable BIOS changes.  I read
somewhere random online that this kind of failure might indicate the
BIOS chip is failing, the suggestion being to use a stand-alone BIOS
programmer on a different BIOS chip.  The AFLASH program tells me the
chip is an ATMEL AT29C020A (or is that AT29C0Z0A?  I can't read my own
writing!).  The motherboard manual tells me it is a "Programmable
2Mbit Flash ROM".  So, heh-heh, anyone got one of these BIOS
programmers?

The reason I am bothering is that I just installed 2 purported-to-be
PII-400 CPUs in place of the single PII-300 that was there before, and
the POST messages and /proc/cpuinfo is telling me they are only
running at 266 MHz.  The jumpers are configured to run faster than
that (e.g. 66MHz bus, 11/2 clock multiplier should be 366MHz or so).
Figured on sync'ing up to most recent BIOS before playing more.
No-can-flash, so I'm stymied.

Since just about every message I get that has html formatting and centered
text is junk mail, I want to create a procmail filter to catch these.  
However, I'm having trouble with the action to detect the tag <center> in
message bodies. This doesn't do it:

:0 B:
* "<center>"
$MAILDIR/SPAM

nor this:
:0 B:
* <center>
$MAILDIR/SPAM

and this doesn't catch the brackets as it just finds the word "center":
:0 B:
* \<center\>
$MAILDIR/SPAM

So how do I catch html tags that are likely to indicate evil mail?

Also, what do you do about UCE that comes in as base64 encoded format? Is 
there a way to unencode these before testing them against procmail 
filters?

  Thanks very much, Paul.

  I've looked some more and decided that I'll go with the Sony Vaio
PCG-v505b from Emperor Linux. Yes, I'll pay about $100 more than buying it
from another vendor, but then I don't have to remove the winduhs and get
linux running. They'll put on Slackware-9.1 partitioned as I request. That
time saving -- and knowing that _all_ the features work -- is worth the cost
difference to me.

  Emperor Linux also has the IBM T30 and T40 boxes. It's interesting how the
higher number is a much lower CPU (1300-1400MHz compared with 2400MHz). And,
the prices are higher, the box is larger and it is heavier than the Sony.
The Sony's battery life (according to specs on the Web) is 3.5 hours. If
that's with winduhs then my experience with the Toshibas is that I'll get
much longer life running linux. I'll ask the vendor.

  I do notice, too, that Emperor charges a _lot_ more for memory upgrades
and other accessories than do many other sources. I can buy an additional
256M of RAM for $64 elsewhere while Emperor wants $150 for it. Cough! Same
with replacement batteries and an extra AC adapter (one for the office, one
stays in the computer bag).

  In the almost-4.5 years I've used my Portege all over the U.S., I've not
dropped it or needed to have either the external floppy drive or the
external cd-rom drive with me. When I've used the machine for presentations
I bring along the port duplicator; otherwise it stays home. It's a dynamite
machine for writing, connecting back to the office network, presentations,
light development and other such things. Now, however, I'll need to run
spatial and approximate reasoning models on the road and the dear, sweet
thing is just not up to the task -- not, at least, if I want to be done in a
reasonable time. :-)

  I remember my first laptop from 1992: a Gateway (built for them by Texas
Instruments), with a 486DX-2/100 CPU running DOS. It weighed 7+ pounds and I
really felt that when I carried it through airports and around trade shows,
conventions and meetings all day. Ugh! Also, the AC adapter port was pooly
designed and kept breaking at 13 months -- with a 12 month warranty. That
put me off Gateway for good. So, I like light machines to carry along with
project files, reference materials and whatever else I can stuff in the
computer bag.

> 
> Any clues would be greatly appreciated!
> 

The native capacity of DDS2 tapes is 4 GB.  If you are using tar to compress
the data, or if you don't have compression enabled on the drive, you are
hitting the end of the tape.

galen
