Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com> wrote:

> An oldish ASUS P2L97-DS motherboard, for dual-processor slot-1
> pentium-II's is giving me trouble flashing the most recent BIOS I can
> find.  ASUS's website says it is version 1008 from 02/12/1999.  There
> is also an older version 1005 available.  The AFLASH.EXE utility they
> provide to flash the BIOS gives me a "data compare failure" when
> trying to flash either one of these (BB instead of FF at byte 1, or
> vice versa).  Luckily, following the directions, I saved the
> originally installed BIOS and can reflash it successfully.  So, I am
> stuck on version 0106.

It's possible that the part isn't being erased.  When a flash device is
erased, the contents are set to FF.  If it is reading BB instead of FF,
I think the old bios didn't get erased.

> 
> There doesn't seem to be a jumper to enable BIOS changes.  I read
> somewhere random online that this kind of failure might indicate the
> BIOS chip is failing, the suggestion being to use a stand-alone BIOS
> programmer on a different BIOS chip.  The AFLASH program tells me the
> chip is an ATMEL AT29C020A (or is that AT29C0Z0A?  I can't read my own
> writing!).  The motherboard manual tells me it is a "Programmable
> 2Mbit Flash ROM".  So, heh-heh, anyone got one of these BIOS
> programmers?

A quick google search shows people using the asus pflash2 utility to flash
the bios.  Of course, this may have been superseded by aflash.  To
answer your question, yes, I have access to a programmer which should
handle that device.

galen

Never mind... I found the answer to:

> So how do I catch html tags that are likely to indicate evil mail?

at Timo's procmail tips and recipes:
http://www.uwasa.fi/~ts/info/proctips.html#lessthan

The answer is to wrap the less than character in parentheses, like so in 
this procmail recipie:

:0 B:
* (<)center>
$MAILDIR/SPAM

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Mon Oct 13 10:24:01 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Mon Oct 13 10:24:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Testing alpha version of logrotate
Message-ID: <20031013172255.GB3288@gate.kl-ic.com>

I could use some volunteer testing help so we can unfork some code:

logrotate (/usr/sbin/logrotate on RH9) is the program (launched by
cron at night) that trims and moves logfiles in /var/log .  logrotate
does things like move /var/log/messages to /var/log/messages.1 and
discarding /var/log/messages.9 .

I am using some new backup methods that are more efficient if files
are not being renamed all the time.  The Suse version of logrotate has
an option,  "dateext", which appends YYMMDD to the log files rather
than renumber them every night, so the log files get only one renaming.

I am lobbying Elliot Lee at Redhat (sopwith at redhat.com) to patch
this useful feature into the main branch of logrotate development.  
Meanwhile, Ruediger Oertel at Suse (ro at suse.de) has generated a patch
on the latest rawhide/Severn release:

> updated patches for 3.6.10 should be done now,
> a src-rpm will appear at ftp.suse.com/pub/people/ro/logrotate
> as soon as the sync to the outside is done. I've got that
> version running on my machine now, but it's basically untested ATM.

This should be decent code - both branches of logrotate development are
pretty stable.  However, there is nothing like a good test in multiple
environments.   Who's up for a bit of alpha testing?


To get the file, download the file  "logrotate-3.6.10-0.src.rpm" from
Suse, and (as root) do:  "rpm -ivh logrotate-3.6.10-0.src.rpm"

Under Redhat, this will create /usr/src/redhat/SPECS/logrotate.spec .
This is a Suse spec file, I have to diddle it a bit for Redhat.  Edit
the file, and remove line 27:  "PreReq:  %fillup_prereq /bin/rm /bin/mv"
which Redhat rpmbuild doesn't like.  

Now do:  "rpmbuild -bp logrotate.spec" This puts a source directory
in /usr/src/redhat/BUILD/logrotate-3.6.10 .  You are ready to compile
and install in that directory, but first you probably want to save a
copy of your original logrotate and man page.  Do something like: 
   cp  /usr/sbin/logrotate  /usr/sbin/logrotate.orig
   cp  /usr/share/man/man8/logrotate.8 /usr/share/man/man8/logrotate.8.orig

Go to /usr/src/redhat/BUILD/logrotate-3.6.10, and do a "make" and a
"make install".   You now have a new version of logrotate, with the 
extra features.  You also have the sources, so you can check for nasties.

The testing consists of using the new logrotate with your existing config
files ( /etc/logrotate.conf and /etc/logrotate.d/* on redhat) unchanged.
There should be no changes in behavior.  Scream at me, or ro at suse.de , if
you see problems.  Later, you redhat folk can modify the config files to
make use of the dateext capabilities.  

Keith

Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Mon Oct 13 13:01:01 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Mon Oct 13 13:01:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] New kernel won't boot
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310130859570.6346@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310121843080.18823@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<86y8vpga0u.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.56.0310130859570.6346@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <86ismsrjpz.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Rich>   From /usr/local/src/linux-2.4.22/ I ran 'make install'. When
Rich> it finished I saw nothing different in /boot. I still have the
Rich> same problem. What step have I missed here? Do I remove the new
Rich> kernel, config and System.map from /boot and re-run 'make
Rich> install'?

Just to sanity check, is there space on the partition?

Also, do you have an /sbin/installkernel?  If so, it is worth a look
to see what it does.

If you've got space and /sbin/installkernel, then:

 a)  save your .config (just to be safe)

     $ cd /usr/local/src/linux-2.4.22
     $ mv .config ../config-2.4.22

 b)  clean the source tree

     $ make mrproper

     or to be _really_ sure:

     $ pushd .. ; rm -rf linux-2.4.22 ; tar xjvf linux-2.4.22.tar.bz2 ; pushd

 c)  restore the .config

     $ mv ../config-2.4.22 .config

     note that once you've been using "make install", you'll have a
     variety of previous config files in your /boot

 d)  configure using old .config

     $ make oldconfig

 e)  here's how I build kernels, there are variations, but this works
     for me:

     $ make dep ; make ; make modules ; su -c 'make install ; make modules_install'
     You compile as a regular user, install as root.  When you get to
     the "su" bit above, you'll be prompted for the root password.

 f)  assuming GRUB, as root edit /boot/grub/menu.lst with editor of
     your choice, then reboot.  My menu.lst entries look like:

     default saved
     timeout 5

     title   GNU/Linux (2.4.22)
     root    (hd0,0)
     kernel  /boot/vmlinuz-2.4.22 root=/dev/hda1
     savedefault

     [...]

Why don't you try that and report back if/where things seem to go wrong.

Subject: [PLUG] Linux-friendly notebook
In-Reply-To: <200310122103.54871.carla@bratgrrl.com>

On Sun, 12 Oct 2003, Carla Schroder wrote:
[...]
> What you have to be careful of are the built-in modems, and built-in
> wireless NICs. IBM, the Great Friend of Linux, doesn't seem to care
> about Linux compatibility on their notebooks.

It varies with the type and model.  Like many laptops, the T series have
1-2 MiniPCI sockets (they resemble laptop memory SODIMMs) that are filled
with various models of ethernet, modem and wireless cards as needed.
Some are Linux-compatible, some not.

At my last job, I swapped in 3Com ethernet+modem MiniPCI cards for the
Lucent WinModems that came with the company's T21s.  Ironically, the old
modem worked with Linux, but the new one wouldn't.  The ethernet worked,
though, which was the important bit.

> The Emperor Linux site has a nice chart of notebooks that support Linux well.
> Certain models of the Sony Vaio are completely supported, and I have some
> clients who use Vaios with Linux. Works just fine, even modems.

Linus has a Vaio.  ;)

	<86ismsrjpz.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

Message-ID: <86ekxgpz7o.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Rich>   In process. As a user I apparently don't have sufficient
Rich> rights in /usr/local/src/linux-2.4.22 to run make without
Rich> generating errors. So, I'm doing it all as root.

Before unpacking the tarball, do something like this:

  $ su -c 'chown rshepard.user /usr/local/src'

Or just compile it in your home directory tree.  There is nothing
magical about /usr/local/src or /usr/src.

Rich>   No /sbin/installkernel on this system.

Hmm.  Try this one:

  <http://www.aracnet.com/~seniorr/installkernel>

It is swiped from the debianutils, but isn't really debian specific in
any noticable way.  I have commented out the final "mkboot -i", which
if you are using grub is pretty much a no-op.  I think you can put it
in either /root/bin or /sbin.  If your distribution acquires its own
installkernel in the future, it'll be put in /sbin.  However one in
/root/bin will pre-empt one in /sbin.  Just something to be aware of.

> >>>>> "Russell" == Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com> writes:
> 
> Russell> Technically, on this motherboard the chipset is only rated at
> Russell> 66 MHz, however, there are jumper settings for 68, 75, 83 and
> Russell> 100 MHz.
> 
> Derek> So, did it boot when set to 100MHz?
> 
> Russell> No.  But I haven't been very far down that road.
> 
> Update: I had momentary success at 83 MHz, but after the first time, I

> me back to 300 MHz, which is an adequate improvement for me, from a
> single 300 MHz CPU to a dual 300MHz.  I compiled a new kernel just to
> stress things a little, but no failures or smoke alarms so far.

That means that the PCI (and AGP) bus is overclocked too.  Some video
cards can handle it better than others.  Other PCI cards might have
problems too.  Does the BIOS have a setting for the clock ratios?  If
you can get the PCI bus speed down, it might boot on the higher bus
speeds.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

modprobe yenta_socket
modprobe pcmcia_core

Make sure cardmgr is picking up the proper card ID in /etc/pcmcia/

>   I think the quickest thing to do is a complete re-install. I've no idea
> what I've done and I'm not sufficiently well versed to know how to fix it

Maybe reinstall the kernel, modules, and pcmcia (cardmanager? - dunno
what it's called) packages and see if you get somewhere?

>   Sigh. Well, if I'm going to screw up an kernel build I'm not going to do
> it half-way. Nope, not this guy. Total catastrophy; nothing less will do.

Well, at least you won't be accused of being a quitter at such things
(breaking the system, I mean)  :-)

>   Lowers head, hooks up floppy drive, pulls out Slackware-8.1 boot floppies
> (because the pcmcia driver with 9.0 won't recognize the cards in the system
> ... but I can try making 9.1 boot floppies.) Nuts. There goes this evening.

I don't know if it'll work with a PCMCIA CD-ROM drive, but it is surely
worth a try - try the sbootmgr disk under the isolinux directory of
$FAVORITE_MIRROR/pub/linux/slackware/slackware-9.0/

>   I'm off for dinner -- I need to get away from this for a while. If there's
> a less drastic solution, I'd sure like to learn what it is.

A full reinstall is definitely as drastic as you can get - just
reinstall the packages relating to the things that aren't working -
modules, PCMCIA, and the kernel, too, if you re-do the modules.

You'll get it back up and running, don't fear.  :-)

Have a good dinner, mine is just about done!

> I use Postfix, how can I check to make sure procmail is my local
> delivery agent?

jbrelin at loyale:/etc/postfix$ grep procmail *
main.cf:mailbox_command = procmail -a "$EXTENSION"

> Where is the documentation on spamassassin so that if a message I get
> over and over that I don't want shows up again I can program
> spamassassin so it can detect it next time?

Make sure you have a fairly recent version of Spamassassin and the
Bayesian filtering is there.  You just have to send it your spam with
sa-learn.

man sa-learn

Message-ID: <86ad83d95o.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Rich>   No, but I think it's time to quit trying to figure out what I
Rich> did wrong and start over. 

But unless you _do_ figure out what you did wrong, you might do it again.

Rich>   Well, that's the rub: this all started with a custom rebuild
Rich> of the 2.4.22 kernel; it was running the default 2.4.22 kernel
Rich> after the upgrade to 9.1.

Just for reference, a vanilla kernel install doesn't touch your /etc/
stuff.  "make modules_install" dumps stuff into /lib/modules/$(KERNELRELEASE).
Installing over a previous kernel/modules, even of the same version,
_shouldn't_ prevent the new one from working, but it might prevent the
previous one from working.  If you want to avoid the conflict, right
after unpacking the kernel source (or after a "make mrproper") edit
the toplevel Makefile, adding a unique "EXTRAVERSION" (see line 4).
Then compile as usual and the $KERNELRELEASE will be different,
modules will go into a separate tree, vmlinuz-<ver> will be different,
etc.

Subject: [PLUG] ICMP rule, etc., to allow nmap...
Message-ID: <1066162035.11113.37.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

I'm setting up apache on xerxes and am wondering why I can't nmap
it.  Maybe there's an icmp packet that's not being accepted, or
something that needs to be.  I had log denied packets turned on
in my firewall, but I disabled that, I see no reason to have a

help matters to have 65k lines of denied this or denied that
sent to the system log from attempting to nmap it.

I can connect to the apache server I've installed to it, though 
it seems to take a long time when I go to the 209.210.202.171 
address for the test page to come up.  I'm fairly sure it's
an icmp type packet not being accepted or something of that
nature.  I have to explicity accept every type of ICMP packet
needed because of a default DENY policy for the forward, input, 
and output chains.

For nmap of EXTERNAL_INTERFACE to work what do I have to change?
Maybe I can put rules in my firewall to only accept nmap 
probes from the other gateway.  I want to be able to 
nmap it to see what ports it has open as this is more
reliable than simply trying to go through all the config
scripts.



# ------------------------------------------------------------------
Here are what the variables are:
# ------------------------------------------------------------------
$EXTERNAL_INTERFACE is my Internet interface on xerxes.
CLASS_A="10.0.0.0/8"                    # Class A private networks
CLASS_B="172.16.0.0/12"                 # Class B private networks
CLASS_C="192.168.0.0/16"                # Class C private networks
CLASS_D_MULTICAST="224.0.0.0/4"         # Class D multicast addresses
CLASS_E_RESERVED_NET="240.0.0.0/5"      # Class E reserved addresses
BROADCAST_SRC="0.0.0.0"                 # Broadcast source address
BROADCAST_DEST="255.255.255.255"        # Broadcast destination address
PRIVPORTS="0:1023"                      
# Well known, privileged port range

UNPRIVPORTS="1024:65535"                # Unprivileged port range
# ------------------------------------------------------------------



# ------------------------------------------------------------------
Here's my current ICMP section...
# ------------------------------------------------------------------
   ipchains -A icmpi  -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p icmp  \
             --icmp-type echo-reply \
             -d $IPADDR -j ACCEPT 

    ipchains -A icmpi  -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p icmp  \
             --icmp-type destination-unreachable \
             -d $IPADDR -j ACCEPT 

    ipchains -A icmpi  -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p icmp  \
             --icmp-type source-quench \
             -d $IPADDR -j ACCEPT 

    ipchains -A icmpi  -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p icmp  \
             --icmp-type time-exceeded \
             -d $IPADDR -j ACCEPT 

    ipchains -A icmpi  -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p icmp  \
             --icmp-type parameter-problem \
             -d $IPADDR -j ACCEPT 


    ipchains -A icmpo -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p icmp  \
             -s $IPADDR fragmentation-needed -j ACCEPT 

    ipchains -A icmpo -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p icmp  \
             -s $IPADDR source-quench -j ACCEPT 
# ------------------------------------------------------------------
    ipchains -A icmpo -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p icmp  \
             -s $IPADDR echo-request -j ACCEPT 

    ipchains -A icmpo -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p icmp  \
             -s $IPADDR parameter-problem -j ACCEPT

    # Added because I see nothing wrong with letting
    # these out.

    ipchains -A icmpo  -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p icmp  \
             --icmp-type destination-unreachable \
             -s $IPADDR -j ACCEPT 
# ------------------------------------------------------------------



# ------------------------------------------------------------------
And here's my spoofing section...
# ------------------------------------------------------------------
 ipchains -A spoofi   -s $CLASS_A -j DENY
 ipchains -A spoofi   -s $CLASS_B -j DENY
 ipchains -A spoofi   -s $BROADCAST_DEST -j DENY -l
 ipchains -A spoofi   -d $BROADCAST_SRC -j DENY -l
 ipchains -A spoofi   -s $CLASS_D_MULTICAST -j DENY
 ipchains -A spoofi   -s $CLASS_E_RESERVED_NET -j DENY -l

 #  I don't want the outside network's dhcp requests...
 ipchains -A spoofi -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p udp -s 0/0 68 -j REJECT

 #  I don't want RIP packets from outside either...
 ipchains -A spoofi -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p udp -s 0/0 520 -j REJECT 

    ipchains -A spoofi   -s 0.0.0.0/8 -j DENY
    ipchains -A spoofi   -s 1.0.0.0/8 -j DENY -l
    ipchains -A spoofi   -s 2.0.0.0/8 -j DENY -l

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Oct 14 13:32:02 2003

From heinlein at madboa.com  Tue Oct 14 15:47:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue Oct 14 15:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Automatic file type in email
In-Reply-To: <4285.134.244.174.87.1066170609.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <4285.134.244.174.87.1066170609.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0310141533420.27843@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 14 Oct 2003, Josh Orchard wrote:

> I was just thinking of a way to automatically alter the file types
> sent across in email.  I get 2MB bmp files from some people and
> would perfer these in jpg or png format.  Any thoughts how I could
> set the email server to change the file types before they are
> delivered?

It's certainly possible -- but pretty invasive. You'd want to

a) set up mimedefang+sendmail, or some equivalent for your MTA, if
   it's not sendmail,

b) have mimedefang disassemble all inbound messages,

c) use the perl File::Type module to identify attachments you want to
   convert,

d) use the perl modules like Image::Magick (for images) and
   HTML::Strip (for HTML) to convert said attachments to saner
   equivalents,

e) have mimedefang reassemble inbound messages and pass them along to
   sendmail.

Or, I suppose, you could have procmail pipe the message to a Perl (or
whatever) script that accomplishes the tasks laid out in steps b
through e.

Like I said, it's invasive...

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

The intent of the Golden Rule is to create a world that makes you happy by
living as if that is already the way things are.  Some people think that
riding bicycles around on the street for any reason OR no reason at all is
the kind of world they'd like to see.  You can't tell someone else what
kind of world they should like.  (But you can hint... and heavily.)

Then, of course, the spammers will escalate, and you get this:
<cen<!--Ack Thp-->ter>

But in actual practice, the simple-minded filter works really well for the
little effort. I think that using (<)center> has taken out about 40 spams
a day for me. I can't get them all, and I think it's a Holy Grail Quest to
try, but any dumb filter that takes out 40%  of the junk is okay by me. 

- Bill Thoen

Paul Johnson replied:
> Do you keep archives of your mail?  If so, just go back through, find
> at least 200 spam and 200 ham, and start learnin!

You are right, this might be easier than finding some outside source
of spam/ham.  I have plenty of saved ham and spam, which I used when
I trained bogofilter.  I just don't know how to transform mbox text
into a stream of handshaked stuff that I can blow into SMTP port 25
on my firewall like it was coming from the net.  For the current job,
I could even launch the stuff inside the firewall at the mail server, 
but I would like to include the firewall in the tests.

So now the question is, are there any test tools that can turn a
mbox file (or a Maildir directory) into messages feeding port 25?

This isn't about training the tools, it is about seeing that all the
tools are working together correctly and that they respond correctly
to a burst of messages.  For this I need test generators.

* Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> [2003-10-14 17:03]:

> On Tue, 14 Oct 2003, Russ Johnson wrote:
> > I disagree. ANYONE going more than 10 miles under the speed limit when

> 
> Excuse me?  The speed limit is an UPPER BOUND, not a gauranteed rate of
> travel.

Explain that to the 10 tickets I've had for impeding traffic. Look it up
in ORS 811.130. I have been recently introduced to a case where an
appeals court affirmed that bicycles are not subject to the impeding
traffic statute. I happen to disagree with this ruling, but that's
neither here nor there. Impeding traffic is dangerous. It IS coded, and
it is the law. The court let the bicycling off on a technicality that
they use "motor vehicle" in that particular statute. Striking the word
"motor" from that section would do wonders. On top of that, he was
STANDING with his bike, not riding it at the time of the citation. I
would have argued that he was a pedestrian, and cited him for something
a little more applicable. 

> And what do you qualify as "not impeded by condition"?  I would say having
> a few hundred bicycles around you in traffic as a condition of impediment
> to high speed travel.  I know I wouldn't ride at full speed while
> surrounded by that many people.  It's just not safe.

No it's not, and the Critical Mass rides do everything in their power to
encourage that unsafeness. 

> > Those bicycles go 5 or 10 mph in a 20 - 25 mph zone. If they weren't
> > impeding traffic, it wouldn't be an issue, as they'd just move along
> > with the rest of the flow, as they should.
> 
> As a matter of fact, Critical Mass is usually outpacing traffic downtown.

That's not what I see from the third floor I work on. I've watched
several rides, and many of the people I see are riding in circles, going
back and forth among the riders, and there are litteraly hundreds of
cars backed up, belching exhaust up Broadway waiting for the slower
bicycles to get out of the way. 

> > They purposefully block ALL traffic lanes in one direction.
> 
> They ARE traffic, silly.  They can't be BLOCKING traffic.  They are moving
> vehicles on the roadway.  They have every right to use the road for that
> purpose.

Yes. They can block traffic... By going slower than necessary to arrive
at their destination. The purpose of a road is to travel (in whatever
vehicle) from point A to point B. The purpose of the CM rides is to
disrupt life. It's a statement, not a journey. 

> > They cut in and out of traffic and ride on the line between lanes and
> > between cars.
> 
> Lane changes and passing are legal.  And bicycles are an exception to the
> "one vehicle per lane" law.

So you are saying that bicycle can share the lane with my Explorer? I
realize they can ride several bikes abreast in a lane. I'm talking about
passing between cars that are in adjacent lanes. That's not legal, and
it's downright dangerous. 

> > I know, as I almost hit one that was riding next to me on 4th street. He
> > was next to me IN MY LANE!
> 
> Right... see above.  Bicycles are allowed to share the lane with motor
> traffic and other bicycles.

Not when it's a car and a bicycle IN THE SAME LANE. There's not room for
a car and a bicycle in the same lane. Show me law that states this is
so. 

> > If it's the people responsible for the spam hitting my mail server (74%
> > rejection rate yesterday!) more power to him.
> 
> That's exactly my point.  You're just spreading misery.

If I was actually doing this, I'd just be giving them back what they
give me. All's fair in love and war. Fighting spam is a war. 

> Is that what you want?  Do you want people to try to hurt other people?

Sending them spam and/or calling them at dinner isn't hurting them. If I
was advocating shooting them, then that would be hurting them. 

> That is the example you set.  That is the world you make.

Again, where is the difference? The CM rides are hurting others. They
are NOT folks just trying to get from A to B. They are folks trying to
make a statement, and causing a lot of grief and hard feelings in the process.

> > > bicycles (whether it's "nothing but" or otherwise), riding around on a
> > > bicycle is a VERY GOOD WAY of getting there.
> >
> > Yes, it is, to a point. However, when you stage a group event that blocks
> > streets, you are inconvienencing others. Exactly the type of thing you

Wrong. I know for a fact it's staged. The website even says it. The last
Friday of every month @ 5:30. Meet at Waterfront Park, under the
Burnside Bridge. 

> Second, convenience is one of the perceived evils that some Massers would
> like to see questioned.  So that's somewhat the reverse of your argument.

I don't see convenience as an evil. It's convenient for me to ride Max
to work, so I do. When it was convenient to drive, I did that. For some,
it's convenient to drive everywhere. For others, it's just as convenient
to bike everywhere. We do what is most convenient for each of us,
according to our values.

> Lastly, Rich is hoping to put people in exactly the position he himself
> does NOT want to be in.  This is the crux of my gripe.

No, Rich is simply dealing a little of what has landed in his lap back
to those who sent it to him.

> > It all depends on who's bull is being gored.
> 
> So you keep writing (though I still don't know what it means).

I can't believe that you've never heard that before. If you really
haven't I can explain it.

> > of "the golden rule".

> The intent of the Golden Rule is to create a world that makes you happy by

I don't see that at all. The intent of the "Golden Rule" is simply to
govern ones actions. Nothing more, nothing less. 

> And the purpose of Critical Mass is different for every rider.

Not according to this:

http://criticalmassrides.info/

"Critical Mass is a monthly bicycle ride to celebrate cycling and to

September 1992, and quickly spread to cities all over the world."

> Many riders are just along for the ride from downtown to a point near
> their home where they break off.  It's just part of the daily commute.

I get the feeling from the CM website that it's not that way.

> > folks riding the bikes know how the cars behind them feel.
> 
> The cars don't feel anything.  They're just hunks of belching metal.

No, but those cars have drivers, and they do feel frustration, among
other things. So now you are saying that CM rides can inflict upon the
drivers what you are admonishing Rich for. 

> However, I'll refer you to the above comment about cyclists moving MUCH
> faster than automobiles through city traffic nearly all the time.

Some do. And some should be cited for speeding.

> Also, you do not have a RIGHT to go as fast as your car is capable of

You don't even have a right to drive. I know that. But blocking traffic
is wrong, no matter the reason. 

> Sounds to me like you've got a bad case of the greeds.

Huh?

> > The really ironic part of this is the Critical Mass ride is responsible

Baseless? It's from several CM websites.

> only because cars pollute?  Use some imagination.

>From talking to several riders, I know that's exactly why they are out
there. Some of those folks are out there specifically to piss off as
many car drivers as possible. 

> I would rank pollution about number six in my "Reasons why nobody should
> drive a personal private automobile within a city limits".

And there are many reasons why we should. It's a trade off. Currently,
it's the best solution we have for many tasks. Get over it. 

> Oh, and way to redirect a comment on your antisocial view of punishment
> and pain-dealing into a slam on people doing nondestructive, positive
> things.

Let's see. Causing backed up traffic, forcing drivers of cars stuck in
traffic to use more of the finite resources we have. That's not
nondestructive or positive. 

Causing ill will with much of the rest of the population, once a month.
That's not positive either. 

You see, there's always at least three sides to an argument, and you
fail to see any side but your own. I acknowledge that bikes have a right
to use the road. I do not believe they should take over the road. 

That's it... Once a month. CM occupies the roads. Bush just took a page
from CM and occupied Iraq. The difference is, no one is shooting at the
bicyclists.

There is an online archive of spam:

  http://www.spamarchive.org/
  
I'm just coming into this conversation but if it's spam filter
testing you're after, one can simulate thousands of spam messages
(depending on the number in each file) going through your mail server
with formail:

cat [name of file] | formail -i "to: recipient at yourdomain.com" -s
/usr/sbin/sendmail recipient at yourdomain.com

Ahhh... good call.

Well, if you can get setup loaded from floppy disks, you can chose to

up everything else.  Slack's installation scripts are really pretty
flexible in that regard.

over... not entering setup at all... then reboot back to your system and
installpkg them.

On Tue, 14 Oct 2003, Russ Johnson wrote:
> I have been recently introduced to a case where an appeals court
> affirmed that bicycles are not subject to the impeding traffic statute.

The statute clearly states "motor vehicle" and not "vehicle", as you
noted.  Section 814 is very clear in stating that "vehicle" shall apply to
bicycles and the entire vehicular code applies to bicycles except where
the statue clearly cannot apply.

> The court let the bicycling off on a technicality that they use "motor
> vehicle" in that particular statute. Striking the word "motor" from that
> section would do wonders.

It wouldn't do anything about Critical Mass, of course.  The statute is as
follows:

(1) A person commits the offense of impeding traffic if the person drives
a motor vehicle or a combination of motor vehicles in a manner that
impedes or blocks the normal and reasonable movement of traffic.

Critical Mass comes about when a large group of cyclists take up the same
route on the road.  In that case, the cyclists ARE the normal and
reasonable movement of traffic.

But then there's this:

(2) A person is not in violation of the offense described under this
section if the person is proceeding in a manner needed for safe operation.

Operating in a large group of cyclists REQUIRES reduced speed for safety.

> * Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> [2003-10-14 17:03]:
> > And what do you qualify as "not impeded by condition"?  I would say having
> > a few hundred bicycles around you in traffic as a condition of impediment
> > to high speed travel.  I know I wouldn't ride at full speed while
> > surrounded by that many people.  It's just not safe.
>
> No it's not, and the Critical Mass rides do everything in their power to
> encourage that unsafeness.

How so?  By merely existing?

Automobile drivers encourage the unsafeness of every street in every city
in the country at every hour of every day.

This is not the sea.  The larger craft does not have the right of way
merely because it is the larger craft.  Let's put the burden of safety
where it belongs: in the hands of he who wields the deadly weapon.

> > As a matter of fact, Critical Mass is usually outpacing traffic downtown.
>
> That's not what I see from the third floor I work on. I've watched
> several rides, and many of the people I see are riding in circles, going
> back and forth among the riders, and there are litteraly hundreds of
> cars backed up, belching exhaust up Broadway waiting for the slower
> bicycles to get out of the way.

And they're still moving faster than the dead stopped automobiles... which
are dead stopped every day at rush hour regardless of bicycle density.

> > > They purposefully block ALL traffic lanes in one direction.
> >
> > They ARE traffic, silly.  They can't be BLOCKING traffic.  They are moving
> > vehicles on the roadway.  They have every right to use the road for that
> > purpose.
>
> Yes. They can block traffic... By going slower than necessary to arrive
> at their destination. The purpose of a road is to travel (in whatever
> vehicle) from point A to point B.

That's one purpose, to be sure.  It's also one of the very last scraps of
truly public space in our increasingly privatized cityscape.  The street
is a gathering place and common ground for all citizens.

When the streets are just for the biggest and most deadly vehicles, then
where do we go for our fairs and block parties?

How do we commune with our neighbors while moving about the city when
everyone's locked into a steel battering ram, strapped in and bracing
themselves for the next collision?

> The purpose of the CM rides is to disrupt life. It's a statement, not a
> journey.

That's your opinion.  And as someone who does not participate, it's not a
meaningful one.

> > > They cut in and out of traffic and ride on the line between lanes and
> > > between cars.
> >
> > Lane changes and passing are legal.  And bicycles are an exception to the
> > "one vehicle per lane" law.
>
> So you are saying that bicycle can share the lane with my Explorer? I
> realize they can ride several bikes abreast in a lane. I'm talking about
> passing between cars that are in adjacent lanes. That's not legal, and
> it's downright dangerous.

Passing on the left is legal when there is room to pass without crossing
the dividing line.  Passing on the left is legal even if you must cross
the dividing line provided that line is dashed and not solid.

A bicycle can overtake all but the very widest of automobiles on all but
the very narrowest of streets without crossing the dividing line.
Typically, they need about 18 inches.

> > > I know, as I almost hit one that was riding next to me on 4th street. He
> > > was next to me IN MY LANE!
> >
> > Right... see above.  Bicycles are allowed to share the lane with motor
> > traffic and other bicycles.
>
> Not when it's a car and a bicycle IN THE SAME LANE. There's not room for
> a car and a bicycle in the same lane. Show me law that states this is
> so.

The law doesn't say whether there's room.  That would be absurd.  (How
could the law know the dimensions of every vehicle on every street in
every circumstance?)

The law does say, however, that overtaking a vehicle within the lane is
legal.

> > > If it's the people responsible for the spam hitting my mail server (74%

The difference between riding bicycles in the street joyously, beckoning

Well, perhaps you shouldn't fight against it, then.

> It's convenient for me to ride Max to work, so I do. When it was

Convenience is YOUR value, though.  I don't ride my bicycle around the
city because it's convenient.  I do it because it's the right thing to do.

Convenience is the bottom rung "value".  When ALL other aspects are equal,

Putting convenience above other values is nothing but false laziness and
greed.

Every time a group of cyclists is the predominant traffic on a particular

I could register linuxhacker.info and write that the purpose of hacking

Are you particularly gullible or not very well socialized?  The endless
variety of human motivation in any common action should be patently
obvious to anyone who bothers to get to know a number of people from
different walks of life and backgrounds.

Hell, I know a guy who rides in every Mass he can find because he thinks

From drl at drloree.com  Wed Oct 15 05:52:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Wed Oct 15 05:52:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Are there any spam simulators out there?
In-Reply-To: <20031015053932.GA17003@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20031015053932.GA17003@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <1066205284.12259.3973.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Tue, 2003-10-14 at 22:39, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> > On Sun, Oct 12, 2003 at 10:54:26PM -0700, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> > > I'm fiddling with spam filtering right now, and watching mail
> > > files as they filter through procmail and such.  However, the
> > > spam isn't reliable (!!);  though I get an average of 200 to
> > > 400 per day, they can be as much as 10 minutes apart.  Is there
> > > any way to simulate spam?  Say a website out there that can
> > > be instructed to send random simulated spams in a burst?
>                                                                                 
> Paul Johnson replied:
> > Do you keep archives of your mail?  If so, just go back through, find
> > at least 200 spam and 200 ham, and start learnin!
> 
> You are right, this might be easier than finding some outside source
> of spam/ham.  I have plenty of saved ham and spam, which I used when
> I trained bogofilter.  I just don't know how to transform mbox text
> into a stream of handshaked stuff that I can blow into SMTP port 25
> on my firewall like it was coming from the net.  For the current job,
> I could even launch the stuff inside the firewall at the mail server, 
> but I would like to include the firewall in the tests.
> 
> So now the question is, are there any test tools that can turn a
> mbox file (or a Maildir directory) into messages feeding port 25?

fetchmail could pull them in off an external server, right through your
firewall.  I think I even saw a GUI for it.  This would be a POP port
(or IMAP if you want), not SMTP.  Would the port matter?

For the SMTP port, your going to have to have the external server dish
them back to you.

How about a .forward on your internal box that goes back out to a new
account on the external box, this external box has a .forward to a new
user on your internal box.  Use fetchmail to start the cycle by pulling
from a POP server running on the external box.

Kinda circular, and it could hammer your network pretty hard, but it
should do the trick.  You might think about renting an extra IP address
from your ISP to do this test (if you can), having physical access to
the external server really helps.  I think the $5 a month is worth it.

I take no responsibility if this crashes any routers or breaks any
firewalls.  
> 
> This isn't about training the tools, it is about seeing that all the
> tools are working together correctly and that they respond correctly
> to a burst of messages.  For this I need test generators.

Insert training filters where needed (or not).

Have fun!

Derek Loree





From guy1656 at ados.com  Wed Oct 15 06:05:02 2003
From: guy1656 at ados.com (guy1656)
Date: Wed Oct 15 06:05:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: PGP Sigs in Spam + some HUMOR...
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0310142324090.519@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <1065918586.10214.49.camel@dell.linux.box> <20031015060829.GA26920@sthelens.dimstar.net> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0310142324090.519@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <200310150607.07046.guy1656@ados.com>

I am an agressive driver. I love it.
I learned to drive in the Allston-Brighton section of Boston, and after many 
years away, I returned for a Thanksgivingday visit. It was touching to be 
"amongst my own," so to speak, in that everyone around me made the same kind 
of assumptions about traffic, driving, and those puny obnoxious obstacles to 
getting from here to the place I'm already thinking about (Steven Covey: 
"Begin with the end in mind") notably bicycles, pedestrians, and (sometimes) 
loose dogs.

Pedestrian laws are set to become even dumber in Portland starting in January. 
The Boston response will be to allow one's brakes to get a little squeaky 
(not physically unsafe, just noisy.) Since most pedestrians are gullible 
enough to confuse noise with an inability to stop, you can use this sound to 
intimidate them into staying on the curb and out of your way - which is where 
they all belong after work is done - out of your way, so you can start taking 
on other drivers, mano a mano.

(Personally, I'd like to design a kind of bumper-mounted unfoldable fence. 
Think of the wicket-shaped things they put on school buses, but make it two 
or three stages long, with a Wiley Coyote type controller. Here you are 
decelerating from 45 to 0 for a momentary stop for a right-on-red. The moment 
you stop, you will of course punch-it to sqeeze into the gap between the next 
two cars of cross traffic. Now, in REAL hard-core driving, if there are a few 
open parking spaces on the cross street to your right, you stop, and then 
accelerate into the parking spaces just like a highway on-ramp, then make 
your cut-in. Obviously this means we have no time for foot-traffic at the 
corner, so it would be neat to unfold a portable fence ahead of time, which 
by keeping pedestrians on the curb, prevents them from invoking that stupid 
20-foot rule.)

With this, Allow me to quote some lines from the infamous "Boston Driver's 
Handbook" (Gershkoff/Trachtman, c.1982.)

"Bike riders are a strange bunch. They tend to feel very self-righteous about 
physical fitness, saving energy, and preserving the environment, yet at the 
same time they fail to realize they are breathing more exhaust than anybody 
else. They claim they have a right to be a part of the traffic stream, but 
the truth is they can't cut it in the Big Leagues. Sometimes, they take up 
enough of the road to slow traffic down significantly, and corrective 
measures are required."

(Note: I once had the pleasure of driving through Bean-town during an 
afternoon blackout. Guess what happened? With no traffic lights, drivers on 
Mass. Ave from Harvard inbouund were averaging about 55mph. Awesome. 
Efficient. Anyways, so for Boston drivers, 45 - 55mph feels just about right 
in-town.)

"When you see 'Lefty' (wrong-way biker) coming at you, just pull to the right 
slightly and coax him gently off the road. [...] As a general policy we 
advocate putting bicyclists in their place: either walking their bikes on the 
sidewalk or riding them on bike paths, as far as possible from the world of 
Boston Driving."

"[Another] type of bicycle rider, known as 'Aggressor,' is always racing 
against traffic. He usually loses, but that doesn't bother him. As a general 
rule he will keep to the far right if he cannot keep up with the cars; at the 
same speed as traffic, he will move left to take up a full lane. [...] At a 
light he will weave to the front of the line, give a quick glance for 
cross-traffic, and run the light, barely missing a stride.

If one blocks your way, the best thing to do is to try to sidesqueeze him into 
the middle of the traffic stream. This will force the bicyclist to weave and 
will usually occupy him enough to allow you to pass him. But beware: if he's 
good, he will move with you and prevent you from doing so."

(GLL: This is where Boston potholes come in handy...)

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Wed Oct 15 09:28:02 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Wed Oct 15 09:28:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Projector
Message-ID: <20031015162635.GA21104@gate.kl-ic.com>

Zot writes:
>         I do need a project still (Again). Kieth has fixed the  project
> power supply but we have not got it to work reliably yet.

Setting up computer projectors is hard, especially setting up that old
Proxima's 640x480 from a random laptop.  Some of the newer projectors
scan-convert, which leads to a shitty looking picture but quicker
laptop setup.  However, XFree is certainly powerful enough and XConfig
files versatile enough that there is almost guaranteed to be a workable
solution for 98% of laptops and 98% of projectors.  The problem, Linux
or Windows, new projector or old, is finding that solution in a few
minutes before a talk.  This has plagued projectors since day one.

  *******************************************************************
  This is actually a career opportunity for one of us!  What about an 
  open-source tool that does this configuration semi-automagically?  
  *******************************************************************

Is there someone here with a smidgen of programming skill (this would
not take much, probably a tiny bit of perl programming) willing to do 
the experimentation necessary, then write a program and a user's guide?
There would be a lot of writing (Mini-Howtos with the setup formula for
every machine) and a lot of user-empathy needed for a friendly design.
You will have to learn XConfig, of course.  But after a while, the
Mini-Howtos will be contributed over the net, so this will not take
forever to complete.

A smallish script driven by a big table of projectors and a big table of
laptops (with accompanying setup formulas) followed by some experimental
algorithms for laptops and projectors not listed, would likely reduce
the fiddling around to seconds or at most minutes.  It would be an
excellent skill advertisment (your splash screen would be projected
worldwide thousands of times a day), and an excellent way to promote
Linux ("This Microsoft junk isn't working!  Go get the Linux laptop!").

Talk about low hanging fruit!  We probably have half-a-dozen projectors
and 30 different kinds of laptops among us, and we are mostly helpful
and friendly types;  whoever took this on as a project would be able
to get a lot of testing experience rapidly.  InFocus and Compview
are in town, and probably would provide access to projectors for the
development of the second version of the program (and if you wanted a
job at such places, this would be a good way to get it).   

Zot, I'm *glad* that hard-to-configure projector is giving you fits, 
because this could lead to a new Linux tool, one that closed-source
Windows will never be able to match.  It could also lead to a good
job for an ambitious PLUG member.  Scratch that itch!

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

On Wed, 15 Oct 2003, guy1656 wrote:
> I am an agressive driver. I love it.

So you wield a deadly weapon in the most flagrant way and expect others to
get out of your way or be killed.

That's very thoughtful and respectful of you.

> It was touching to be "amongst my own," so to speak, in that everyone
> around me made the same kind of assumptions about traffic, driving, and
> those puny obnoxious obstacles to getting from here to the place I'm
> already thinking about (Steven Covey:  "Begin with the end in mind")
> notably bicycles, pedestrians, and (sometimes)  loose dogs.

This helps explain why most of Boston is hideous to behold.  Travelling is
more than just transport.  Appreciation and care for the space through
which you travel.  When people just think of places as destinations (and
worse, as just INTERIOR destinations), exteriors and spaces between are
neglected and ugliness sets in and streets become unpleasant places.

The customized interior space of an automobile insulates a person from
their surroundings and further separates a person from their community and
city.  And as the spaces between destinations get less and less pleasant
to experience, people choose to spend more of their time confined in those
insulating interiors.

The most pleasant spaces to travel in Boston are, not coincidentally, in
those regions where it is most difficult to drive a car at non-human
speeds; Beacon Hill, the North end, etc.

> The Boston response will be to allow one's brakes to get a little
> squeaky (not physically unsafe, just noisy.) Since most pedestrians are
> gullible enough to confuse noise with an inability to stop, you can use
> this sound to intimidate them into staying on the curb and out of your
> way - which is where they all belong after work is done - out of your
> way, so you can start taking on other drivers, mano a mano.

Again, you threaten violence to get your way without consideration for the
people you threaten except insofar as whether or not they respond to your
threat.  This kind of behavior is not only violent and disrespectful, but
antisocial and uncivil.

Why do you bother living in civilization at all?

People with this kind of attitude reap the benefits of civil society while
chipping away at the very foundation that allows it to exist at all.  They
undermine civilization itself and impede any kind of human progress.

> (Personally, I'd like to design a kind of bumper-mounted unfoldable
> fence....so it would be neat to unfold a portable fence ahead of time,
> which by keeping pedestrians on the curb, prevents them from invoking
> that stupid 20-foot rule.)

So you'd attempt to control human beings like cattle for your convenience.

That's too sick to be funny, even.  Do you have no respect for other
people?  You're like Alex in A Clockwork Orange.  It's all about your own
personal pleasure and convenience and if violence is what you need to use
to get it, you'll do it.  Does this bother you at all?  Do you really want
to live in a world where you have to watch your back all the time for
suspicion that someone might stab you for their convenience?  Do you like
to be treated like cattle and shoved around by people who think they're
more important than you are?  Why would you propogate such a notion and
make that world?

> "Bike riders are a strange bunch. They tend to feel very self-righteous
> about physical fitness, saving energy, and preserving the environment,
> yet at the same time they fail to realize they are breathing more
> exhaust than anybody else.

I don't think ANY cyclist doesn't recognize that he breathes more exhaust
than anybody else.

This is like Russell's arguments about the purpose of Critical Mass.  The
author presumes he knows the minds of others, then points out an obvious
contradiction with reality but assumes this is the fault of the presumed
cyclist and not a flaw in the presumptions of the author.  This is clearly
a case of someone wanting to call another person stupid rather than
wanting to understand and love other people.

But I guess that's to be expected from someone that advocates violence
against people for being inconvenient.

> (Note: I once had the pleasure of driving through Bean-town during an

Except for the fact that there ARE cyclists and pedestrians and drivers

> "When you see 'Lefty' (wrong-way biker) coming at you, just pull to the

First, I certainly don't advocate someone cycling the wrong way on the
street.  It's dangerous, illegal, and dumb.

Second, threat of deadly violence is hardly gentle.

Third, it's not your place to coax anyone into anything with regard to the
public roadways.

> [...] As a general policy we advocate putting bicyclists in their place:
> either walking their bikes on the sidewalk or riding them on bike paths,
> as far as possible from the world of Boston Driving."

This is contrary to the law and civility.  It's selfish and all-around
fucked-up thinking.

> "[Another] type of bicycle rider, known as 'Aggressor,' is always racing
> against traffic. He usually loses, but that doesn't bother him.

I don't know about "racing against traffic", but I would say that, in
town, I pass more cars than pass me.  It's just the nature of the system.
My vehicle is more agile and less prone to the impediment of congestion.

Of course, the statement above is an attempt by the author to bolster his
own ego by calling someone else a "loser" (by losing the "race").
Travelling is not a competition and viewing it as such is putting needless
friction into what could be a joyful experience.

> As a general rule he will keep to the far right if he cannot keep up
> with the cars;

In most places, this is the law.

> at the same speed as traffic, he will move left to take up a full lane.

In Oregon, at least, this is also the law.

> [...] At a light he will weave to the front of the line, give a quick
> glance for cross-traffic, and run the light, barely missing a stride.

This is the law in Idaho and soon to be the law in Oregon.

> If one blocks your way, the best thing to do is to try to sidesqueeze
> him into the middle of the traffic stream.

This is self-contradictory.  If the cyclist is only in the middle of the
lane when he is travelling at the rate of the rest of the traffic, why
would he be blocking anyone's way?

(And the persistent use of the terms "my way" and "your way" is erroneous
and subtly arrogant.  A road is just a way.  It is not mine or yours.
When we both are using it, it could be called our way.)

> This will force the bicyclist to weave and will usually occupy him

>
> (GLL: This is where Boston potholes come in handy...)

This sounds like the technique used by the truck driver that ran me off
the road and into a rut that turned my wheel and subsequently broke two of
my ribs.  Surely his convenience was worth whatever pain and suffering I
had to endure.

So what makes a person this arrogant, violent, and hateful?  Does that
actually make anyone's life BETTER?

From guy1656 at ados.com  Wed Oct 15 11:23:01 2003
From: guy1656 at ados.com (guy1656)
Date: Wed Oct 15 11:23:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] WOT: Pub trans
In-Reply-To: <1066240041.18973.69.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1065918586.10214.49.camel@dell.linux.box> <1066201565.4494.25.camel@dell.linux.box> <1066240041.18973.69.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <200310151124.54835.guy1656@ados.com>

: The other option is regular, reliable, cost
: effective, fast public transportation system
: out to Scappoose and St. Helens, but that's not
: likely to happen anytime soon. ...

... Um, no thank you. Public trans brings a change in the political 
demographics of a region, diluting the opinion of the rural, mostly 
independent-minded (Linux?!?) folk by filling the area with people more 
dependent on government services. These people then vote to expand the role 
of municipal services at the expense of digging deeper in to the wallets & 
savings of the original denizens, who moved out here because we want and need 
fewer public services in the first place.

The other question is that I haven't heard of too many public trans projects 
which are wholly funded by the ridership alone. Therefore, such projects are 
dependent on grabbing some amount of revenue from people who don't use the 
service but just happen to live unfortunately close to the system. This is 
essentially relying upon a sort of theft - the locals who pay but don't use 
the system are being robbed, and for that they get an influx of transplants 
who don't understand the self-reliant culture: "Wanna go somewhere? Buy your 
own car." Also: Paying more money ( to private capitalist business or private 
person) to buy a 4x4 and mongo tires allows you to save tax money no longer 
needed for road maintenance (so you vote down the road repair levy.)  You are 
now more impervious to potholes & washouts, which themselves serve to screen 
out the wimp-mobiles. :-D

Almost on-topic: By contributing to the local private sector and starving the 
local public sector, isn't that the same as avoiding bloatware?

- GLL

On Wed, 2003-10-15 at 00:45, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> > If anything, they are *more* capable of pulling over and allowing
> > regular traffic to go by.
> 
> Wow.  You realize that your statement implies that bicycles are NOT
> "regular traffic"?
> 
> That's what we'd call a "double standard".  Bicycles are not "regular
> traffic", so they should step aside and let that through.  But bicycles
> ARE "regular traffic" and should abide by the same laws as everything
> else.

Oh, come on now.  You're mincing words.  Bicycles are not *regular*
traffic.  They are a rare form of traffic, at least as far as I see. 
Nowhere does it state you must be regular to be held by the same laws as
everybody else.  I am not regular in my use of computers - I use Linux. 
Should I then be not held to any of the same laws everybody else must
follow in regards to computing?

> > I think I'll write the my state representative about that one - get the
> > word motor out of that law.
> 
> That would make every pedestrian a criminal.

If a pedestrian is walking down the middle of the road, impeding
traffic, then guess what?  They *ARE* violating the law.  I don't think
most people consider pedestrian's shoes to be vehicles, either.  The law
did have the word vehicle in it, didn't it?

> > It may be arguable from another standpoint, though, I don't know -
> > bicycles are bound to all the same laws a motorized vehicle is except
> > for those by their very nature they cannot follow.  That seems to
> > include them in the motor world, if you ask me...
> 
> Huh?  I don't get what you've written here.

Ok, let me see if I can rephrase it.

Law A states motor vehicles can't do /this/.

Law B states bicycles are held to all the same laws as motor vehicles,
except those by their very nature they cannot or should not be expected
to follow.

Law A clearly doesn't include bicycles by itself.  Law B clearly
includes bicycles in laws written for motor vehicles.

Which law do you go by?  I'm no lawyer, but it sounds to me like the
judge got it wrong.

> > > Yes. They can block traffic... By going slower than necessary to arrive
> > > at their destination. The purpose of a road is to travel (in whatever
> > > vehicle) from point A to point B. The purpose of the CM rides is to
> > > disrupt life. It's a statement, not a journey.
> >
> > It's downright disgusting.
> 
> Using the streets for any purpose other than travelling in the shortest
> distance from Point A to Point B is disgusting?

The law includes 'reason' in most everything.  You should try it.  :-)

> What do you think of block parties?
>
> How about parades?

Well, I really personally dislike both block parties and parades,
because they can (and do) fudge up traffic, although block parties tend
to be in residential areas where the traffic impact is minimal. 
Parades, on the other hand, I really dislike.

> What about Sunday drives in the country?

Sunday drives in the country don't have any effect on anybody, do they? 
Country roads are essentially never congested, although there are always
exceptions to this due to collisions or construction.  I don't see why
we need to include the exceptions in such a broad brush stroke, though.

> Kickball in the street?

It's a residential type thing, with minimal impact on traffic.  If the
little kids (assuming it's kids playing kickball, of course) don't get
out of the way for a vehicle with a need to use the street, though, I
would have a problem with it.

> > Not just downright dangerous - I'd call it reckless driving.  At the
> > very least, I'd call it careless driving.
> 
> Doesn't that require endangering the lives of others?
> 
> The cars are the dangerous weapons on the street, not the bicycles.

No, I don't think either law (and we're talking about two [reckless and
careless]- but I am not a lawyer) requires endangering the lives of
others.  A bicycle can do damage to a vehicle, or injure him(or
her)self, or cause the driver of one of the motorized vehicles to use
evasive action to not kill the bicycle rider and do damage to another
vehicle and its driver and passengers.

I think all of these things would fall under reckless driving, assuming
you can prove reckless intent... but I really don't think that would be
a problem for most DAs.  If you didn't think you could show intent in a
situation like that, you would have to go for a careless driving
citation, which has no intent requirement.  It is also an infraction,
instead of whatever reckless driving is (either a misdemeanor or a
felony - I'm pretty sure it's just a misdemeanor, though).

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Wed Oct 15 11:49:01 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Wed Oct 15 11:49:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Traffic, SPAM, and Linux
Message-ID: <20031015184749.GB21104@gate.kl-ic.com>

It is in our genes to transform our frustration into punishing others.
Spammers are frustrated at getting their ads to the few that actually
want the stuff.  They punish the rest of us.  We are frustrated about spam,
and can't find the spammers, so we punish the Direct Mail Association.
Jeme is frustrated at automobiles, and his inability to convince most
drivers to join him in bicycling - so he approves of measures like
Critical Mass.  Drivers, who think these particular cyclists are
self-deluding punishment-spreading jerks, then incorrectly punish
other cyclists by running them off the road.  (BTW, I fully expect
one of these drivers to go into roadrage mode, and drive through a
Critical Mass crowd at 80 miles an hour, killing himself and about
10 of the C.M. participants.  Resulting in legislation that would
severely restrict bicycling in ways completely irrelevant to managing
Critical Mass demonstrations.  Legislators are jerks, too).

Myself, I feel rage towards spammers, and rage towards closed-source
monopolists who create laws restricting competition against them.  I
got a chuckle out of the "use the spammers against themselves" trick
that started this argument going.  But punishment doesn't solve the 
problem, and it makes the world a more painful place.  Ask yourself
whether you would be a better person if your life was more painful.
If the answer is no, then extrapolate to the rest of the human race.
If the answer is yes, find a dominatrix and seek your bliss in a more
private way, thanks.

The Linux community, as a whole and by individual example, teaches a
better way.  We convert the frustration against Microsoft into advocacy
for Linux.  We don't picket Microsoft headquarters, we pass out Knoppix
disks.  We don't piss and moan about bugs, we fix them.  And although
we are a little late to the party about creating quality user apps, open
source apps are getting better at a rate that Microsoft cannot match.  
Fellows like Dan run Linux clinics for newbies, Dave and Zot set up
lectures to continue the education, and almost everyone here devotes
significant efforts to helping each other.  You can't buy that in a 
box from Microsoft, and in time no one will try.  We have the good
aspects of human nature on our side, we have sociality and conviviality,
and if we can remain true to these positives we cannot lose.

Those plagued by Spam may be forgetting the early days of Usenet,
when the groups were often clogged with classified ads by individuals
peddling their old stuff.  Oh, how the debates raged over what
constituted "commercial" versus "non-commercial" ads;  we were mostly
young communists [;-)] then, and Usenet was mostly transported over the
"not-for-commercial-use" Arpanet, so we felt we had a right to attack
folks who tried to sell commercially with ads in Usenet.  Personal ads
were all right "of course" (Why "of course"?).  

People don't do a lot of personal ads on lists anymore - at least not
in proportion to the vastly larger number of users out there.  The 
reason?  Ebay!  There is a much better outlet for peddling old stuff,
and now probably the only reason Ebay doesn't do *all* the garage sale
stuff in the world is that most people still don't know how.  The only
reason stuff still gets peddled in this group (and it seems to be rare)
is affinity;  we would rather sell our precious stuff to help our friends,
and we would rather buy from our friends.

I think there is a lesson for spam, here.  Some may smirk and go hmph
(you get a lot of that from the young and shallow) but there is a
business opportunity here - not as big as Ebay perhaps, but there.
Creating a market that efficiently links the peddlers of "legitimate"
spam products and consumers will dry up the revenue that drives that
kind of spam.  Educating email users in an entertaining way about the
various kinds of spam fraud should reduce the success of the 419 stuff. 
Developing better businesses for clever internet-savvy Africans (and
others) will make computer fraud a less attractive option.  Spam is a
symptom of a slightly broken economy, and as cheap as Spam is to send
out, there are better ways to move that information to the customers
that want it.  Spam is a "cry for help", a demonstration of unmet needs,
and many of those needs have a technological or business solution,
ripe for smart folks like us to get rich solving.

There may be some technological or business solutions for Jeme's desire
to make the world more bike friendly, too.  There are a lot of things
you can do on a bike that you can't do in a car, like stop and smell
the roses.  Or log in at a sidewalk kiosk.  Or stop and talk to people
without blocking traffic.  Create enough advantages for bicycling, and
being slow and wet and tired and bumper-bait won't seem quite so
offputting.  Cycling proponents argue the negatives ("It's cleaner!
You won't die as soon of a heart attack!  It's anti-corporate!") and
forget the lesson we are slowly learning with Linux - sell solutions,
not complaints.  Serve people, don't thwart or punish them. 

I'm looking out at the cold, wet rain right now, and thinking about a
book I want from the Tigard library 5 miles south, and a couple of checks
I want to put in my bank 2 miles west.  Absurd as it might sound to Jeme,
I am thinking "car" and not "bike".  In June, on a 75 degree sunshiny
day, Jeme and the bike win.  In a fully open source world, both those
infotransactions happen over the net, and I get immediate gratification.
With a fully developed net, I need neither bike nor car, ceding the roads
to those still willing to do battle on them.  If Jeme or others want my car
off the road, there are opportunities to provide me with better options. 
Gratitude and remuneration await those who prefer helping to punishment.

Keith

[and Jeme, I don't want the above to seem like I am picking on you (well,
maybe a little).  Mostly, I think of you as a smart and talented fellow
with a wide argumentive streak, just like I was a few years ago.  Now I
am older, and still argumentative, but not as smart and talented.  I
wish I had paid less attention to the incompetent punishers of the world,
and spent more time using my skills to make people happy.  I project those
wishes on you, though I suspect you can only learn this from your own
personal clue-by-four.  Dreams drive us, but we make no progress without
sympathy.  You have plenty of the former - put more effort into the
latter, because I would like to see some of your dreams come true, too]

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

> And war is stupid because it does not bring more happiness to the world,

If we lived by that.... we'd still be ruled by The Queen today.  No,
wait, we're on the West side of the US.  If we weren't hablando espanol,
we'd be ruled by one of Napolean's descendants.  I'll be he'd be pissed
off by crazy bicyclists, though... that might not be pretty for you.

> > They are folks trying to make a statement, and causing a lot of grief
> > and hard feelings in the process.
> 
> I think they are people out travelling the city's roads and having loads
> of fun and spreading joy in the process.

If you honestly believe that, then you have a ways to go in your study
of humanity.

There are some extreme problems with the CM philosophy.  First, by
clogging the roads, they slow down the petroleum-fed vehicles, bringing
them, often, to a complete stop.  I don't believe any CM rider will
argue they don't slow down traffic.  Since they know they do it, and do
it over and over again, we must assume it is intentional.

Slowing down traffic, forcing traffic to stop, causes the cars to sit
there idling.  That wastes gasoline (or diesel) and forces more
pollutants into the air.  Isn't that contrary to the values of the
average CM rider?  Don't many of them ride their bikes specifically to
help keep the air just that much cleaner?  They're causing more
petroleum bi-products to be released into the atmosphere than if they
would have just gone home for the day.

Another substantial problem is you state they believe they are spreading
joy, beckoning others to join them on their bicycles.  Gee, I have a
picture in my head of people frolicking in a field, kinda like the
XP-default desktop field, maybe.

CM riders *piss people off*.  They ride their bicycles to block traffic,
eating the time of regular commuters.  You will never win somebody over
to your way of thinking if your most visible method is offensive to
everybody you're trying to win over.  If I argued for reduced
governmental gun control by pulling out my .22 pistol and firing it at
3AM just off the property of every state representative's residence who
lived outside of a city limits, waking them up, I think I would find I
wouldn't be winning them over to my side, now would I?

Or maybe I could borrow my friend's blank-firing pistol and go outside
the capital building and start firing it.  I'm sure that would win them
over to my side, right?

Wrong.

It makes absolutely no sense at all.

Rob

On Wed, 15 Oct 2003, Russ Johnson wrote:
> If one is "running" something, are they not it's defacto leader?

For one, the headline calls him "Leader of the Free World" and the article
goes on to say he's "benevolent dictator of Planet Linux, the largest
collaborative project in history".  I'd hardly call the kernel the largest
collaborative project in history.  If you wanted to call ONE project the
largest, it would probably be the GNU project.  And that DOES have a
leader.

As for your contention that someone who runs something must be the leader,
I would say perhaps no.  A leader leads.  A leader provides vision and
direction.  It is very possible for someone to have nominal or even real
control over a project, but not be the most active visionary or director
of the project.  That person would run the project without being the
leader.

reconsider your living situation.

PSU should never add any parking.  It is downtown.
