On Wed, 15 Oct 2003, AthlonRob wrote:
> Oh, come on now.  You're mincing words.  Bicycles are not *regular*
> traffic.  They are a rare form of traffic, at least as far as I see.

You're not looking.  Go downtown and sit at an intersection and see how
many bicycles pass that one intersection every hour.

> Nowhere does it state you must be regular to be held by the same laws as
> everybody else.  I am not regular in my use of computers - I use Linux.
> Should I then be not held to any of the same laws everybody else must
> follow in regards to computing?

You are a regular computer user and all computer users (regular or
otherwise) should be held to the same laws.

But if the law prohibits the use of a Graphical Interface System (and goes
on to define that) for a particular purpose, you shouldn't be held to that
law if you don't use a Graphical Interface System.  This is the case with
the law against impeding traffic.  It only applies to motor vehicles.  The
code is very clear and makes that distinction from section to subsection.

> > That would make every pedestrian a criminal.
>
> If a pedestrian is walking down the middle of the road, impeding
> traffic, then guess what?  They *ARE* violating the law.

Sometimes they are and sometimes they're not.  It depends on the other
circumstances and conditions of the roads, sidewalks, and adjoining land.

> I don't think most people consider pedestrian's shoes to be vehicles,
> either.  The law did have the word vehicle in it, didn't it?

OK, so if I put my feet down, am I a pedestrian or a vehicle?

> > Huh?  I don't get what you've written here.
>
> Ok, let me see if I can rephrase it.
>
> Law A states motor vehicles can't do /this/.
>
> Law B states bicycles are held to all the same laws as motor vehicles,
> except those by their very nature they cannot or should not be expected
> to follow.

That's NOT what the law says.  It says that a bicycle is a VEHICLE for all
sections of the code except where the code cannot apply.  It is not a
MOTOR VEHICLE.

> Law A clearly doesn't include bicycles by itself.  Law B clearly
> includes bicycles in laws written for motor vehicles.

That's not what Law B (ORS 814.400) says.

> Which law do you go by?  I'm no lawyer, but it sounds to me like the
> judge got it wrong.

No, you got it wrong.

> > Using the streets for any purpose other than travelling in the shortest
> > distance from Point A to Point B is disgusting?
>
> The law includes 'reason' in most everything.  You should try it.  :-)

Actually, intent is NOT a consideration when forming law.  Intent is part
of the Congressional Record when law is written, but the court rarely
listens to arguments of legal intent and judges merely on application.

That's why you can't challenge a law in court without a pending case under
that law.

> Well, I really personally dislike both block parties and parades,
> because they can (and do) fudge up traffic, although block parties tend
> to be in residential areas where the traffic impact is minimal.
> Parades, on the other hand, I really dislike.

Do you participate in ANY public gatherings?

> Sunday drives in the country don't have any effect on anybody, do they?

You really believe driving a car has no effect on anybody?

> Country roads are essentially never congested, although there are always
> exceptions to this due to collisions or construction.  I don't see why
> we need to include the exceptions in such a broad brush stroke, though.

Well, you did write that using the road for a purpose other than getting
form Point A to Point B is "disgusting".

> It's a residential type thing, with minimal impact on traffic.  If the
> little kids (assuming it's kids playing kickball, of course) don't get
> out of the way for a vehicle with a need to use the street, though, I
> would have a problem with it.

So automobiles are the #1 priority in appropriating public space in a
city?  That's kind of fucked up.  Automobiles are just one little tool in
the great attempt to improve life for humanity.

> > The cars are the dangerous weapons on the street, not the bicycles.
>
> No, I don't think either law (and we're talking about two [reckless and
> careless]- but I am not a lawyer) requires endangering the lives of
> others.

811.135 Careless driving; penalty. (1) A person commits the offense of
careless driving if the person drives any vehicle upon a highway or other
premises described in this section in a manner that endangers or would be
likely to endanger any person or property.

811.140 Reckless driving; penalty. (1) A person commits the offense of
reckless driving if the person recklessly drives a vehicle upon a highway
or other premises described in this section in a manner that endangers the
safety of persons or property.

> A bicycle can do damage to a vehicle, or injure him(or her)self, or
> cause the driver of one of the motorized vehicles to use evasive action
> to not kill the bicycle rider and do damage to another vehicle and its
> driver and passengers.

Personally, I'd saw the weapon is wielded by the driver.  If a person is
walking around with a cocked and loaded gun and his finger on the trigger,
I'd hardly blame the schmoe who bumped into him for the bullet in the
third guy's head.  Dig?

> I think all of these things would fall under reckless driving, assuming
> you can prove reckless intent... but I really don't think that would be
> a problem for most DAs.

Pushing anything weighing more than a thousand pounds around at speeds
greater than 20mph in a public place is reckless endangerment in my book.

> If you didn't think you could show intent in a situation like that, you
> would have to go for a careless driving citation, which has no intent
> requirement.

ORS 161.085 (9) "Recklessly," when used with respect to a result or to a
circumstance described by a statute defining an offense, means that a
person is aware of and consciously disregards a substantial and
unjustifiable risk that the result will occur or that the circumstance
exists. The risk must be of such nature and degree that disregard thereof
constitutes a gross deviation from the standard of care that a reasonable
person would observe in the situation.

A reasonable person would, to me, calculate the forces involved in moving
heavy shit around at high speeds and the relevant impact of those forces
on a human body and observe enough caution to reduce those forces to
sub-lethal levels.

> It is also an infraction, instead of whatever reckless driving is
> (either a misdemeanor or a felony - I'm pretty sure it's just a
> misdemeanor, though).

Careless driving is a traffic violation and reckless driving is a
misdemeanor.  However, if you cause an accident with either, you can be
charged with further penalties.

> > Which vehicle was applying force in that situation?  The bicycle is almost
> > never the dominant force in a collision.
>
> Both vehicles were applying force, and the bicycle was the one causing
> the problem.

What's "the problem"?  To me, the problem would be someone dying or
seriously injured.  In an auto/bicycle collision, the cause of that
problem would surely be the automobile.

Do you have some other definition of "the problem"?

> I don't think most full-time-employed folks have the time or the energy
> to leave work on Friday, meet under a tree, and disrupt rush-hour
> traffic as much as they can.

There are no trees under the Burnside Bridge, that I recall.  And you're
further presupposing that it's someone's intent to "disrupt rush hour
traffic as much as they can".

And if you don't have the energy to ride a bicycle a few miles after a
day's work, I think you have serious health problems that should be
addressed.

> > Sounds like you need some lifestyle re-evaluation.  You could make it work
> > and probably free up lots of time for your self, family and friends, if
> > you wanted to put an ounce of effort into creating a more pleasant life.
>
> Wow - how is that?  Everybody live where they work?

That's a good start.

> Naw, I really think life is very pleasant living out here in the
> country.  I wouldn't want to live in a city for very long at all.

Then don't work in a city.  Your lifestyle is a whole system.  If you
prefer the country, then make your life in the country.

> I don't live in the suburbs, I live further out than that.  I do most of
> my work within walking distance of home,

That's very good.

> although I attend school up in Portland.

Do you telecommute at all?

> I definitely don't spend 25% of my money on transportation (have you
> seen my car?  lol).

Gas, insurance, etc.  25% is an average for the least wealthy 80% of the
public.

> My car is parked on the street.

So you use publicly subsidized storage for your private property?

> We essentially paid for our street directly,

> and when I park at PSU, I pay over $100 a term for a parking spot that
> isn't guaranteed to be there.

That's still massively subsidized.

The actual cost of automobile operation is staggering.  Something on the
order of several dollars per mile.  Most of this is picked up by the
people, collectively, through their public agencies.

generalization.

> by filling the area with people more dependent on government services.

I don't think there's any evidence at all that public transit increases
the population of the area served by public transit.

And few people are more dependent on government services than users of
private gasoline-powered automobiles on public roads and highways.

> These people then vote to expand the role of municipal services at the

> The other question is that I haven't heard of too many public trans
> projects which are wholly funded by the ridership alone.

There isn't any such thing as PRIVATE transportation projects that are
wholly funded by the ridership alone.

You cannot operate transportation at user expense.  Every transportation
system is massively subsidized by the public.

Modern transportation is prohibitively expensive on the individual level.
But it is deemed important enough to be supported by the population acting
collectively.  Now, some might say it is deemed important BY the people
and others might say it is deemed important by the folks on the receiving
end of those public funds.  I think it's perhaps too complex for a certain
answer.

> Therefore, such projects are dependent on grabbing some amount of
> revenue from people who don't use the service but just happen to live
> unfortunately close to the system. This is essentially relying upon a
> sort of theft

Again, the social fabric is woven from many individuals working in their
own way to achieve common goals and the aggregate goal of increased
quality of life through peace, love, and understanding (being the only
ideals a group can hold that do not cause interpersonal friction and
strife).

> - the locals who pay but don't use the system are being robbed,

These systems allow a low cost of living for the poor who provide services
for everyone else in society at very low wages (thus decreasing the end
cost of those services).

It is currently impossible to remove one's self from that system except
for possibly by foresaking all modern convenience and the benefits of
civilization and society.

> and for that they get an influx of transplants who don't understand the
> self-reliant culture: "Wanna go somewhere? Buy your own car."

Do you need a reminder of how many public subsidies go into the production
of automobiles, roads, and gasoline?

> Also: Paying more money ( to private capitalist business or private
> person) to buy a 4x4 and mongo tires allows you to save tax money no
> longer needed for road maintenance (so you vote down the road repair
> levy.)

Could those monster trucks and tires be produced without properly
constructed roads to transport the materials and goods to market?

> You are now more impervious to potholes & washouts, which themselves
> serve to screen out the wimp-mobiles. :-D

One cannot be more or less impervious.  It is an absolute.

> Almost on-topic: By contributing to the local private sector and
> starving the local public sector, isn't that the same as avoiding
> bloatware?

No, it's the same as encouraging rape, murder, and starvation.

Why don't you just move to Sierra Leone and become a warlord?

From carla at bratgrrl.com  Wed Oct 15 17:32:02 2003
From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Wed Oct 15 17:32:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] useful procmail links
Message-ID: <200310151733.02799.carla@bratgrrl.com>

There's been a lot of discussion on using procmail lately, here's some links 
that might be helpful:

http://www.linux.org.uk/~telsa/BitsAndPieces/procmailrc
http://www.uwasa.fi/~ts/info/proctips.html

Timo has some interesting ideas on spam control, including a roll-your-own 
challenge-response system. Unlike other C-R systems, his is a one-shot 
challenge-response. The sender needs to include a password in their subject 
line:
http://www.uwasa.fi/~ts/info/spamfoil.html

I'm testing it on a limited basis. Anything that requires a specific, extra 
step from other humans is prone to difficulties. :)

On Wed, 2003-10-15 at 09:33, Russell Senior wrote:
> >>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:
> 
> Rich>   I may very well have mis-configured the kernel and missed the
> Rich> pcmcia driver I needed. I don't know. Painful waste of time,
> Rich> that's what it's been.  
> 
> The thing that made it a waste was that you chose to flush the
> learning opportunity down the toilet.  Why don't you bring your box to
> the clinic this Saturday and have someone show you how to build a
> kernel properly and you will plunger some of the lossage back out.
> 
> -- 
> Russell Senior         ``shtal latta wos ba padre u prett tu nashtonfi
> seniorr at aracnet.com      mrlosh''  -- Bashgali Kafir for ``If you have
>                          had diarrhoea many days you will surely die.''
> 
Sounds like your initrd-<kernel version>.img does not have the pcmcia
modules in it.  After installing the new kernel, run mkinitrd
/boot/initrd-<new kernel-version>.img <new kernel-version>.  This should
pickup all the modules you need to get started.  The generic initial ram
disk may not have the laptop modules in it.

HTH

Ken
CADTOCAM.COM

I've commuted by bike, myself, for many years:  and I'd love to
participate in this discussion, but NOT HERE!  It is not why I read this
list.  Hey, listen, if you guys would actually use plug-talk for these
delightful flame wars, then I'd probably join in the fun!

Quite enough said.

--Jason Van Cleve





From jason at vancleve.com  Thu Oct 16 00:16:01 2003

On Wed, 2003-10-15 at 13:47, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> It is in our genes to transform our frustration into punishing others.
> Spammers are frustrated at getting their ads to the few that actually
> want the stuff.  They punish the rest of us.  We are frustrated about spam,
> and can't find the spammers, so we punish the Direct Mail Association.
> Jeme is frustrated at automobiles, and his inability to convince most
> drivers to join him in bicycling - so he approves of measures like
> Critical Mass.  Drivers, who think these particular cyclists are
> self-deluding punishment-spreading jerks, then incorrectly punish
> other cyclists by running them off the road.  (BTW, I fully expect
> one of these drivers to go into roadrage mode, and drive through a
> Critical Mass crowd at 80 miles an hour, killing himself and about
> 10 of the C.M. participants.  Resulting in legislation that would
> severely restrict bicycling in ways completely irrelevant to managing
> Critical Mass demonstrations.  Legislators are jerks, too).
> 
> Myself, I feel rage towards spammers, and rage towards closed-source
> monopolists who create laws restricting competition against them.  I
> got a chuckle out of the "use the spammers against themselves" trick
> that started this argument going.  But punishment doesn't solve the 
> problem, and it makes the world a more painful place.  Ask yourself
> whether you would be a better person if your life was more painful.
> If the answer is no, then extrapolate to the rest of the human race.
> If the answer is yes, find a dominatrix and seek your bliss in a more
> private way, thanks.
> 
> The Linux community, as a whole and by individual example, teaches a
> better way.  We convert the frustration against Microsoft into advocacy
> for Linux.  We don't picket Microsoft headquarters, we pass out Knoppix
> disks.  We don't piss and moan about bugs, we fix them.  And although
> we are a little late to the party about creating quality user apps, open
> source apps are getting better at a rate that Microsoft cannot match.  
> Fellows like Dan run Linux clinics for newbies, Dave and Zot set up
> lectures to continue the education, and almost everyone here devotes
> significant efforts to helping each other.  You can't buy that in a 
> box from Microsoft, and in time no one will try.  We have the good
> aspects of human nature on our side, we have sociality and conviviality,
> and if we can remain true to these positives we cannot lose.
> 
> Those plagued by Spam may be forgetting the early days of Usenet,
> when the groups were often clogged with classified ads by individuals
> peddling their old stuff.  Oh, how the debates raged over what
> constituted "commercial" versus "non-commercial" ads;  we were mostly
> young communists [;-)] then, and Usenet was mostly transported over the
> "not-for-commercial-use" Arpanet, so we felt we had a right to attack
> folks who tried to sell commercially with ads in Usenet.  Personal ads
> were all right "of course" (Why "of course"?).  
> 
> People don't do a lot of personal ads on lists anymore - at least not
> in proportion to the vastly larger number of users out there.  The 
> reason?  Ebay!  There is a much better outlet for peddling old stuff,
> and now probably the only reason Ebay doesn't do *all* the garage sale
> stuff in the world is that most people still don't know how.  The only
> reason stuff still gets peddled in this group (and it seems to be rare)
> is affinity;  we would rather sell our precious stuff to help our friends,
> and we would rather buy from our friends.
> 
> I think there is a lesson for spam, here.  Some may smirk and go hmph
> (you get a lot of that from the young and shallow) but there is a
> business opportunity here - not as big as Ebay perhaps, but there.
> Creating a market that efficiently links the peddlers of "legitimate"
> spam products and consumers will dry up the revenue that drives that
> kind of spam.  Educating email users in an entertaining way about the
> various kinds of spam fraud should reduce the success of the 419 stuff. 
> Developing better businesses for clever internet-savvy Africans (and
> others) will make computer fraud a less attractive option.  Spam is a
> symptom of a slightly broken economy, and as cheap as Spam is to send
> out, there are better ways to move that information to the customers
> that want it.  Spam is a "cry for help", a demonstration of unmet needs,
> and many of those needs have a technological or business solution,
> ripe for smart folks like us to get rich solving.
> 
> There may be some technological or business solutions for Jeme's desire
> to make the world more bike friendly, too.  There are a lot of things
> you can do on a bike that you can't do in a car, like stop and smell
> the roses.  Or log in at a sidewalk kiosk.  Or stop and talk to people
> without blocking traffic.  Create enough advantages for bicycling, and
> being slow and wet and tired and bumper-bait won't seem quite so
> offputting.  Cycling proponents argue the negatives ("It's cleaner!
> You won't die as soon of a heart attack!  It's anti-corporate!") and
> forget the lesson we are slowly learning with Linux - sell solutions,
> not complaints.  Serve people, don't thwart or punish them. 
> 
> I'm looking out at the cold, wet rain right now, and thinking about a
> book I want from the Tigard library 5 miles south, and a couple of checks
> I want to put in my bank 2 miles west.  Absurd as it might sound to Jeme,
> I am thinking "car" and not "bike".  In June, on a 75 degree sunshiny
> day, Jeme and the bike win.  In a fully open source world, both those
> infotransactions happen over the net, and I get immediate gratification.
> With a fully developed net, I need neither bike nor car, ceding the roads
> to those still willing to do battle on them.  If Jeme or others want my car
> off the road, there are opportunities to provide me with better options. 
> Gratitude and remuneration await those who prefer helping to punishment.
> 
> Keith
> 
> [and Jeme, I don't want the above to seem like I am picking on you (well,
> maybe a little).  Mostly, I think of you as a smart and talented fellow
> with a wide argumentive streak, just like I was a few years ago.  Now I
> am older, and still argumentative, but not as smart and talented.  I
> wish I had paid less attention to the incompetent punishers of the world,
> and spent more time using my skills to make people happy.  I project those
> wishes on you, though I suspect you can only learn this from your own
> personal clue-by-four.  Dreams drive us, but we make no progress without
> sympathy.  You have plenty of the former - put more effort into the
> latter, because I would like to see some of your dreams come true, too]

much has to be rock-solid stable. I already have my own job, which means I 
won't have much bandwidth to learn to 'administer' the new device  on top of 
that. I have to learn enough job-related things within my own field to keep 
current as is. I have no experience in managing routers, or switches, so I'm 
looking for something that needs as much attention as a typical TV set - lots 
of complex circuitry inside, sure, BUT the user interface is simple. Turn it 
on/off, plug things into it (like a VCR, DVD or game player) and these things 
work, without having to call for tech support or buy & read 3 five-pound 'In 
a Nutshell' books ...

What sort of hardware would plug into the wall (RJ-11 telephone socket) and

simultaneously as I do e-mails 'n' stuff in Linux?

That mostly goes with DSL in general.  POTS doesn't have the bandwidth
to support reliable high speed connections over very much distance,
and DSL providers generally tend to use some nasty hacks to screw you
out of the service you're paying for, like PPPoE.  Comcast sucks, but
it's better than Qwest.

From srau at rauhaus.org  Thu Oct 16 09:07:02 2003
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Thu Oct 16 09:07:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DSL Modem & QWEST
In-Reply-To: <200310160735.39756.guy1656@ados.com>
References: <200310160735.39756.guy1656@ados.com>
Message-ID: <20031016155941.GB9975@rauhaus.org>

* guy1656 <guy1656 at ados.com> [031016 07:28]:
 
> QWEST offers a device called an Actiontec 1520, but surfing blogs & install 
> woes sites, seems to indicate that that unit is rather buggy.

I bought one of these after my Qwest-provided Cisco 678 died shortly
after the warrenty expired.

I've not had any major problems with the Actiontec, though I did
initially have to talk to Qwest tech support to get it working
correctly.

> I currrently have a gateway cpu, a second computer behind it for my
> job. If we get this working, my wife may be able to telecommute a few
> days a week, but her place is an MS-only shop, and she would be using
> VPN.

> What sort of hardware would plug into the wall (RJ-11 telephone socket) and 
> provide one or more Cat-5 plugs for the Linux computers and an open Cat-5 
> plug so if my wife jacks he laptop into that port, then she can VPN in Win 
> simultaneously as I do e-mails 'n' stuff in Linux?

In my basement, the WAN port port on the Actiontec plugs in to the phone
jack via RJ-11. Be sure to use filters on all telephones that use this
same phone line.

The ethernet port on the Actiontec is plugged in to the external ethernet
on my Linux firewall, and the internal ethernet on the firewall plugs in
to a small 8-port ethernet switch. I have Winders, Linux, and
occasionally BSD, Solaris, & whatever plugged into the switch, along
with an 802.11b wireless bridge. I do NAT on the firewall, so everything
on the switch uses RFC 1918 private addressing.

At work, we have a Cisco VPN concentrator, and the Windows vpn client
connects to it fine going through NAT & the firewall. I've also set up a
LAN to LAN vpn to the concentrator using FreeSWAN on the firewall.

> Also, comments on a Cysco 678?

It worked great until it died. :( Cisco also discontinued them, and have
pretty well abandoned the lowest-priced CPE market.

--Stafford

I had Speakeasy over Covad for a year (then moved out of DSL range) and the 
service was excellent.  There were two times when I had outages of over a few 
minutes.  One time was when Qwest opened the box at the end of the street and 
crossed a wire (I lost the other phone line then too).  The other time was 
when a router near the DSLAM went into the big bit bucket in the sky.

Speakeasy was not cheap (I had SDSL), but I always found the service to be 
excellent.  When I had a routing problem (they didn't filter traceroute 
packets like Comcast seems to be doing), I could call tech support and email 
them a traceroute trace and they'd look at it while we were on the phone.  
Tech support that knew something!  I got followups on my problem reports 
within a few hours and usually another about 24 hours after the problem was 
fixed making sure the problem was really fixed.

Now, I've got Comcast and the service is not great.  At least the hour-long 
outages in the middle of the day seem to be gone.  Comcast's DNS is flaky, 
and getting email through their servers is difficult at best.  My download 
rate is consistently around 220kB/s, so I really cannot complain much about 
that.  Upload is not pretty though.

Best,
Kyle

On Thu, 16 Oct 2003, guy1656 wrote:

> This is what scares me - I don't (yet) know what a tracerout is (for example,)
> or how to extract one from a DSL device (internal or external.) This also
> means I don't know how much I don't know about DSL. I'm willing to learn, but
> I don't have much time to waste on getting this thing up & running fast and
> reliable.

  /usr/sbin/traceroute. Read all about it: 'man traceroute'. Works on
dial-up, too.

> But my question is, what's this gonna be like? I can get the physical
> 'thingie' (such as an Intel 3200 PCI card, which (I think) simply connects to
> the RJ-11 cable coming out of the wall. (So far so good) I've not yet seen a
> Cisco 678 - how would I hook that up?

  Next reading assignment: <http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/DSL-HOWTO/>.

> Would my wife be aple to jack in her (Win) laptop into one port, while I was
> already connected on some other port?

  Two items here:

  1) Build yourself a floppyfw firewall box on the least expensive hardware
you can find (old 386 with 16M RAM, video card, keyboard, two NICs and a
floppy drive is all you need) or buy a firewall appliance. Very, very
important. Do not stand naked on the 'Net; you'll be attacked and ravished
very quickly.

  2) Between your firewall and the working computers put a 4-port switch
(faster than a hub). You can plug in both your computer and your wife's
computer and each of you works independently on the dsl line.

HTH,

Rich

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Oct 16 10:36:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Oct 16 10:36:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DSL Modem & QWEST
In-Reply-To: <200310160735.39756.guy1656@ados.com>
References: <200310160735.39756.guy1656@ados.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0310160907110.1941@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 16 Oct 2003, guy1656 wrote:
> I was informed by mail that DSL is now available in my area.
>
> QWEST offers a device called an Actiontec 1520, but surfing blogs & install
> woes sites, seems to indicate that that unit is rather buggy.

Have you looked into alternative carriers?  I use Speakeasy and don't have
to directly deal with Qwest at all.  (It's not even clear how much of my
line is managed by Qwest.  Probably just the termination equipment and the
last-mile copper, but very little of the maintenance.)

> I currrently have a gateway cpu, a second computer behind it for my job.
> If we get this working, my wife may be able to telecommute a few days a
> week, but her place is an MS-only shop, and she would be using VPN.
[snip]
> What sort of hardware would plug into the wall (RJ-11 telephone socket) and
> provide one or more Cat-5 plugs for the Linux computers and an open Cat-5
> plug so if my wife jacks he laptop into that port, then she can VPN in Win
> simultaneously as I do e-mails 'n' stuff in Linux?

You definitely want some kind of firewall/gateway machine, probably doing
HAT (Host Address Translation).  If you go with such a solution (which
everyone here would surely recommend), you're going to need a firewall
device that can tunnel or pass the VPN bits.  That could be a simple DC
powered thingie that is small and silent and sucks very little power
(though I don't know which models from which manufacturers support which
VPN protocol) or it could be a low-powered PC (I use a 486/50 with 16MB
RAM) with a properly configured kernel and iptables (floppyfw will do it
handily -- no hard disk required).

J.

Though I've already deleted the message, I recall that one of
you was concerned about DSL or cable reliability because you
run a server. One solution is for two or more of you in the
same situation to host each other's services. For example,
each of you can host the others' content on your web
server. If your connection fails, people can get to you via
the other location(s).

From mikedela at theplatinumrule.com  Thu Oct 16 11:09:01 2003
From: mikedela at theplatinumrule.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Thu Oct 16 11:09:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Procmail and Spam
In-Reply-To: <1066324466.1455.161.camel@lana>
References: <1066324466.1455.161.camel@lana>
Message-ID: <1066327737.1871.3.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>

On Thu, 2003-10-16 at 10:14, Jon Jacob wrote:
> Okay, more procmail/spamassisin confusion.  After reading all the
> discussions about the subject, I decided to give it a try.  I got
> spamassisin working as it should, but I cannot figure out how to get the
> spam to go to a "caughtspam" folder.  I have a /etc/procmail file as
> follows:
> 
> DROPPRIVS=yes
> 
> :0fw
> * < 256000
> | spamc

Try adding something like this:
:0H
* ^X-Spam-Status: Yes
/wherever/caughtspam/

That checks the new header, and puts it into the spam bucket. By
default, procmail will deliver the mail if there's some kind of error.

-- 

Mike

In-Reply-To: <1066329631.24646.20.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1066329631.24646.20.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1066330277.1647.72.camel@sparticus>

On Thu, 2003-10-16 at 11:40, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> Okay, spamassassin is putting the spam in a folder nicely, but now how
> do I get the bayesian filter to parse that folder? 

I had exactly this problem. Looking at the file it turned out in my case
to be the way Exchange was munging the headers (very non-standard, for
sure). The solution is to "prep" the file before you process it with
SpamAssassin:


  $formail -ds < $reported_spam_file >> $tmp_reported_spam_file
  sa-learn --ham --mbox $tmp_reported_good_file

There's a lot of variables there (I like to do it this way to make it
easy for people after me to change the file locations if they need to).
Here's a "concrete" example:

  formail -ds < /var/spool/mail/spam >> /tmp/reported_spam
  sa-learn --spam --mbox /tmp/reported spam

Repeat in a similar fashion for the reported "good" mail, stir, and
serve on a warm plate!


Best,
--

| "Open For Business"     | Www: http://www.gencom.us        |

From deansuhr at carpedis.com  Thu Oct 16 11:53:02 2003
From: deansuhr at carpedis.com (Dean Suhr)
Date: Thu Oct 16 11:53:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DSL Modem & QWEST
In-Reply-To: <200310160956.30611.guy1656@ados.com>
Message-ID: <BBB436F9.59C73%deansuhr@carpedis.com>

>on 10/16/03 9:56, guy1656 at guy1656 at ados.com wrote:
> This is what scares me - I don't (yet) know what a tracerout is (for example,)
> or how to extract one from a DSL device (internal or external.) This also
> means I don't know how much I don't know about DSL. I'm willing to learn, but
> I don't have much time to waste on getting this thing up & running fast and
> reliable. 
> 

OK - let's have that beer first to just take a moment to relax.  Let's make
it simple and sweet - later you can do all of that fancy stuff. You just
want something that works, right?

Any service to your home will go down occasionally.  It's the ease of
recovery that is important. DSL reliability is a function of the local
copper and how many times a month some technician is  messing with the wire.
The same is true of cable but in my past experience cable's reliability as
an ISP is worse than the QWEST and choice of ISP solution with DSL (I use
EasyStreet - saving $5 per month on the cheapest ISP never appealed to me -
EasyStreet is commercial business class service, and they are local).

Setting up DSL is easy ...

1) Plug in microfilters (in-line cigar sized passive devices) into each
phone wire that shares the phone line that your DSL modem will be connected
to. QWEST will sent these to you when you sign up.  Total time - 2 minutes.

2) From the RJ-11 phone jack plug into the DSL modem.  I would strongly
suggest an external modem, not a card in a PC.  The external box can always
be on and is one less complex thing (like a PC with an internal card) to
fail or lock up.  Virtually all DSL modems have no or very little
configuration - you just plug them in and go. Watch the lights on the modem
- after it powers on the WAN (external to QWEST) light should flash while
the modem trains - this is kind of like the tone handshaking that you used
to do when you dialed out.  It will come on solid and you are connected to
the real world via DSL!  Total time 2 minutes.

3) Plug cable from the Ethernet modem into a Router (<$100 LinkSys is great
with 4-8 ports - you can get them with wireless 802.11 if you like, too).
Plug your computer's ethernet into the router.  Jump into the Network
control panel and set your IP to be DHCP, and the gateway to be the IP
assigned by the router manufacturer (read the manual - likely it's
192.168.0.1).  Use the browser on your computer to connect to the router by
typing in the IP, enter the external WAN IP that QWEST sent you into the
right box.  You're good to go.  Total time <5 minutes.
You should come back to this router config step and make sure that the ports
are all closed except those you are using (SMTP=25, if you have servers open
www=80, and POP=110).  You might need others for the VPN.

4) Connect other computers to the router and make sure that their IP is
assigned by the router (DHCP).  Total time per computer <2 minutes.

I know little about VPN's.  You might need a special port open and perhaps
some special hardware that you plug into the router between the computer and
the router.

When things go wrong (this is what I have my wife do).  Usually it's an
email failure.  I ask her if a web page can load.  If not I ask her if the
WAN and LAN lights are flashing (if not unplug and replug the DSL modem).
At this point its a quick call to the ISP to see that all is well on their
end. They can see up the line all the way to your DSL modem and you don't
need to know anything about trace routes. Usually you are not the first to
report a regional outage but sometimes they ask me to call QWEST. Usually
its a short DSL outage and everything comes back up OK.  Very occasionally I
have to unplug the DSL modem for a few seconds and plug it back in - just
because - it's kind of like a blue screen fatal error thing - it just
happens).

It's really not very complicated to set up or maintain.

Dean

From sasha_romanosky at yahoo.com  Thu Oct 16 12:01:02 2003
From: sasha_romanosky at yahoo.com (Sasha Romanosky)
Date: Thu Oct 16 12:01:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] more hardware trouble
In-Reply-To: <86brshvb3n.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <005e01c39417$c34762e0$6401a8c0@laptop>

fwiw, 

I went through something very similar to this a couple of days ago. On
power up, the fans would spin, but no beeps, no post, no video. For some
reason taking the memory out at least made it beep. The problem was the
CPU. This behavior was identical wether it was the broken CPU (that I
had just purchased) or when trying a CPU from another machine that was
known _not_ to work with the motherboard. 

As well, in the past I had trouble getting a machine to POST and it
turned out to be that the motherboard bios default settings required the
cpu fan connected and running. I think what I had was a cpu fan that was
working but not connected to the "cpu fan" MB connector. In the bios,
there was a way to disable this safety feature. But how to get to the
bios in the first place? Well, in a very small font on some obscure page
of the motherboard manual, it mentioned that you could cirumvent this
feature by holding down the SHIFT key (or something) on boot.

Hope this helps. 
sasha

Has anyone gotten the Cisco DSL 504 or the model that will be used in
St. Helens to work under Linux without bridging it?  

I guess if you do that you have to let the router control your network
numbering and perhaps the firewall also.  On the other hand, I think 
the only way to reprogram the 504 is through the serial port and
provided cable.  I suppose it could be left wide open as far as
firewalling where it could then be plugged into a router with 
a switch off it for the lan.  But MS-NAT and masquerading 
as far as I know are incompatible.  This becomes a problem 
on networks that already have a router/firewall where 
one ends up having to abandon that firewall/router 
and firewall every single workstation directly.

-----------         ------------
|         |         |          |   ----------                 /-------\
| DSL-504 |---------| Linux    |---| switch |-----6 lines-----|  LAN  |
|         |         | router/  |   ----------                 \-------/ 
-----------         | firewall |
                    |          |
                    ------------ 

The latter configuration without bridging should be 
possible.  The only difference with my subnet is a 
switch between the DSL-504 and Linux 
routers/firewalls.  If I were to go to a second 
line of DSL, I'd consider dropping the subnet.
Chances are I'd probably have to bridge twice 
though.  Bridging is $5/month where minimum you
lose an ip out of the Opus pool and end up paying
at least $5/month for one static one.

A little off topic...  I've asked for POTSless DSL,
but Opus says the phone company requires dialtone
where there are times CenturyTel will take one 
copper pair that appears to be unused to replace
another one that is broken or lossy, dialtone 
being the determinant of which lines can be 
used for the patch.  If they'd just keep track
of line use or use a DSL detector, there 
wouldn't be a problem.  Thing is, all the
lines coming to my place can't be used by
anyone else very easily without someone 
digging up the cable where I thought phone
companies tried to maintain clean runs to
a central box.

>>>>> "Michael" == Michael C Robinson <michael at goose.robinson-west.com> writes:

Michael> Does anyone know how to completely erase spam instead of
Michael> doing a standard delete?

Yes, I do.  

After each spam message arrives, power down your computer.  Following
good ESD practices remove the hard disks from your computer, then go
to a clearing away from dry grass or brush, scrape the surface down to
a mineral soil in a 3 foot radius.  Place the drive on the ground,
pour a half-cup or so of thermite on top of the drive.  Taking proper
care, ignite the thermite, then stand well back while your spam is
_completely_ erased.

From Anderson.Robert at menlolog.com  Thu Oct 16 14:59:02 2003

Message-ID: <25E622D843625C40BE0EEC150B437C1B0173EF5E@cnfqe029.cnf.prod.cnf.com>

It's probably not a good idea to erase spam completely, as opposed to
filtering it. Spamassassin will produce false positives as well as false
negatives. It would be wise to filter, and then review the filtered messages
before deleting. But if you have faith in Spamassassin, the method mentioned
below will work.

-Rob Anderson

PASA Meeting 21 Oct 2003
========================

PASA, the Portland Area Sys Admins, invites you to our next meeting to 
be held on Tuesday, the 21st of October 2003 with Matrix Networks.
Please visit our meetings page at and RSVP so we can have an estimate of
attendance.  The RSVP is NOT mandatory, but appreciated!
See our meetings page for information and RSVP:
http://pasa.portland.or.us/meetings

Schedule
=========

7:00 - 7:30 Pizza / Welcome / Introductions
7:30 - 8:00 Nigel Ballard - Director of Wireless. Discusses Wi-Fi for
	    corporate users,convenience over security worries.
8:00 - 8:30 Mark Bilton-Smith - IP Telephony Sales. Discusses the 
	    benefits of migrating existing systems or installing new systems
            using a wholly IP-based phone solution.
8:30 - 10:00 Networking, discussion over beer. Location TBD.
About Matrix Networks
=====================

Matrix Networks has been serving Portland's voice and data needs for
thelast twenty years. Within the last two years Matrix has had a shift
of emphasis as the market has moved. New directions involve installing
pointto point wireless links thus circumventing lengthy and costly fiber
orcopper runs between buildings. Matrix has also been providing Wi-Fi
solutions for enterprises, hotels and marinas and more recently
IP-basedphone solutions have provided a new and exciting focus for the
staff at Matrix


About PASA 
==========

PASA is an informal support group for Portland Area Systems
Administrators. We currently have members from the east and west sides,
Vancouver, and Portland proper. Members are UNIX, NT, NetWare, and Network
administrators -- sometimes a combination of the four. Someday we may
get around to building some structure into the group, but that hasn't
happened yet. (Of course, there are no membership dues either.)

We are also an official USENIX SAGE local group.

From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)

In-Reply-To: <200310161000.28236.carla@bratgrrl.com>

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0310161453480.3477@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 16 Oct 2003, Carla Schroder wrote:

> If a client wants to run an important Web site over their DSL, I try
> to talk them out of it. Web hosting services are cheap, and a lot
> less hassle. [...] Of course this is for ordinary people, not uber
> geeks like Heinlein. :)

I'd agree with the assessment that any "important Web site" ought to
be hosted on a professionally managed network -- but it does beg the
question of what "important" means. Other questions present
themselves:

* can the site owner stand an hour or two of downtime now and then?

* is the site not terribly bandwidth-intensive?

* will the site owner promise never to post his/her URL on
  Slashdot? :-)

* does the site owner or his/her hired geek like doing the hands-on
  work of maintain the site's server?

* is the flexibility of adding more software options or bells/whistles
  more important than raw platform stability?

For those who answer "yes" to the above, then DSL might be
appropriate...

-- Paul "uber geek, 'cause Carla said so" Heinlein
   <heinlein at madboa.com>

From sandy at herring.org  Thu Oct 16 15:22:01 2003
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Thu Oct 16 15:22:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Procmail and Spam
In-Reply-To: <1066327737.1871.3.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <1066324466.1455.161.camel@lana> <1066327737.1871.3.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <20031016222121.GA29186@kippered.herring.org>

Here's what I do...


## Call SpamAssassin
:0fw: spamassassin.lock
* < 256000
| spamassassin -a

# Work around procmail bug: any output on stderr will cause the "F" in "From"
# to be dropped.  This will re-add it.
:0
* ^^rom[ ]
{
  LOG="*** Dropped F off From_ header! Fixing up. "

  :0 fhw
  | sed -e '1s/^/F/'
}

## Flagged as SPAM by spamassassin?
:0:
* ^X-Spam-Status: Yes
spam


Alter to taste for system-wideness.

hth,
Sandy

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Thu Oct 16 15:36:02 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Thu Oct 16 15:36:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Projector, configuration
Message-ID: <20031016223454.GA565@gate.kl-ic.com>

Yesterday I posted one of my long rambles about a "great opportunity
for computer projectors and Linux."

NOT!  There are tools coming into place to do this.  The reason Zot
has problems with his ancient 1993 Proxima is that it is too old to
have "DDC", Display Data channel, which is display configuration
data coming up pins 12 and 15 of the HD-15 cable.  DDC showed up
around 1994 or so.

So, sorry for the false alarm - there is no business here.  Sigh.

I did find something useful.  This is a page that should be posted near
every computer projector:

http://www.infocus.com/service/tech_library/laptop_chart.asp?site_lang=1&site_region=1&

This describes the key sequences to activate the external video port on
every laptop out there - hundreds of models by manufacturer.  With that,
and some XConfig frobbing, you should be able to get most projectors to
work.

---

On a related note:

I talked with Keith Packard a bit at Advanced Topics last night. 
KeithP is one of the principle designers of X-Windows.  He is currently
moving most of X functionality out of user space and into the kernel,
which Linus Torvalds likes but the BSD community hates.  Much fireworks
going on.  Is this a fork?  Who is the forker, and who is the forkee? 

Keith says his new code will be ready around the beginning of 2004,
is very small and fast (it recompiles on his laptop in about 10 seconds)
and will make things like laptop ACPI work great.  It will handle
projectors with different video formats just fine.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Thu Oct 16 17:05:02 2003
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Thu Oct 16 17:05:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DSL Modem & QWEST
In-Reply-To: <200310160735.39756.guy1656@ados.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0310161641400.17704-100000@aluminum.bavariati.org>

On Thu, 16 Oct 2003, guy1656 wrote:
[DSL, VPN, RSN]
> What sort of hardware would plug into the wall (RJ-11 telephone socket) and
> provide one or more Cat-5 plugs for the Linux computers and an open Cat-5
> plug so if my wife jacks he laptop into that port, then she can VPN in Win
> simultaneously as I do e-mails 'n' stuff in Linux?

A DSL modem/router, a firewall appliance and a network hub or switch.
Many firewalls have built-in network switches, saving a box.

So, it'd be like this:
computer -\
computer - switch -- firewall -- modem -- phone-line
computer -/

Most firewalls handle the VPN stuff OK.  You might want to check and see
if it's a PPTP, IPSec or some other sort of VPN, and then Google or
something to see if the firewall you're using handles it.

I've had good luck with the LinkSys BEFSR41, which has a built-in 4-port
switch. Just promise me, whatever firewall you get,
*don't forget to install the latest firmware upgrade.*

> Also, comments on a Cysco 678?

I have one left over from when I had QWest DSL, with Pacifier as my ISP.
Worked like a champ.

As for cable, well, I miss DSL.

Good luck,
  Aaron

From kyle at silverbeach.net  Thu Oct 16 17:23:02 2003
From: kyle at silverbeach.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Thu Oct 16 17:23:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Projector, configuration
In-Reply-To: <20031016223454.GA565@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20031016223454.GA565@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <200310161722.04853.kyle@silverbeach.net>

On Thursday 16 October 2003 15:34, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
[snip]
> On a related note:
>
> I talked with Keith Packard a bit at Advanced Topics last night.
> KeithP is one of the principle designers of X-Windows.  He is currently
> moving most of X functionality out of user space and into the kernel,
> which Linus Torvalds likes but the BSD community hates.  Much fireworks
> going on.  Is this a fork?  Who is the forker, and who is the forkee?

Que???!??  Is any of this appearing in any mailing lists? (other than this one 
of course).  It really seems like X is starting to implode.  Sigh.

Whoa!  This seems like a 180-degree turn for Linus.  He and his kernel 
henchmen have very consistently said that the more code in user space, the 
merrier.  Graphics was one of the examples they used.  DRI was not that 
popular with the kernel folks until the DRI people showed what was needed 
otherwise.  Things are put in the kernel only when there is a strong reason 
to do so.  See the removal of the in-kernel HTTP server.  It proved a point, 
but Apache has sped up a lot in the last couple of years and the need for 
such a server has diminished.

What exactly is Keith putting in the kernel?  I can see all the card-specific 
register frobbing maybe.  DRI has some security points that make it a little 
than exciting (from some things I've read, not personal experience).

(might need to replace DRI with DRM, it is the direct rendering 
interface/manager or something, _NOT_ digital rights mismanagement.)

I tend to agree with Linus' original position that this kind of stuff stays 
outside the kernel.

I also tend to think that the X-protocol has some very nice features and some 
really annoying problems.  I think it needs some deep reengineering, but keep 
some of the core concepts.  Networks are faster and processors are two or 
three orders of magnitude faster than what X started with.  That makes for 
different tradeoffs and makes some things really frustrating and some things 
possible that were not before.

Best,
Kyle

On Thu, 16 Oct 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Does anyone know what I need to configure (and how) so that when I
> issue 'shutdown -h now' the system powers off automatically at the
> end?

While poweroff or for that matter "shutdown -h now" will power the system
off, it still needs to be supported by the BIOS and after that the kernel.

If APM, then you need the apm modules loaded.  I forget what the APIC
equivalent might be.

	 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310161824190.19411@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1066357661.2703.4.camel@localhost.localdomain>

or you could compile the following code into setuid-root executable
called 'emacs'.....

--------------------------------
#include <unistd.h>
#include <sys/reboot.h>
#include <stdio.h>

/* see reboot(2) for details on this */


int main(void)
{
	unsigned int ttl = 0xA;
	(void)printf("The system will power off in %d seconds\n\a",ttl);
	sync();
	sync();
	sync(); /* a third one for good luck */
	(void)sleep(ttl);
	reboot(0x4321FEDC);
	return 0x0;
}
--------------------------------------

On Thu, 2003-10-16 at 14:48, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> 
> On Thu, 16 Oct 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> > Do I need to keep the spam as it comes in to my folder or can I toss it?
> 
> No reason not to.
> 
> > Does anyone know how to completely erase spam instead of doing a
> > standard delete?
> 
> No reason to even write it to disk, if you really trust SpamAssassin so
> much.
> 
> :0:
> * ^X-Spam-Status: Yes
> /dev/null
> 
Wouldn't another trick be writing spam to a ramdisk instead of hard
disk so that it's easy to erase completely?  That way if there's
a false positive it's easy to catch while any spam doesn't have
to be cleared with anything beyond the standard rm.  It's not
a good idea to just delete some spam from the standpoint it
may accumulate being of a nature that one wouldn't want a
forensics team to find it from the standpoint it could be deemed
illegal with there being no way to show that it's unsolicited.
Besides, a virus could be spam where even deleting it a clever
cracker may find a way to activate the deleted file considering
that perhaps only the first bit of the file is potentially 
gone.

On Thursday 16 October 2003 20:09, Billy Dimaculangan wrote:
> I have a simple question on shell scripting.

Bill,
Do:
  man cut
for all the details

example:
cat filename | cut -d':' -f1

cut is pretty straightforward to use. You can specify the column delimiter and 
then the field you want.  Play with it a bit and you should get the hang of 
it.

Scott

As for chaining squid, IIRC it is pretty easy.  Just looked it up in
squid.conf.default:

#  TAG: cache_peer
#       To specify other caches in a hierarchy, use the format:
#
#               cache_peer hostname type http_port icp_port
#
#       For example,
#
#       #                                        proxy  icp
#       #                                        proxy  icp
#       #          hostname             type     port   port  options
#       #          -------------------- -------- ----- -----  -----------
#       cache_peer parent.foo.net       parent    3128  3130  [proxy-only]
#       cache_peer sib1.foo.net         sibling   3128  3130  [proxy-only]
#       cache_peer sib2.foo.net         sibling   3128  3130  [proxy-only]
#
#             type:  either 'parent', 'sibling', or 'multicast'.
#
#       proxy_port:  The port number where the cache listens for proxy
#                    requests.
#
#         icp_port:  Used for querying neighbor caches about
#                    objects.  To have a non-ICP neighbor
#                    specify '7' for the ICP port and make sure the
#                    neighbor machine has the UDP echo port
#                    enabled in its /etc/inetd.conf file.
#
#           options: proxy-only
#                    weight=n
#                    ttl=n
#                    no-query
#                    default
#                    round-robin
#                    multicast-responder
#                    closest-only
#                    no-digest
#                    no-netdb-exchange
#                    no-delay
#                    login=user:password | PASS | *:password
#                    connect-timeout=nn
#                    digest-url=url
#                    allow-miss
#                    max-conn
#                    htcp
#                    carp-load-factor
#
#                    use 'proxy-only' to specify that objects fetched
#                    from this cache should not be saved locally.
#
#                    use 'weight=n' to specify a weighted parent.
#                    The weight must be an integer.  The default weight
#                    is 1, larger weights are favored more.
#
#                    use 'ttl=n' to specify a IP multicast TTL to use
#                    when sending an ICP queries to this address.
#                    Only useful when sending to a multicast group.
#                    Because we don't accept ICP replies from random
#                    hosts, you must configure other group members as
#                    peers with the 'multicast-responder' option below.
#
#                    use 'no-query' to NOT send ICP queries to this
#                    neighbor.
#
#                    use 'default' if this is a parent cache which can
#                    be used as a "last-resort." You should probably
#                    only use 'default' in situations where you cannot
#                    use ICP with your parent cache(s).
#
#                    use 'round-robin' to define a set of parents which
#                    should be used in a round-robin fashion in the
#                    absence of any ICP queries.
#
#                    'multicast-responder' indicates that the named peer
#                    is a member of a multicast group.  ICP queries will
#                    not be sent directly to the peer, but ICP replies
#                    will be accepted from it.
#
#                    'closest-only' indicates that, for ICP_OP_MISS
#                    replies, we'll only forward CLOSEST_PARENT_MISSes
#                    and never FIRST_PARENT_MISSes.
#
#                    use 'no-digest' to NOT request cache digests from
#                    this neighbor.
#
#                    'no-netdb-exchange' disables requesting ICMP
#                    RTT database (NetDB) from the neighbor.
#
#                    use 'no-delay' to prevent access to this neighbor
#                    from influencing the delay pools.
#
#                    use 'login=user:password' if this is a personal/workgroup
#                    proxy and your parent requires proxy authentication.
#                    Note: The string can include URL escapes (i.e. %20 for
#                    spaces). This also means that % must be written as %%.
#
#                    use 'login=PASS' if users must authenticate against
#                    the upstream proxy. This will pass the users credentials
#                    as they are to the peer proxy. This only works for the
#                    Basic HTTP authentication sheme. Note: To combine this
#                    with proxy_auth both proxies must share the same user
#                    database as HTTP only allows for one proxy login.
#                    Also be warned that this will expose your users proxy
#                    password to the peer. USE WITH CAUTION
#
#                    use 'login=*:password' to pass the username to the
#                    upstream cache, but with a fixed password. This is meant
#                    to be used when the peer is in another administrative
#                    domain, but it is still needed to identify each user.
#                    The star can optionally be followed by some extra
#                    information which is added to the username. This can
#                    be used to identify this proxy to the peer, similar to
#                    the login=username:password option above.
#
#                    use 'connect-timeout=nn' to specify a peer
#                    specific connect timeout (also see the
#                    peer_connect_timeout directive)
#
#                    use 'digest-url=url' to tell Squid to fetch the cache
#                    digest (if digests are enabled) for this host from
#                    the specified URL rather than the Squid default
#                    location.
#
#                    use 'allow-miss' to disable Squid's use of only-if-cached
#                    when forwarding requests to siblings. This is primarily
#                    useful when icp_hit_stale is used by the sibling. To
#                    extensive use of this option may result in forwarding
#                    loops, and you should avoid having two-way peerings
#                    with this option. (for example to deny peer usage on
#                    requests from peer by denying cache_peer_access if the
#                    source is a peer)
#
#                    use 'max-conn' to limit the amount of connections Squid
#                    may open to this peer.
#
#                    use 'htcp' to send HTCP, instead of ICP, queries
#                    to the neighbor.  You probably also want to
#                    set the "icp port" to 4827 instead of 3130.
#
#                    use 'carp-load-factor=f' to define a parent
#                    cache as one participating in a CARP array.
#                    The 'f' values for all CARP parents must add
#                    up to 1.0.
#
#
#       NOTE: non-ICP/HTCP neighbors must be specified as 'parent'.
#
#Default:
# none

The documentation in that file is nothing if not complete.  :-)

From mikedela at ipns.com  Thu Oct 16 22:16:02 2003
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Thu Oct 16 22:16:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] what about this raid checking script?
Message-ID: <D8QOA5SPHD4UPWU4WQNMH96OJJH4393.3f8f7ae4@miked>

#/bin/bash
LOG_FILE=/tmp/raid_check_$$
SYSTEM=`uname --nodename`
MAILTO='mikedela at ipns.com'
echo "The $SYSTEM system has RAID failures on it." >> $LOG_FILE
echo "Below is the output from /proc/mdstat" >> $LOG_FILE
echo "===========================================" >> $LOG_FILE
cat /proc/mdstat | egrep 'md.*raid' | fgrep -i '(f)' >> $LOG_FILE
if [ $? -eq 0 ]
then
cat /proc/mdstat >> $LOG_FILE
echo "===========================================" >> $LOG_FILE
mail -s 'URGENT: RAID disk failure detected' $MAILTO < $LOG_FILE
fi

rm -f >> $LOG_FILE
exit 0


So far, I can tell that it does not delete the LOG-FILE that it makes in /tmp 
when I run it manually.

From ramunro1 at ix.netcom.com  Thu Oct 16 22:27:02 2003
From: ramunro1 at ix.netcom.com (Robert Munro)
Date: Thu Oct 16 22:27:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Using spamassassin's tagging
In-Reply-To: <20031017040101.25215.37464.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20031017040101.25215.37464.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <1066368376.3467.43.camel@griffin>

On Thu, 2003-10-16 at 21:01, "Michael C. Robinson" wrote:
> 
> On Thu, 2003-10-16 at 14:48, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> > 
> > On Thu, 16 Oct 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> > > Do I need to keep the spam as it comes in to my folder or can I toss it?
> > 
> > No reason not to.
> > 
> > > Does anyone know how to completely erase spam instead of doing a
> > > standard delete?
> > 
> > No reason to even write it to disk, if you really trust SpamAssassin so
> > much.
> > 
> > :0:
> > * ^X-Spam-Status: Yes
> > /dev/null
> > 
> Wouldn't another trick be writing spam to a ramdisk instead of hard
> disk so that it's easy to erase completely?

This is a good idea!  I liked it so much that I've done it in Mandrake
9.1 using Evolution with SpamAssassin.  The key is that /tmp is in RAM.

Here's my *one* filter in Evolution:

Rule name: SpamAssassin    Execute actions -> if all criteria are met

If +Add:  Pipe Message to Shell Command -> /home/[uid]/spam-filter.sh ,
does not return -> 0 

Then +Add:  Move to Folder -> "Spam" in "Local Folders"

That's the entire filter.  Here's the script /home/[uid]/spam-filter.sh,
as I'm using the Razor agent and reporting spam back to its databases...

* * *

export LANG=en_US
spamassassin -ea > /home/[uid]/test.txt
let rc=$?
if [ ${rc}!=0 ] ; then
        touch /tmp/mbox
        spamassassin -r < /home/[uid]/test.txt
fi
exit ${rc}

* * *

The "[uid]" must be replaced with your userid, both above and elsewhere.

The "touch" command creates the mailbox file the first time following a
reboot.  Afterwards, it doesn't do anything but update the access time.

To test this, I allocated /tmp/mbox using touch, then tested the script:

/home/[uid]/spam-filter.sh < spam.txt > /tmp/mbox

That worked (spam.txt I use as input to sa-learn), so I finished it up:

rm /home/[uid]/evolution/local/Spam/mbox

ln -s /tmp/mbox /home/[uid]/evolution/local/Spam/mbox

I moved the contents of my Evolution Spam folder to /tmp/mbox, shutdown
and restarted Evolution.  This works, so I can look for false-positives.

Regards,
Robert Munro

From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Thu Oct 16 23:14:02 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Thu Oct 16 23:14:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Using spamassassin's tagging
In-Reply-To: <1066368376.3467.43.camel@griffin>
References: <20031017040101.25215.37464.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> 
	<1066368376.3467.43.camel@griffin>
Message-ID: <1066371193.27978.128.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

How do you program the filter in evolution and what should the
procmail settings be to do this?

> > Wouldn't another trick be writing spam to a ramdisk instead of hard
> > disk so that it's easy to erase completely?
> 
> This is a good idea!  I liked it so much that I've done it in Mandrake
> 9.1 using Evolution with SpamAssassin.  The key is that /tmp is in RAM.
> 
> Here's my *one* filter in Evolution:
> 
> Rule name: SpamAssassin    Execute actions -> if all criteria are met
> 
> If +Add:  Pipe Message to Shell Command -> /home/[uid]/spam-filter.sh ,
> does not return -> 0 
> 
> Then +Add:  Move to Folder -> "Spam" in "Local Folders"
> 
> That's the entire filter.  Here's the script /home/[uid]/spam-filter.sh,
> as I'm using the Razor agent and reporting spam back to its databases...
> 
> * * *
> 
> export LANG=en_US
> spamassassin -ea > /home/[uid]/test.txt
> let rc=$?
> if [ ${rc}!=0 ] ; then
>         touch /tmp/mbox
>         spamassassin -r < /home/[uid]/test.txt
> fi
> exit ${rc}
> 
> * * *
> 
> The "[uid]" must be replaced with your userid, both above and elsewhere.
> 
> The "touch" command creates the mailbox file the first time following a
> reboot.  Afterwards, it doesn't do anything but update the access time.
> 
> To test this, I allocated /tmp/mbox using touch, then tested the script:
> 
> /home/[uid]/spam-filter.sh < spam.txt > /tmp/mbox
> 
> That worked (spam.txt I use as input to sa-learn), so I finished it up:
> 
> rm /home/[uid]/evolution/local/Spam/mbox
> 
> ln -s /tmp/mbox /home/[uid]/evolution/local/Spam/mbox
> 
> I moved the contents of my Evolution Spam folder to /tmp/mbox, shutdown
> and restarted Evolution.  This works, so I can look for false-positives.
> 
> Regards,
> Robert Munro
> 
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

On Thu, 2003-10-16 at 21:00, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> Not entirely related to this post but I've noticed that ever since I 
> upgraded my system to SuSE 8.2, I cannot reboot my system anymore with 
> the "reboot" command. When I issue a "reboot" command the system goes 
> into runlevel 6 and all of the processes shutdown but the system never 
> gets to the part where it actually reboots. Instead it just hange with 
> the HD activity LED on constantly. I have to press the reset button to 
> get my system too reboot.
> 
> I've never seen this problem with Linux before and this is on a system 
> that I've had for nearly 3 years and it has run nothing but Linux and 
> I've never had any problems with the box. I don' reboot very often and 
> so I guess I didn't notice this feature before. If I do a halt my 
> system goes down cleanly and powers down so I'm left wondering what a 
> reboot does differently and why it's broken all of a sudden.

Those are two different signals to the BIOS.  My guess is that you have
a ...hmm... broken ?? errr... older BIOS?  The new default kernel was
probably compiled without support for your ummm... particular BIOS.  You
might want to try updating your BIOS before changing your kernel.  See
your motherboard manufacturer's web site for more information.  Warning,
this usually entails booting into DOS and can be a very scary
experience. 

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

On Thu, 16 Oct 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> How many people from Beaverton en route to Vancouver have to go through
> downtown Portland?
[snip]
> Even just a two lane road from 30 and Cornelius Pass across Sauvie's
> Island to Vancouver involving the construction of two bridges, one of
> which has to be built anyways to replace a failing one, would alleviate
> a lot of traffic congestion.

More roads to not alleviate congestion.  This is one of those times where
most folks' common sense is absolutely contradictory to the real world
(sort of like the common sense notion that things must touch in order to
have mechanical effect on each other which was shattered by Newton).

The good people of Atlanta, Los Angeles, Seattle, and Detroit can tell you
all about how much their congestion was relieved by new road construction.

> Doing a two lane road limits the number of cars going through there
> which alleviates pollution concerns some.  Especially if we start using
> cleaner cars which we should be doing anyways.

Fuel efficiency and emissions are red herrings.  The real problem is the
automobile itself.  They do not operate on a human scale and as a result
destroy the basic mechanisms of human civilization.  They keep people
apart spatially and (partially as a result of the spatial separation)
psychologically.  Their scale of operation (high speed and huge size)
removes the practical need for closely constructed, fully functioning
neighborhoods.  (Why should we have a grocery store here when there's a
megamart five miles down the road?)  This creates an expectation of
convenience and a sense of entitlement to that which is not practically
available.  The constant travelling also decreases the number of
opportunities for chance encounters with other human beings and virtually
eliminates familiarity with one's neighbors and the need to get along well
with those whom one would not normally seek out as companions.

I could go on.  This only brushes the surface.

> There's a lot of beautification going on, but where's the parking and
> how much is being done to establish needed facilities?

In my opinion, there's far too much parking downtown.  There's probably
more parking downtown than actual ground acreage.

> Highway 30 is at four lanes, 3000 cars or so a day pass Scappoose.
> Perhaps it would have been better to add mass transit instead of doing
> the road expansion project or better to extend Cornelius Pass to
> Vancouver for all the folks going around.

Mass transit would have been a great idea, but the people of Columbia
County have been totally unreceptive to the idea of building a rail
system.

> The top part of the circle around Portland, the road from Cornelius Pass
> to Vancouver, is missing.

Why would you want people to go AROUND the city?  To continue the illusion
that they live in the country?

> Columbia County is the poorest in the state probably due largely to
> having zero higher education institutions and also due to poor access to
> Vancouver, which is quite frankly closer than Portland as the crow
> flies.

The crow is not a human being.  Geography is more than just distance on a
map.  There's a big fucking river there.  Respect that.  It's not just
some obstacle for you overcome and subdue.

> Scappoose has enough density, not to mention the wealthiest Fred Meyer's
> in the state thanks to the traffic on 30, mass transit is becoming a
> realistic idea.

The Fred Meyer is probably part of the reason it's such a poor county.
Fred Meyer can only exist because people drive there to do all their
shopping in one place.  We know what this does to small, local businesses
that could be filling those niches.

Here's another case where efficiency is totally destructive.  An
"inefficient" system with dozens of shops (one in each neighborhood) would
employ more people and, being owner-operated, keep the profits in the
county.

I don't know whether to laugh or cry when someone says that a Fred Meyer
or a Wal-Mart or Target or something is coming into town and calls it
"investment in the community" and says that's a good thing.  Nothing could
be worse for a community than to have a new shop built that is owned by
someone outside the area.  The argument comes that the new establishment
will employ local people and that's good for the local economy.  However,
the fact is that it is very much a financial INVESTMENT and a good
investment is one from which you draw more than you put in.  The intent of
the remote owners is to suck more money out of the community than they
put into it.

> It's a better idea than those stupid streetcars put down the center of
> clogged arteries for the benefit of the rich living in new riverfront
> condos just south of downtown Portland.

Well, streetcars down the center of clogged arteries ARE a good idea.

However, the new South Waterfront (as they're now calling John's Landing,
I guess) is the worst idea EVER.  It will be nothing buy high priced
housing and fancy new office space for upscale business.  The public
transit is necessary only to get the poor people in for working in the
shops to serve the rich people.  And there is enough geographic separation
between that and the real downtown area to keep the homeless people from
accidentally wandering in.  And if they try to ride the streetcar, well,
that's why we have transit cops.

> Mass transit systems either need to be up off the streets or under them,
> but for gosh sakes not on them.

They need to REPLACE private transportation on the same routes.

The streets should be for people operating at a human scale (pedestrians,
cyclists, scooters or the like for the elderly and otherwise infirm) and
the occassional commercial or emergency vehicle.  Anybody travelling
beyond that scale in speed or size should be on a rail.

> They also need to be fast enough to matter without too many stops.  The
> streetcars are cars that need a special light guage rail, how stupid.

And WHY is that stupid?  It's cheaper to maintain, provides a smoother
ride, runs with greater mechanical efficiency, and is less prone to
accidental collision than a vehicle on a paved road with pneumatic tires.

> Get out more Jeme, be more realistic.

I get out a whole lot.  And I see more of the city than you can get from
behind your TV-like windshield.

I think you're shooting from the hip and working from your internal
notions of what things SHOULD be like without having any experience what
how these things really work.  Building more roads has NEVER decreased
congestion.  Adding lanes actually DECREASES average speeds due to
turbulence effects from cars changing lanes to jockey for position.
Auto emissions are nothing compared to the enormous emissions of
refineries, tire plants, and road run-off from leaky machines plus the
ridiculous waste of junkyards, tire dumps, drive-thru disposables, etc.
etc. etc...  It's a nightmare stream of endless garbage and poison with
exactly one very short generation of usefulness.

Grow up and get responsible.  We've got lots of work to do to shape this
place up for our great-great-grandchildren and their
great-great-grandchildren.

As the Iriquois law stated (as recorded by Thomas Jefferson, a great
admirer of the Iriquois):  Make every decision with respect for its impact
on the seventh generation, even if this requires skin as thick as the bark
of a pine.

In other words, butch up, pussy... it's not your world to trash.  So get
out there and work harder for the people that really matter:  those who
will not be born for two hundred years.

J.

From raanders at acm.org  Fri Oct 17 05:22:02 2003
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Fri Oct 17 05:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DSL Modem & QWEST
In-Reply-To: <200310160735.39756.guy1656@ados.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0310170508440.8120-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

I've read all the follow ups to this but didn't want to get lost in the 
thread.

I work for an ISP that uses Qwest as one of it's DSL providers.  Here are 
some points in no particular order.

*  Sometimes Qwest DSL connections just go down and require either a power 
   cycle on the CPE and/or a bounce of the circuit in our router.  This 
   has become such an issue that a few routers (not Cisco) include a 
   bounce function as part of the OS (Redback I seem to remember.)
      We monitor anyone that asks and is not blocking pings and get pager 
   alerts when a DSL line goes down ie. no ping response.  Usually with 
   in minutes we bounce the circuit.  (An automated circuit bounce process
   is in the works.)

*  A Firewall (doing NAT) behind a CPE doing NAT (routed circuit) sucks 
   for speed.  A Firewall behind CPE with a bridged circuit is a good 
   thing.  I know as my home DSL line was the former for awhile.

*  Actiontec 1520 has a web based setup on the LAN side and takes about
   5 minutes to talk a slightly clueful customer through.

*  Cisco 678 (675) has a management cable and text base interface.  Don't
   go that way with the home user if possible.  Qwest no longer provides 
   Ciscos.

*  Most off the (local) shelf firewall/routers are not very efficent.  
   Some eating up to 25% of your bandwidth.  Well let me qualify that
    - Linksys on a direct wireless connection.  I haven't tested a Linksys
   on a DSL line.
      I use an Asante FR3004C with serial port.  If DSL (not the phone 
   line goes down) I power up the modem connected to the serial port.  
   Change one setting in the Asante, restart it, and I'm back online 
   though a bit slower.

*  SDSL trumps ADSL.  Costs more but if you're going to do any kind of 
   hosting on the DSL you'll appreciate it.

*  Qwest is Qwest.  We have a Qwest technician as a customer.  He thinks 
   we provide better ISP and technical services than he gets from Qwest.


Rod
-- 
  "Open Source Software - Sometimes you get more than you paid for..."

From baloo at ursine.ca  Fri Oct 17 08:19:02 2003
From: baloo at ursine.ca (Paul Johnson)
Date: Fri Oct 17 08:19:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [baloo@ursine.ca: exim4: How to stop viruses at SMTP time]
Message-ID: <20031017151854.GA20930@ursine.ca>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

For those who don't have the time to read this now, or who want to
bookmark it, it's on my website.  http://ursine.ca/~baloo/

The Virus Infected Blackhole List is dead, both mine and the one that
used to be vbl.messagelabs.com.  So what's a postmaster to do?

This is my new solution to the Virus Infected Blackhole List.  I got
tired of maintaining it.  That's a damn good trick, since as of this
writing (10/17/2003), I have a crappy job watching a door 10 hours a
night, four nights a week, at a children's hospital and you *need*
something to keep your mind occupied and off the *increadably*
depressing surroundings.

Start off with exim4-daemon-heavy, clamav-daemon, and
clamav-freshclam.  It's in sid.  If you're using woody, go find a
backport, please do not pin, as this *will* break your system.  Go
read the debian-user archives for why.

Get it working.  If you successfully installed it, it's probably
working.

Edit /etc/exim4/conf.d/acl/40_exim4-config_check_data and add this
before the accept comment at the end.

  # Deny viruses.

  deny message = Message contains malware or a virus ($malware_name).
       log_message = $sender_host_address tried sending $malware_name
       demime = *
       malware = *

Now, go edit /etc/exim4/conf.d/main/01_exim4-config_listmacros and add
this below the banner at the top.

  av_scanner = clamd:/var/run/clamd.ctl

Restart exim4.  Congratulations, you now bounce viruses at SMTP time.

- --

  `-  Debian - when you have better things to do than fix a system
