From bthoen at gisnet.com  Fri Oct 17 09:43:02 2003
From: bthoen at gisnet.com (B. Thoen)
Date: Fri Oct 17 09:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Reporting SPAM (was Using spamassassin's tagging...)
In-Reply-To: <20031017152040.GC20930@ursine.ca>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0310170913230.2892-100000@gisnet.com>

On Fri, 17 Oct 2003, Paul Johnson wrote:

> On Fri, Oct 17, 2003 at 08:11:26AM -0600, B. Thoen wrote:
> > Reporting it either costs me money or takes up too much time, which are 
> > both resources I don't want to spend on this irritating practice. I tried 
> > reporting it once upon a time, but the results proved it doesn't have any 
> > measurable effect. My SPAM load is still increasing.
> 
> Give it two months before passing judgement about whether or not
> reporting works.  What, you thought it was going to happen overnight?
> 

One only has to look at the spam statistics (see 
http://www.raingod.com/angus/Computing/Internet/Spam/Statistics/) to 
realize that efforts like SpamCop are not getting the job done. 
They're not even making a dent in the load.  Pretty soon, people with 
small personal servers (like me) are going to be getting so much spam that 
it will look the same as a permanent DDoS attack.

I think we need to get rid of anonymous e-mail for starters. If such a
system could be set up, I think I'd shut down sendmail and use the new
service. It's the same thing as abandoning Usenet for private,
spam-excluded mailing lists. Then people can choose to use a secure mail
system or stick with the chaotic anarchy of the current system.

In the old days, the anarchy was great, but then you had to learn the lore 
to join the tribe. Now any idiot can get into the game, and there's too 
many. You can't fight massed ignorance head-on. Best to just step aside 
and let it blunder into some other obstacle. But we need a choice; right 
now we don't have much, and it doesn't take a genius to see the 
catastrophe coming.

- Bill Thoen

Subject: [PLUG] squid: request from another cache as a client?
In-Reply-To: <20031017072633.GB7174@ursine.ca>
References: <200310160735.39756.guy1656@ados.com>
	 <20031016151731.GI15415@ursine.ca>

	 <Pine.LNX.4.58.0310161453480.3477@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
	 <20031017025332.GE340@ursine.ca> <1066365252.4042.41.camel@dell.linux.box>
	 <20031017072633.GB7174@ursine.ca>
Message-ID: <1066413231.6844.9.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Fri, 2003-10-17 at 00:26, Paul Johnson wrote:

> On Thu, Oct 16, 2003 at 09:34:12PM -0700, AthlonRob wrote:
> > A cache at the individual ISP level would be very nice, I agree... but
> > do most have such a thing available?  I know mine doesn't.
> 
> Encourage your ISP to start one.  All it takes is an extra machine
> comparable to a Windows gaming box hardware wise, and it's trivial to
> make it a transparent proxy so your users never have to change
> anything to use it.  Bonus points if you can convince your ISP to use
> adzapper with it: They could even advertize truly ad-free web browsing
> then.

Encouraging an ISP to set up a proxy isn't a bad idea - it would perhaps
speed things up when generally browsing the web.  Maybe they could set
it up to cache from things like gentoo.oregonstate.edu, wherever debian
downloads from, and v4.windowsupdate.microsoft.com regardless of size of
download.. just put some big disks in there.

Setting up adzapper or somesuch with it is a decent idea, too.  I,
personally, use SquidGuard for my content filtering needs.

But setting up either of those transparently - no - that can lead to
problems.  Transparent proxies are *not* fool-proof.  You can (and do)
run in to problems when you use a transparent proxy, although the
problems are not terribly common.

Encourage folks to use the proxy manually (hell - they could provide a
.reg file for the Windows lusers)... advertise it with "Hey!  This
speeds up your Web Browsing!" or something.

> > A cache at the LAN level isn't going to make a significant dent in
> > things.
> 
> Well, it does if you're limited on bandwidth and have several users.
> Like six geeks, one cable connection.  I don't think even an adzapping
> proxy cache would have saved us if we were on DSL.

One geek and five non-geeks here.  I set up a transparent squid proxy
for my LAN.  It uses SquidGuard to filter out porn and ads.

We just have DSL.

I don't honestly notice a day-to-day speed improvement, except when I
browse to a site that's heavy in static graphics that somebody has been
to before (although I don't think any of us ever hit the same website as
somebody else, except perhaps google and ebay)... or Windows
Updates/other big downloads.  WinUp gets run on one machine, then the
next machine runs it and the downloads happen in a matter of seconds.

> > So, if you don't mind, would you elaborate on your proxy cache idea? 
> > :-)
> 
> Everybody's gotta do it.

Better start writing to ISPs...

> > The documentation in that file is nothing if not complete.  :-)
> 
> Right, I already saw that, but I never could get it to do that.

Well, the first big troubleshooting question should always be...

What happened when you tried?

Rob

use the check_whitelist perl script that comes with SpamAssassin ( in the

never gotten it to work without tweaking it.

On Fri, 17 Oct 2003, Paul Johnson wrote:
> If you get compromised and become an open relay, by direct action of
> cracker or by virus, you deserve to have your ISP suspend or cancel your

This is wrong on so many levels.

Open relays should be the standard.  People should pass each others' mail,
no questions asked.  It doesn't take that much.  The only reason we don't
ALL have open relays is because SOME do not and that focusses the burden
on those that do instead of distributing it across the entire network and
so the burden becomes higher than it should be and more relays are
restricted and the cycle reinforces itself.

Secondly, the only thing people DESERVE is to be forgiveness and
dignified, kind, respectful treatment.  If something unfortunate happens
to a person or happens because of a person, the humane response is to
forgive the person and work with the new situation.  If help must be lent,
lend it.  If sympathy will help, share that.  Punishment is positive
feedback for pain and misery.

What's wrong with people that they must work so hard to cause each other
problems?

From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Oct 17 11:52:02 2003

On Fri, 17 Oct 2003, B. Thoen wrote:
> Pretty soon, people with small personal servers (like me) are going to
> be getting so much spam that it will look the same as a permanent DDoS
> attack.

That's absurd.  With that level of inundation, no person would EVER
read email and the entire spam system would die under its own weight.
A balance will be reached.  We're over that balancing point now and it's
just taking time for the system to find equilibrium.

> I think we need to get rid of anonymous e-mail for starters.

Your first thought is to remove privacy and security from others to solve
your problem?

> It's the same thing as abandoning Usenet for private, spam-excluded
> mailing lists.

I've been using USENET ALOT lately and I have seen very little spam.

And have you ever considered the social repercussions of abandoning USENET
for private mailing lists?  For one, it is more exclusive and less likely
to include unsolicited opinion and points of view.  This is a great
detriment to intellectual discussion.  Points of view are limited to those
who know where the list is and have subscribed explicitly.  USENET allows
for free browsing of groups in a loose topical hierarchy so that all
discussions are easily found in one place and a person can pop in and out
of discussions on their own time.

For open discussions, USENET is far superior to email lists.

> Then people can choose to use a secure mail system or stick with the
> chaotic anarchy of the current system.

I'll take the anarchy, thanks.  Authorities will never bring the same
level of freedom, flexibility, and harmony that anarchy can.

> In the old days, the anarchy was great, but then you had to learn the
> lore to join the tribe. Now any idiot can get into the game, and there's
> too many.

Yeah, Bill, you're right.  It's all about you being better than everyone
else.  The ignorant, unwashed masses just aren't good enough to play in
your internet.

Forgive my sarcasm, but that kind of thinking is just elitist crap.
People can and will learn to be good to each other.

> You can't fight massed ignorance head-on. Best to just step aside and
> let it blunder into some other obstacle.

Wash your hands of the whole situation and let people make things worse
for themselves?  If you're so much better than most people, perhaps you
could share some of that great wisdom and experience and TEACH.  Ignorance
isn't fought head-on by slamming the ignorant against their shortcomings
over and over, ignorance is fought sidelong by joining in the ranks and
sharing your enlightened views.  It takes time and patience and
forgiveness, but it yields the greatest positive results.

> But we need a choice; right now we don't have much, and it doesn't take
> a genius to see the catastrophe coming.

It doesn't take a genius to see that catastrophe wouldn't be the END,
either.  Something bad might happen.  But your idea of "the death of
email" is absurd.  If the system becomes unusable, it will be unusable to
the spammers as well.  It will not have to be abandoned, it will just
change shape.  I think USENET is a fine example here.  It became unusable
for a while, but the results just didn't justify the level of inundation.
Equilibrium has been achieved.

J.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Fri Oct 17 14:14:02 2003

> Is there any way to copy a portion of the text of a pdf file?

Bill,

On Red Hat systems, pdftotext comes as part of the xpdf rpm. On Debian
systems, pdftotext comes as part of the xpdf-utils package.

Or, you can use the little text-select tool in Adobe Acrobat reader.

In-Reply-To: <1066423974.1055.0.camel@apollo.spears.org>
References: <1066423974.1055.0.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310171436170.22953@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 17 Oct 2003, Bill Spears wrote:

> Is there any way to copy a portion of the text of a pdf file?

  Yes. Two ways; three, actually.

1. If the pdf was generated by a linux tool or Adobe's distiller then you
can simply block the text in xpdf or acroread and paste it into either a
virtual terminal or a gen-u-whine X application.

2. Same source as above: run the pdf file through 'ps2ascii <input.pdf>
<output.txt>' then clean up the closed-up words with a text editor.

3. If the file was scanned, run it through 'pdftopbm' to translate to a
bit-mapped format that gocr can recognize. Then read the man page for gocr
and generate one .txt file for each page in the original pdf document. Takes
some cleaning -- depending on the quality of the scan and the fonts used --
but it is faster than rekeying everything.

Rich

From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Oct 17 16:56:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri Oct 17 16:56:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Using spamassassin's tagging...
In-Reply-To: <1066420916.6861.26.camel@dell.linux.box>
References: <20031017124945.GA14737@ursine.ca>  <20031017150155.511A0158F81@kanga.canids.net>
  <20031017153923.GA21689@ursine.ca>  <Pine.LNX.4.52.0310171133050.1941@shaft.bitmine.net>
 <1066420916.6861.26.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0310171624450.1941@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Fri, 17 Oct 2003, AthlonRob wrote:
> On Fri, 2003-10-17 at 11:39, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> > This is wrong on so many levels.
>
> Is it?

Ayup.

> Wow.

Indeed.  Mind-blowing, isn't it?

> Do you agree there are 'bad guys' out there on the Internet?

I don't believe there are 'bad guys' or 'good guys'.  There's just a bunch
of guys.

Do you really believe there are bad guys?  Can you just pick them out of a
line-up and dispose of them or do we have somehow winkle them out with
bait so we can end their miserable lives?

Life sure would be good if there weren't other people with conflicting
desires messing things up for me!  Let's put together some more prisons.
Surely that'll solve the problem.  After all, the United States has more
people in prison per capita than any other industrialized nation, so our
crime rate is the low... oh, wait.

> People who do things they shouldn't?

Everyone does things they shouldn't; by other people's standards and even
their own.

> Or are you saying there *isn't* anything bad you can do on the Internet?

I got all kinds of ideas of bad things a person can do on the internet.

Is doing something bad the only requirement to being a 'bad guy'?  If so,
then everyone's a 'bad guy'.  Who's got the black hats?

> If you can spread a worm or virus, or emailbomb somebody, that's ok,
> there's nothing wrong with it?

There's nothing wrong with being able to spread an emailbomb or a virus or
a worm.  There is something wrong with actually doing it.

> If we were all open relays somebody could, with virtually no effort at
> all, email bomb somebody quite effectively.

With closed relays, it's still quite effective.

And making it more difficult to do doesn't solve the problem.  The problem
isn't it happening, the problem is people wanting to make it happen.
Solve the root problem and you don't have to worry about whether or not
it's possible.

You don't bring down the murder rate by taking away the weapons.  You
bring down the murder rate by teaching people to respect others' lives.

(Or do you favor gun control?)

> The spreading of viruses and worms among Windows users would be able to
> happen a lot quicker.

Do you have any idea how Windows worms and virii are spread?  They use the
system default SMTP server.  Presumably, a person is allowed to send mail
through their own default SMTP server.  A compromised system almost ALWAYS
has a place to relay mail.

> Spam could increase exponentially, clogging down mail servers
> everywhere.

It is not in the interest of spammers to clog down the entire mail system.
It will not happen because they would all go out of business long before
it got that bad.

> No, not everybody deserves forgiveness or kind, dignified, respectful
> treatment.

This, to me, is axiomatic.  There is no basis for debate.  Either you
respect people or you spread misery and make war.

> Punishment is necessary in the world... but I don't think we want to get
> too far into that discussion, we'll get way further off topic.

It's all the same topic.  It's about respecting people and giving them
everything you can.

> You seem to trust everybody not to harm you.

I do, but I think you might not understand what that means.  I trust
everybody to not harm me, but I don't believe nobody will.

People react much better to trust than suspicion.  People act more
responsibly when given real responsibility than when left to their own
whim and wimsy.  This is Psych 101.  Ask any parent.

Who was it that wrote "Unix doesn't prevent you from doing something
stupid because that might prevent me from doing something clever"?  I
think it relates here.  You have to give people power in order for them to
do great things.

> I don't have such faith in the world.

There really isn't any choice.  The alternative is so unpleasant.  The
only viable alternative to a social structure of mutual trust and respect
is one of totalitarian control through violent coersion.  This is
essentially the difference between the progressive and the conservative.

I believe every crime can be traced back to someone who doesn't know how
to respect other people... and that, barring physiological mental illness,
is always the way they were taught to live, either explicitly or by
example.

It's an oft-used cliche (and I guess it wouldn't be a cliche if it wasn't
oft-used), but we have to break the cycle.  It will probably take a
hundred generations of very hard work before it is the norm everywhere,
but it's worth it... and if we don't start now, it will be AT LEAST one
more generation away.

J.

/usr/share/doc/gdbm-1.8.0/NEWS

CHANGES from 1.7.3 to 1.8
  1.  Added GDBM_CENTFREE functionality and option.
  2.  Added GDBM_COALESCEBLKS functionality and option.
  3.  Added GDBM_NOLOCK flag.
  4.  Made ``fast'' mode the default, making GDBM_FAST obsolete, and
adding
      the GDBM_SYNC flag and GDBM_SYNCMODE option.
  5.  Switched to building with libtool.

CHANGES from 1.7.2 to 1.7.3
  1.  Fixed a couple of last minute problems. (Namely, no autoconf.h in
      version.c, and no GDBM_FASTMODE in gdbm.h!)
  2.  Fixed some documentation bugs.

None of these should effect format issues.

From mark at linuxhardware.net  Fri Oct 17 21:39:02 2003
From: mark at linuxhardware.net (Mark Griskey)
Date: Fri Oct 17 21:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] wget timeout value
In-Reply-To: <3F90AC44.5020506@pobox.com>
References: <3F90AC44.5020506@pobox.com>
Message-ID: <200310172138.09436.mark@linuxhardware.net>

wget and the -T option, in my experience was a headache, simply because 
setting it seemed to do nothing.  It seems that wget, at least on Linux, is 
using the value in: 

/proc/sys/net/ipv4/tcp_retries2

for timeouts, which is set to 15 minutes. Lower this value and your timeout 
will match.  I had to use wget for a very large harvesting project, and this 
was the source of much frustration.

However, there is a patch, that will allow wget's -T to behave independent of 
the value in tcp_retries2.

Here is the link:
http://www.geocrawler.com/archives/3/409/2000/11/0/4723942/

I've been using a version of wget compiled with this patch for quite sometime 
and have been very happy with the results.

More information can be found here:

http://www.geocrawler.com/archives/3/409/2000/1/0/3189215/

I'd be more than happy to help you compile a version with the patch in place 
should you need it.

Mark

On Friday 17 October 2003 7:58 pm, Brian Quade wrote:
> I have been using wget to download files and was reading the man page to
> see how I could optimize it more.  The -T option sets the timeout value
> which is 900 seconds (15 minutes) by default.  The documentation says,
> "Please do not lower the timeout value unless you know what you are

> something?  Does anyone know?  Would it crash the server or lock up my

I have a faint, rusty memory that making the timeout value too low could cause 
some problems navigating ipchains, or going through proxies. I've forgotten 
everything about ipchains, so who knows. As far as just sitting down and 
typing something like 'wget  www.masses.o.mp3s.com', and wandering away while 
it goes to work, I can't imagine what awful things could happen by changing 
the timeout value to something that suits you better. I think none, unless 
you use it in some automated functions, and it gives up too soon if there is 
connection flakiness.

I suppose too long a timeout could get annoying if you have some kind of bot 
or script that retrieves pages at regular intervals, and it waits too long to 
give up on a bad connection.

Don't you love helpful man pages?  :P

From ramunro1 at ix.netcom.com  Sat Oct 18 00:59:01 2003
From: ramunro1 at ix.netcom.com (Robert Munro)
Date: Sat Oct 18 00:59:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Using spamassassin's tagging
In-Reply-To: <1066368376.3467.43.camel@griffin>
References: <20031017040101.25215.37464.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
	 <1066368376.3467.43.camel@griffin>
Message-ID: <1066463920.3038.163.camel@griffin>

On Thu, 2003-10-16 at 22:26, I wrote:
> 
> Here's the script /home/[uid]/spam-filter.sh . . .
> 
> export LANG=en_US
> spamassassin -ea > /home/[uid]/test.txt
> let rc=$?
> if [ ${rc}!=0 ] ; then
>         touch /tmp/mbox
>         spamassassin -r < /home/[uid]/test.txt
> fi
> exit ${rc}

That doesn't work over reboots, because Evolution reallocates the Spam
mbox file on disk when it doesn't find it at the linked /tmp location,
so the "touch" line should be deleted.  Instead, add the following two
lines somewhere in /etc/rc.sysinit:

# Cleanup Spam mailbox
rm -f /tmp/mbox
touch /tmp/mbox

Disclaimer:  I haven't rebooted to test this yet, but it *should* work.

Regards,
Robert Munro

From russell-evans at qwest.net  Sat Oct 18 02:24:02 2003
From: russell-evans at qwest.net (russell-evans at qwest.net)
Date: Sat Oct 18 02:24:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] (no subject)
In-Reply-To: <FCEBIHDEIPOEEPHFOCFFOEOACHAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
References: <FCEBIHDEIPOEEPHFOCFFOEOACHAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>

I'm waiting on a job to finish that doesn't require me to do anything so I have
some time.

Thank you
Russell



#/bin/sh

### VARIABLES ###

# File that contains two columns of data for parsing
INPUT_FILE=result.txt


### VARIABLES - DO NOT EDIT ###

# declare varibles
declare -a RESULT
declare -a COL1
declare -a COL2

# Create array of date in INPUT_FILE
if [ -r $INPUT_FILE ] ; then
  RESULTS=(`cat $INPUT_FILE`)
else
  exit 1
fi

# Number of elements in RESULTS array
COUNT=${#RESULTS[@]}

### FUNCTIONS ####

CREATE_COL_ARRAYS () { # create two arrays composed of each column in
INPUT_FILE
 # INPUTS: COUNT variable, count of fields in array RESULT
 # OUTPUT: COL1 array
 #	   COL2 array	     
 let x=0
 while [ $x -lt $COUNT ]  ; do
   let y=$x+1
   # Create array of first column data
   COL1[$x]=${RESULTS[$x]}
   # Create array of second column data
   COL2[$x]=${RESULTS[$y]}
   let x=$x+2
 done
} ### END CREATE_COL_ARRAYS

PROCESS_COL1 () { # Do something to COL1 array
 # INPUTS: COL1 array
 # OUTPUT:
 echo column1=\"${COL1[@]}\"			 
} ### END PROCESS_COL1

PROCESS_COL2 () { # Do something to COL2 array
 # INPUTS: COL2 array
 # OUTPUT:
 echo column2=\"${COL2[@]}\"			 
} ### END PROCESS_COL2

### MAIN ###

# Call CREATE_COL_ARRAYS to create column arrays
CREATE_COL_ARRAYS || exit 1
PROCESS_COL1 || exit 1
PROCESS_COL2 || exit 1
exit 0

Yeah, swen hit and suddenly Usenet went practically spam-free.  I like
it.  Maybe the spammers are getting hit too hard by a taste of their
own medicine to spam on Usenet anymore.  One can only hope.

> I'll take the anarchy, thanks.  Authorities will never bring the same
> level of freedom, flexibility, and harmony that anarchy can.

The internet is more communist than anarchist, really; though neither
communism nor anarchy has a central authority or government.
Communism implies self-regulation in which each person participates
more or less cooperatively, anarchy is a bit more selfish (I'll do
what I want, everybody else be damned).  Communism's self-regulation
system has mostly worked for the Internet since it's creation, I'd
rather not see that change now.  It's a system that works well, just
not when basic needs of living are involved (which is why communism
doesn't work in real life on a scale larger than a commune, and there
has never been a truly communist country).

On Sat, 18 Oct 2003, Randal L. Schwartz wrote:

> Not grep, which only finds things and prints the entire line.

Actually, GNU grep has the --only-matching (-o) option which shows
"only the part of a matching line that matches" the indicated regex.
It's simplistic in the sense that it'll only return one match per
line, but given the right input it works well enough, e.g.,

# get list of ftp mirrors for red hat 9
wget -q -O - http://www.redhat.com/mirrors/ |\
  grep -oi "ftp://.*/9/en/os/i386/"

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

> cooperatively, anarchy is a bit more selfish (I'll do what I want,
> everybody else be damned).

I don't know who taught you social politics, but they were grossly
misinformed.

Communism is an economic system and anarchism is a social structure.  You
need both an economic system and a social structure to have a society.

You could be anarcho-communist or anarcho-capitalist (though you'd have to
be downright misanthropic for that one) or democratic socialist or
whatever.  Me, I'm more of a libertarian socialist or an
anarcho-syndicalist.

But your idea that anarchism requires selfishness is so dead wrong, I
hardly know where to begin.  The selfish are very rarely anarchist unless
they are dead set on destroying civilization.  Selfishness is a "one man
against the world" philosophy and it simply cannot be supported unless
there is a massive state to protect that one man from the world.

Lots of people confuse communism with a political system (typically the
soviet system).  I think this is basically a result of very poor education
due to Red Scare politics through most of the last century preventing
adequate public discourse.

> Communism's self-regulation system has mostly worked for the Internet
> since it's creation, I'd rather not see that change now.

Self-regulation is a matter of each individual regulating his or her self.
When spamcop.net tells ISPs to shut down service or else the entire
service's mail will be blackholed, that is coersion and has no place in a
self-regulating system.

> It's a system that works well, just not when basic needs of living are
> involved (which is why communism doesn't work in real life on a scale
> larger than a commune, and there has never been a truly communist
> country).

Communism (the real thing, not the idea to which you've attached that
name) is very difficult when basic needs are involved because some
barbaric people still quest for power over their fellow man and would seek
control over the flow of necessary goods and services as a lever for
personal power.

It's also fairly true that no social or economic system scales well.
(This is true for almost any system, really.)  Once a system gets so large
that every participant cannot see and understand the whole of the
mechanism, it breaks down and starts acting in unpredictable ways.  There
are purely automatic systems that require no conscious intervention (the
natural cycle of birth, death, decay, and growth, for example), but those
are obviously different from most human-designed systems.

For example, the internet works as a physical structure (though nobody
knwos how we're going to reincorporate all of those obsolete parts as
upgrades take place -- but we'll call manufacturing of components a
different system for convenience) and doesn't foul up packet passing badly
every day because piecewise or as a whole, each component does exactly the
same thing.  It scales more or less infinitely because the differences
between a network of forty nodes (which a person could easily grasp
intellectually) and a network of forty thousand is just the number of
hops.  Every network engineer knows (or should know) how his little piece
of the puzzle is SUPPOSED to act and that's the same for EVERY piece of
the network.  It's essentially an automatic mechanical system that doesn't
involve human decision-making.  The allocation of IP addresses, however,
IS a human decision and is really fouled up.  And so now we've got to
consider re-allocating those addresses and maybe adding more bits to the
thing, but that means much bigger, faster hardware than we've got and oh
goodness, what a pickle!  The part that requires regular, biased
decision-making broke down because it's too big to get your head around.

Human scale is a very important design element.
J.

From bthoen at gisnet.com  Sat Oct 18 12:08:02 2003
From: bthoen at gisnet.com (B. Thoen)
Date: Sat Oct 18 12:08:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Procmail Recipie Ideas for New Spammer Trick?
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0310181158001.5845-100000@gisnet.com>

Trying to pick off spam messages, I'm seeing more of this sort of trick:

 Vicod<klr5ed73hnt>in
 Prescri<kxd1l6sdjir451>pti<knkm2xp3d8skk>on

Take out the HTML tags and you can see the spam filter trigger words. This 
is what the mail reader does, so the victim can read it, but the procmail 
filter sees the tags and misses the words.

In this case, all the tags start with "<k", but I bet I can't count on 
that for long. I suppose I could check for tags between every letter, but 
testing for v(<).*>i(<).*>c(<).*>o(<).*> . . . etc. seems like too much 
work. Does anyone have any ideas how or if one can deal with this new 
spammer trick with Procmail?

- Bill Thoen

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Sat Oct 18 15:12:02 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Sat Oct 18 15:12:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix header_checks (was Reporting SPAM)
In-Reply-To: <20031018212016.GA4497@brian.brianandkellyderr.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0310171124210.1941@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0310171143490.3328-100000@gisnet.com>
	 <20031018035246.GE6150@ursine.ca> <1066450518.6861.57.camel@dell.linux.box>
	 <20031018212016.GA4497@brian.brianandkellyderr.com>
Message-ID: <1066515010.9411.26.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Sat, 2003-10-18 at 14:20, Brian Derr wrote:
> On Fri, Oct 17, 2003 at 09:15:18PM -0700, AthlonRob wrote:
> > Postfix's header_checks are way cool.
> 
> I've been working on a way to, shall we say, vaporize Jeme's messages
> using procmail.  But I was looking into the postfix header_check you
> refered to and piqued my interest.  Can you explain how it works?
> Reading through the example "sample-filter.cf" file I see that you can
> REJECT, IGNORE, etc but what is the syntax for the
> /etc/postfix/header_check file?

header_checks = regexp:/etc/postfix/blocks

in main.cf (I'm using blocks rather than header_check, just season to
taste) then blocks contains:

/^From: Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net>/ REJECT

Mine actually contains more than that, stuff after the REJECT line, but
I don't think we need that here.  You can add stuff after REJECT like
550: I don't like this email address or something similar.

That way, as soon as the mail server says From: Jeme A Brelin
<jeme at brelin.net> your mail server says 550: I don't like this email
address.

Rob

On Sat, 18 Oct 2003, B. Thoen wrote:
> Can't say; I'm not using SA yet. Before I get into that though I thought
> I'd explore what could be done with just Procmail first.

Well, you're really just treading over well-travelled ground.

I believe it was Larry Wall who wrote, "The existence of wheels in Unix
has not yet precluded their reinvention."

However, if you're just looking for a good way to do this filtering thing,
spamassassin is pretty darned good at it.

> > One option, I suppose, would be just to s/<[^>[//g the whole message
> > before your filter sees it.  But that's pretty destructive.
>
> Yes, I still get a lot of legitimate mail that's HTML formatted; don't
> want to destroy that before I read it.

Well, it wouldn't destroy the mail, only the HTML formatting.

> Fortunately, I haven't seen a lot of these yet, so it's not a desperate
> situation at this point. The trick seemed hard to counter with what I
> know about Procmail egrep filtering (which ain't much) so I'm hoping
> there's a simple solution before I get swamped with the buggers.

Well, that's the point, I think.  I guess the spammer's idea is that the
filtering is being done by the ISP and not the end users, so bypassing the
filter would make sense.  But if filters are implemented by end users
INSTEAD of ISPs, then there's no point trying to bypass them because the
people who actually use filters are not going to be a receptive target
audience.

> I imagine this could be tough for SpamAssassin, filling its database
> with lots of nonsense garbage. Or can it keep track of legitimate words
> vs.  randomly-generated strings?

Nah, it just parses the message before it runs the checks.  Pretty easy to
strip that stuff out and THEN make your decisions.

I haven't seen any rules that actually look for these random strings...
nor have I stopped to consider the unpleasant effects of such a filter.

>   In Slackware I cannot do this. I learned from a Web page that to stop the
> daemon I grep for it in the process list and kill it off. Simple enough.
> But what I've not yet found is how I start it back up again without
> rebooting.

Rich, Slackware is similar to the above.  Look in your /etc/rc.d/
directory.  There you will find such jewels as rc.inet1, rc.nfsd,
rc.gpm, etc, etc.  Most of these scripts take a command line parameter
(ie, 'start' or 'stop' or 'restart').  Have a look through each script
to see the way they are run so when you want to create your own script
you know how it should look.

So, on your slack box if you wanted to stop nfsd you would enter:
/etc/rc.d/rc.nfsd stop  Simple enough, or rc.nfsd restart if you need
to restart her.  Have fun!

Brian
(loving slackware for 4 years now)

From heinlein at madboa.com  Sat Oct 18 18:17:01 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sat Oct 18 18:17:01 2003
Subject: Fedora comments (was: [PLUG] Copying text from pdf)
In-Reply-To: <1066498459.1056.10.camel@apollo.spears.org>
References: <1066423974.1055.0.camel@apollo.spears.org> 
 <Pine.LNX.4.58.0310171409030.4851@pecos.madboa.com> <1066498459.1056.10.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0310181741180.4851@pecos.madboa.com>

On Sat, 18 Oct 2003, Bill Spears wrote:

> BTW, I've been meaning to ask you for your opinion on the future of
> Red Hat.  I read somewhere that us coolies were going to be using
> something maintained by Fedora. Would you comment on whether the
> average user (one or two systems, medium Linux skills) should stick
> with Red Hat or maybe move to Debian?

It's a good question. I've been pondering it myself. I hope my musings
don't come off as troll bait...

I've had Debian installed for some time on an old Alpha. I don't power
it up all that often -- it's mostly a plaything, really -- so my
experience with Debian had been pretty limited.

More recently, however, I installed Debian 'testing' on my wife's
computer. Now that it's running, it's a piece of cake to maintain. The
apt-* tools are really slick.

Getting it running, however, was pretty tedious. I'm sure that more
experienced Debian admins know better ways of getting the 'testing'
release installed, but for me it was difficult:

1. Tried various iso's and floppy images of the testing release -- but
   couldn't successfully complete any of them. (This trial-and-error
   process took hours...)

2. Finally, I installed a very minimal version of Debian stable and
   then tweaked (and retweaked quite a few times) the
   /etc/apt/sources.list file to point at the testing section of the
   mirrors.

3. Ran 'apt-get dist-upgrade' to get move to testing.

4. Since Debian stable is still running a 2.2 kernel, I installed a
   2.4.22 kernel package. The module settings for my NIC, however,
   didn't migrate smoothly at all. It took a bit of experimentation to
   figure out that the 2.2 rtl8139 module has been replaced in the 2.4
   series by 8139too. A newbie would have been completely stymied.

5. Then ran apt-get quite a few more times to get a working X
   installation. Again, it's not a process for newbies...

Had I simply wanted Debian stable, it would have been cake. Getting
Debian testing -- which has packages I consider reasonably up to date
-- was, for me, tedious.

But, like I said, now that it's running, it's great. I've got a
feeling I won't have to do anything but the occasional 'apt-get
update' and 'apt-get upgrade' for a long time, which makes me smile
very broadly.

Fedora will be an interesting experiment. I think of it as driven by
Red Hat, but enhanced by the community. There will be Fedora Core
(Red Hat-driven, core packages) and then Fedora Extras
(community-driven, other stuff).

So far, Red Hat is talking about two Core releases a year. Many
(most?) admins, of course want nothing to do with two upgrades a year.
Once a year is good for development desktops, and once every 24 to 36
months isn't so bad for servers and business desktops.

The big question is, will the Fedora community be successful in
supporting older Core packages once Red Hat has moved on? What we're
discussing on the Fedora Legacy mailing list is how we're going to
choose which Fedora Core releases we (the community) will support and
for how long.

It's an open question as to how well it'll work.

On the other hand, the Fedora Core beta installations have worked
pretty well for me. A couple hiccups, but, really, they're
tremendously easy to install -- and you get software that's very, very
current, often more so than Debian testing.

The great thing is, you can't really lose. Debian and Fedora/Red Hat
are both wonderful. Compared to one another, they both have strengths
and weaknesses. Compared to anything coming out of Redmond, they're so
far superior that it makes your head spin.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>



From drl at drloree.com  Sat Oct 18 18:33:01 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Sat Oct 18 18:33:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Procmail Recipie Ideas for New Spammer Trick?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0310181516360.6148-100000@gisnet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0310181516360.6148-100000@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <1066528017.717.52.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Sat, 2003-10-18 at 14:42, B. Thoen wrote:
> On Sat, 18 Oct 2003, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> > On Sat, 18 Oct 2003, B. Thoen wrote:
> > > Trying to pick off spam messages, I'm seeing more of this sort of trick:
> > >
> > >  Vicod<klr5ed73hnt>in
> > >  Prescri<kxd1l6sdjir451>pti<knkm2xp3d8skk>on
> > >
> > > Does anyone have any ideas how or if one can deal with this new spammer
> > > trick with Procmail?
> > 
> > There's usually enough other stuff going on in those messages to trigger
> > spamassassin.  Are you finding otherwise?
> 
> Can't say; I'm not using SA yet. Before I get into that though I thought
> I'd explore what could be done with just Procmail first.
> 
> > One option, I suppose, would be just to s/<[^>[//g the whole message
> > before your filter sees it.  But that's pretty destructive.
> 
> Yes, I still get a lot of legitimate mail that's HTML formatted; don't 
> want to destroy that before I read it.

spamprobe ignores HTML tags for scoring purposes, to quote the man page:


Ignores HTML tags in emails for scoring purposes unless  the  -h
command line option is used.  Many spams use HTML and few humans
do so HTML tends to become a powerful recognizer of spams.  How-
ever  in  the author's opinion this also substantially increases
the likelihood of false positives if someone does  send  a  non-
spam  email containing HTML tags.  SpamProbe does pull urls from
inside of html tags however since those tend to be spammer  spe-
cific.

> 
> Fortunately, I haven't seen a lot of these yet, so it's not a desperate
> situation at this point. The trick seemed hard to counter with what I know
> about Procmail egrep filtering (which ain't much) so I'm hoping there's a 
> simple solution before I get swamped with the buggers. 
> 
> I imagine this could be tough for SpamAssassin, filling its database with
> lots of nonsense garbage. Or can it keep track of legitimate words vs. 
> randomly-generated strings?

I've been very impressed with spamprobe, it consistently filters around
98%, the other 1 or 2 percent are always the latest spam; I only ever
see them once.  After more than a couple thousand spams, I have gotten
no false positives.

Just a PLUG.

Derek Loree

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Sat Oct 18 19:38:01 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Sat Oct 18 19:38:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Starting daemons in a running Slackware system
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310181653330.26989@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0310181653330.26989@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1066531001.9408.31.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Sat, 2003-10-18 at 16:57, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Slackware uses BSD-style init scripts whereas most linux distributions
> (such as Red Hat which I've used for six years) use SysV-style init scripts.
> Among the differences is that with the SysV style, if I want to stop and
> restart daemons such as nfs or network I type:
> 
> 	/etc/rc.d/init.d/nfs stop
> 	/etc/rc.d/init.d/nfs start
> and the equivalent for the network daemon.
> 
>   In Slackware I cannot do this. I learned from a Web page that to stop the
> daemon I grep for it in the process list and kill it off. Simple enough.
> But what I've not yet found is how I start it back up again without
> rebooting.

Depending on what you're doing, a HUP might do the trick...

killall -HUP smbd nmbd -for instance.

Otherwise, if you look in /etc/rc.d, you'll see there are a few scripts
like that already, I know sshd supports start/stop/restart arguments,
for instance.

There was recently (within the last month) a long thread in
alt.os.linux.slackware about converting the daemon scripts to the Linux
standard whatchamacallit setup using start/stop/restart for each daemon
script.  You might look it up, as the OP did some work already and had
at least one script converted over.

Rob

>   When I look for the modules for the built-in sound support on the MSI
> motherboard I find them in /lib/modules/2.4.22/kernel/drivers/sound/ as
> ac97.o.gz and ac97_codec.o.gz. However, I cannot load them with 'modprobe'
> and they are not loaded during boot (only soundcore shows up with 'lsmod').
> 
>   Are they not loaded until needed? Is there a reason why modprobe would
> report "Can't locate module
> /lib/modules/2.4.22/kernel/drivers/sound/ac97.o.gz" when the file is there
> and greater than 0 bytes?

That's odd - can you cut-and-paste the exact input and output?  ie; what
you typed and what it spat back out to you?

I didn't think you usually called ac97 directly.

Oh, and BTW, Slackware 9.1 defaults to ALSA sound by default now.  Alsa
modules use the snd- format for their modules.  You might check the Alsa
Soundcard Matrix for your motherboard (or its chip) and see what alsa
module to use, although if you installed hotplug I would have expected
it to have been automagically loaded for you.

there are docs and manuals squirreled away all over the place, in 
/usr/share/doc, and various other locations. Think of it as treasure hunt. :)

have to reformat and reinstall the whole damned works, which is the preferred

undisturbed. (Just one little system file! gaaahh!)

If you're confident using mostly non-GUI utilities, LNX-BBC is way super
cool as a rescue disk.  I just used it to rescue a computer infected
with <insert latest virus here> in no time flat.  Just fired it up,
selected a safe kernel (this box doesn't like default 2.4.x kernels -
oh, I modified LNX-BBC to support multiple kernels, too...), scp'd
f-prot over from my server, and had it scan the hard drive.  VERY
simple.

LNX-BBC utilizes the cloop module like Knoppix does... it's a lot like
Knoppix, I think, without all the jazzy desktop stuff.  I was able to
get links -g on there, running in X, though.  By default it comes with
Browsex for X browsing and lynx and links for console browsing.  The
latest CVS (which just recently started booting, I understand) actually
includes Mozilla Firebird as a graphical browser.

All that fits on a 50MB CD.

I can't think of a better rescue disk than that.  :-)

From russell-evans at qwest.net  Sun Oct 19 00:18:02 2003
From: russell-evans at qwest.net (russell-evans at qwest.net)
Date: Sun Oct 19 00:18:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] (no subject) rev2
In-Reply-To: <E1AAnJD-0007PF-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <FCEBIHDEIPOEEPHFOCFFOEOACHAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
    <E1AAnJD-0007PF-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

I made some mistakes in the script I posted I think I corrected all of them
here.

Thank you
Russell

#/bin/sh

### VARIABLES ###
# File that contains two columns of data for parsing
INPUT_FILE=result.txt

### VARIABLES - DO NOT EDIT ###
# declare array variables
declare -a RESULT
declare -a COL1
declare -a COL2

### FUNCTIONS ####i
CREATE_ARRAY () { # Create array from data in INPUT_FILE
 # INPUTS: file INPUT_FILE
 #OUTPUT: array RESULTS
 #		variable COUNT
 if [ -r $INPUT_FILE ] ; then
   RESULTS=(`< $INPUT_FILE`)
 else
   exit 1
 fi
 # Number of elements in RESULTS array
 COUNT=${#RESULTS[@]}
 # Check to make sure there was data in INPUT_FILE
 if [ $COUNT = 0 ] ; then
   echo "No data in file"
   exit 1
 fi
}

CREATE_COL_ARRAYS () { # create two arrays from RESULTS  
 # INPUTS: COUNT variable, count of fields in array RESULT
 # OUTPUT: COL1 array
 #	   COL2 array	     
 let x=0
 while [ $x -lt $COUNT ]  ; do
   let y=$x+1
   # Create array of first column data
   COL1[$x]=${RESULTS[$x]}
   # Create array of second column data
   COL2[$x]=${RESULTS[$y]}
   let x=$x+2
 done
} ### END CREATE_COL_ARRAYS

PROCESS_COL1 () { # Do something to COL1 array
 # INPUTS: COL1 array
 # OUTPUT:
 echo column1=\"${COL1[@]}\"			 
} ### END PROCESS_COL1

PROCESS_COL2 () { # Do something to COL2 array
 # INPUTS: COL2 array
 # OUTPUT:
 echo column2=\"${COL2[@]}\"			 
} ### END PROCESS_COL2

### MAIN ###
# Create array from data in INPUT_FILE
CREATE_ARRAY
# Call CREATE_COL_ARRAYS to create column arrays
CREATE_COL_ARRAYS || exit 1
# Do something with COL1 array
PROCESS_COL1 || exit 1
# Do something with COL2 array
PROCESS_COL2 || exit 1
exit 0

> #/bin/sh

should be #!/bin/sh
and maybe not sh, since POSIX sh doesn't have arrays.

> declare -a RESULT

should be RESULTS

>    COL2[$x]=${RESULTS[$y]}
>    let x=$x+2

you're only assigning every other element of COL1 and COL2.
COL1[0] has a value, COL1[1] is null, COL1[2] has a value, etc.

On Sat, 2003-10-18 at 18:16, Paul Heinlein wrote:

> So far, Red Hat is talking about two Core releases a year. Many
> (most?) admins, of course want nothing to do with two upgrades a year.
> Once a year is good for development desktops, and once every 24 to 36
> months isn't so bad for servers and business desktops.

Most other comments agreed with, I have to disagree with these.

The biggest problem I have with any "snapshot" (and I consider RH9 a
snapshot) is the same thing as a technology freeze on the Space Shuttle
program.  Yes it help with the process (the shuttle must freeze 10 years
out sometimes), but in the computing world, it does not make sense.

For example, RH9 comes with Mozilla 1.2.x.  Mozilla was at 1.3 when it
came out, and 1.4 before I ever installed it.  Now Ximian desktop (XD2)
uses moz 1.4.x but it screws the history files.  Largely since XD2
favors galeon, it has not cared too much about its mozilla failures.
Mozilla 1.5.x is now out and no movement from ximian is evident to me.


So what I hope out of fedora is a way of avoiding this.  To be honest, I
am not so sure.  The usual arguments against Redhat from the debian and
gentoo crowds fall flat since they suffer from this technology lag as
well. (are you serious that stable used 2.2.x?).

Yes I could compile/download my own.  But I have clients.  Multiplied
out, I have to react for over 1000 machines.  Often they need similar
latest thingies (Mozilla being #1).  Having binary packages I can send
is critical.  Better yet, binaries that they can download from someone
else.  Having to build my own binaries is tedious and usually
troublesome.  Hell just getting 2 sony laptops working the same (while
they are CPUs and years apart, both have small HD space) is enough pain.

>>>>> "Zot" == Zot O'Connor <zot at whiteknighthackers.com> writes:

Zot> Yes I could compile/download my own.  But I have clients.
Zot> Multiplied out, I have to react for over 1000 machines.  Often
Zot> they need similar latest thingies (Mozilla being #1).  Having
Zot> binary packages I can send is critical.  

I've always had this inuition that Debian-like infrastructure could
solve this problem for you.  You cache debian packages (swiped from
Debian archives or built yourself if necessary) that you have tested
and vouch for for your clients, and have the sources.list on your 1000
machines point at your tested cache.  Then, either update via a cron
or some other automated mechanism, e.g., roughly:

  for h in $host-list ; do
    ssh -l root $h 'apt-get update ; apt-get dist-upgrade'
  done

I don't know how well this would work in practice, but seems plausible
enough to be worthy of further exploration.  Alas, I manage
considerably fewer than 1000 machines, and at my scale it doesn't look
worth the effort.

Zot> Better yet, binaries that they can download from someone else.

That part might be tricky.

On Sat, Oct 18, 2003 at 06:16:32PM -0700, Paul Heinlein wrote:

> Getting it running, however, was pretty tedious. I'm sure that more
> experienced Debian admins know better ways of getting the 'testing'
> release installed, but for me it was difficult:
> 

As a recent Debian convert, I know of what you speak. I've got my base
install routine down.

1) Pop in the Woody CDs 
2) type bf24 at the boot prompt (to install with a 2.4 kernel)
3) upon finish of the stable install, replace "stable" with "testing"
or "unstable" in /etc/apt/sources.list
4) apt-get update && apt-get -u dist-upgrade

After slurping much bandwidth, I've got my updated machine.

I've converted converted six machines from redhat so far ranging from
servers running stable to laptops running unstable. One idea of debian
I really like is the "perpetual upgrade". With the updating/upgrading
process I can upgrade my system without a reboot (of course to running
a new kernel requires a reboot).

BTW, I've come to like "aptitude" better than that apt-get
suite. Check it out :-)

> So far, Red Hat is talking about two Core releases a year. Many
> (most?) admins, of course want nothing to do with two upgrades a year.
> Once a year is good for development desktops, and once every 24 to 36
> months isn't so bad for servers and business desktops.
> 

I haven't been keeping up with Red Hat, I threw in the towel when they
came out with RH9 so soon after 8, changed the libraries and then
started this Fedora migration.

I'd like to know if these core releases will require downing the machine,
inserting the CD, upgrading and then rebooting.

> The biggest problem I have with any "snapshot" (and I consider RH9 a
> snapshot) is the same thing as a technology freeze on the Space Shuttle
> program.  Yes it help with the process (the shuttle must freeze 10 years
> out sometimes), but in the computing world, it does not make sense.
> 
> For example, RH9 comes with Mozilla 1.2.x.  Mozilla was at 1.3 when it
> came out, and 1.4 before I ever installed it.  Now Ximian desktop (XD2)
> uses moz 1.4.x but it screws the history files.  Largely since XD2
> favors galeon, it has not cared too much about its mozilla failures.
> Mozilla 1.5.x is now out and no movement from ximian is evident to me.
> 
> 
> So what I hope out of fedora is a way of avoiding this.  To be honest, I
> am not so sure.  The usual arguments against Redhat from the debian and
> gentoo crowds fall flat since they suffer from this technology lag as
> well. (are you serious that stable used 2.2.x?).
> 

The default install of the current Debian stable (Woody) uses a 2.2
kernel. However, just typing "bf24" installs a 2.4 kernel during the
install. IIRC, Woody came out in July of 2002 so at that time 2.2 was
considered stable and I guess the 2.4 kernel just wasn't tested enough
to be the default. Testing is supposed to be taking Woody's place near
the end of this year.

My understanding of the Debian process is that what you talk about is
why there are the three versions, stable for the servers/production
machines, testing for those who need more current packages, and
unstable for those who like to be up on the cutting edge. There are
ways to have a stable box and install testing or unstable packages on
it. I'm not far enough in my understanding to comment on that, maybe
someone else can describe the art of "pinning".

I use unstable at home and on my laptop and I must say, it is pretty
stable. I've only had two times in the last six months where an
upgrade has stymied me. And a quick trip to the IRC channel fixed
those.

Keith



From drl at drloree.com  Sun Oct 19 10:34:01 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Sun Oct 19 10:34:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] BTTV drivers-
In-Reply-To: <20031019164958.16047.qmail@web10803.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20031019164958.16047.qmail@web10803.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1066585713.571.64.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Sun, 2003-10-19 at 09:49, Nick Wehr wrote:
> Hey people -
> 
>    I've got a custom driver that I need to use for
> video 4 linux.  It's installation instructions tell me
> to recompile the kernel.  Do I have to do this?

This depends of how the BTTV driver uses the kernel.  If it has to patch
the kernel code, as opposed to just compiling a module, then you will
have to compile your kernel.

>   BTTV
> loads as a module, so isn't there some other *easier*
> way?

Again, that depends on whether or not the driver has to make changes to
the kernel source, or just read the kernel configuration.  The only way
to find this out is to look at the driver source.

The most likely (and least frustrating) way to get this device to work
is to follow the instructions.  They were probably designed to work with
a large variety of systems.

Sometimes you can get away with just downloading the header files for
the kernel that you already have running, but if that is not in the
instructions, you won't know how to compile the module against these
headers.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

From russell-evans at qwest.net  Sun Oct 19 12:05:02 2003
From: russell-evans at qwest.net (russell-evans at qwest.net)
Date: Sun Oct 19 12:05:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] (no subject) rev3
In-Reply-To: <20031019075035.D6B46158F91@kanga.canids.net>
References: <20031019075035.D6B46158F91@kanga.canids.net>
Message-ID: <E1ABIr7-0000HX-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

This should correct the creation of the column arrays.

I generated a test file with 
let x=0 ; while [ $x -lt 100 ] ; do echo $x $x ; let x++; done > result.txt 

Thank you
Russell

#!/bin/sh

### VARIABLES ###
# File that contains two columns of data for parsing
PATH=$HOME
INPUT_FILE=$PATH/result.txt

### VARIABLES - DO NOT EDIT ###
# declare array variables
declare -a RESULTS
declare -a COL1
declare -a COL2

### FUNCTIONS ####i
CREATE_ARRAY () { # Create array from data in INPUT_FILE
 # INPUTS: INPUT_FILE file
 # OUTPUT: array RESULTS
 #	   variable COUNT
 if [ -r $INPUT_FILE ] ; then
   RESULTS=(`< $INPUT_FILE`)
 else
   exit 1
 fi
 # Number of elements in RESULTS array
 COUNT=${#RESULTS[@]}
 if [ $COUNT = 0 ] ; then
   echo "No data in file"
   exit 1
 fi
}

CREATE_COL_ARRAYS () { # create two arrays from RESULTS  
 # INPUTS: COUNT variable, count of fields in array RESULTS
 # OUTPUT: array COL1 
 #	   array COL2	      
 let x=0
 let y=0
 let z=0
 while [ $x -lt $COUNT ]  ; do
   let z=$y+1
   # Create array of first column data
   COL1[$x]=${RESULTS[$y]}
   # Create array of second column data
   COL2[$x]=${RESULTS[$z]}
   let y=$y+2
   let x++
 done
} ### END CREATE_COL_ARRAYS

PROCESS_COL1 () { # Do something to COL1 array
 # INPUTS: COL1 array
 #	   COUNT variable, count of elements in RESULTS array
 # OUTPUT:
 let HALFCOUNT=($COUNT / 2)
 let x=0
 while [ $x -lt $HALFCOUNT ] ; do
   echo -n  COL1[$x]=${COL1[$x]},
   let x++
 done	
 echo		       
} ### END PROCESS_COL1

PROCESS_COL2 () { # Do something to COL2 array
 # INPUTS: COL2 array
 #	   COUNT variable, count of elements in RESULTS array
 # OUTPUT:
 let HALFCOUNT=($COUNT / 2)
 let x=0
 while [ $x -lt $HALFCOUNT ] ; do
   echo -n  COL2[$x]=${COL2[$x]},
   let x++
 done			  
 echo
} ### END PROCESS_COL2

### MAIN ###
# Create array from data in INPUT_FILE
CREATE_ARRAY
# Call CREATE_COL_ARRAYS to create column arrays
CREATE_COL_ARRAYS || exit 1
# Do something with COL1 array
PROCESS_COL1 || exit 1
# Do something with COL2 array
PROCESS_COL2 || exit 1
exit 0






On Sun, 19 Oct 2003 00:50:35 -0700, Felix Lee said:

>  >    COL2[$x]=${RESULTS[$y]}
>  >    let x=$x+2
>  
>  you're only assigning every other element of COL1 and COL2.
>  COL1[0] has a value, COL1[1] is null, COL1[2] has a value, etc.

On Sun, 19 Oct 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   In my original message I noted that I tried 'modprobe ac97.o.gz' and
> presented what came back. Heh! Just now I logged into that system ane ran
> 'lsmod'. No soundcord module either today. Let me try loading the specific
> modules again ...
>
> # modprobe ac97.o.gz
> modeprobe: Can't locate module ac97.o.gz
>
> # locate ac97.o.gz
> /lib/modules/2.4.22/kernel/drivers/sound/ac97.o.gz
>
>   To write that I'm puzzled, perplexed and out of my knowledge set is an
> understatement.

I'm kind of shocked nobody has written this yet, but modprobe takes a
module name, not a filename.

Here's an example fromy my machine:

[root:~]#rmmod mga_vid
[root:~]#locate mga_vid
/lib/modules/2.4.18/kernel/drivers/misc/mga_vid.o
/usr/lib/mplayer/vidix/mga_vid.so
[root:~]#modprobe mga_vid.o
modprobe: Can't locate module mga_vid.o
[root:~]#modprobe mga_vid
[root:~]#lsmod
Module                  Size  Used by
mga_vid                 8400   0  (unused)

See?  Just type the right thing and the right thing can happen.

J.

On Sun, 2003-10-19 at 09:27, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   The motherboard is a MSI KT3 Ultra2 (MS-6380E v1.X with the VIA Apollo
> KT333 and VT8235 chipsets. The audio chip is a Realtek ALC650. Neither
> Realtek nor ALC650 is listed on the alsa soundcard matrix page.

VIA VT8235 is, however... try following the steps on this page (noting
you have Alsa 0.9.6 or 0.9.7 on there)...

http://www.alsa-project.org/alsa-doc/doc-php/template.php?company=VIA&card=&chip=via8235&module=via82xx

Really, all you need to worry about is loading the proper module, you
don't need to worry about setting up a proper .asoundrc.

Keith Nasman said:
> I'd like to know if these core releases will require downing the
> machine, inserting the CD, upgrading and then rebooting.

Naw. Just upgrade the fedora-release package and "yum update" or
"apt-get dist-upgrade" or "up2date -u". Perhaps restart services for
glibc updates.

I've gone from Severn Beta -> FC test 1 -> FC test 2 -> FC test 3 by
that route, rebooting only for new kernel packages (of which there
have been many, mostly ACPI or exec-shield fixes, I think).

The "defining characteristic" of Fedora Core 2 is expected to be the
2.6 kernel, so I'd plan on at least one reboot for that upgrade. ;-)

From heinlein at madboa.com  Sun Oct 19 16:17:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sun Oct 19 16:17:02 2003
Subject: Fedora comments (was: [PLUG] Copying text from pdf)
In-Reply-To: <1066550335.6311.148.camel@kat>
References: <1066423974.1055.0.camel@apollo.spears.org> 
 <Pine.LNX.4.58.0310171409030.4851@pecos.madboa.com> 
 <1066498459.1056.10.camel@apollo.spears.org>  <Pine.LNX.4.58.0310181741180.4851@pecos.madboa.com>
 <1066550335.6311.148.camel@kat>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0310190837120.4851@pecos.madboa.com>

On Sun, 19 Oct 2003, Zot O'Connor wrote:

> The biggest problem I have with any "snapshot" (and I consider RH9 a
> snapshot) is the same thing as a technology freeze on the Space
> Shuttle program.  Yes it help with the process (the shuttle must
> freeze 10 years out sometimes), but in the computing world, it does
> not make sense.

In my work environment, the core questions in this regard are
customization and reliance. I haven't worked this out completely, but
I think my assertions would be something like this:

* The more customization we do to an application, the more stable we
  want it to be.

* The more we rely on an application's current behavior -- esp. w.r.t.
  its predictability and uptime -- the more stable we want it to be. A
  related issue is the number of people who rely on the behavior: the
  more users involved, the more consistency is needed.

The obverse would be something like

* Applications we use "out of the box," that don't need rock-solid
  uptime and predictability -- those we want to see upgraded in a
  timely manner.

To my way of thinking, that puts different types of systems and
applications in need of different upgrade architectures:

* Application servers: At work, we host a number of key applications
  on Linux servers that don't allow user logins: sendmail, Mailman,
  Squid, OpenLDAP, stunnel, SquirrelMail, Apache, Samba, and NFS.

  Each of those applications is subject to a certain amount of
  customization for our enviroment. They also need to interact with
  other key applications (e.g., Perl, PHP, libdb, glibc, OpenSSL) in
  very, very predictable ways. Otherwise, things break for lots of
  people all at once.

  These machines really benefit from what you call the "snapshot"
  approach. For example, even incremental upgrades to PHP can throw
  SquirrelMail into a tizzy. I don't want continuous upgrades to these
  applications. I want them stable and predictable. Hopefully, the
  servers hosting these applications can keep a stable OS
  configuration for at least two years.

* Login servers: We have a couple other Linux login servers used for
  students, researchers, and faculty to compile/test/run applications
  for class and research projects.

  Custom-built applications can be very sensitive to changes in
  development libraries, glibc and, esp. compilers.

  Typically, I can provide a couple machines to serve in this role.
  That allows folks to test their apps in the new environment,
  rebuilding them if necessary.

  Still, there needs to be a fairly long life for these boxes. We have
  researchers whose NSF grants rely on demos they build and run on
  these hosts. Again, even incremental upgrades can be problematic.

* Desktops: We also have a number of desktop hosts. These are good
  candidates for the small, continuous upgrades provided by, e.g.,
  Debian testing or Gentoo. If something breaks or changes, the
  individual user can usually be fairly flexible.

Different environments have different needs, of course, and I don't
want to suggest that my environment is indicative of all others.

Still, there are very few of my backroom servers that I'd trust to a
distribution that was continually upgrading its apps or libraries. The
backporting approach taken by Red Hat is more to my liking.

On the desktop, however, the continuous upgrades make more sense in
many situations.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

I think this has come up on the list before, with the rational for not
restarting services automatically being that you can schedule the
downtime (however brief) if done manually.

Most of Redhat's security advisory end with a statement like: "After
the errata packages are installed, restart the Web service by running
(as root) the following command: /sbin/service httpd restart"

Also, say my web servers have passphrases on the SSL certificates. If
httpd restarts, I have to re-enter the passphrase, which will be
difficult to do if it's a 2AM scheduled upgrade via RHN, etc.

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District

From ian at znark.com  Sun Oct 19 23:31:01 2003
From: ian at znark.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Sun Oct 19 23:31:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] stuck rpm processes
In-Reply-To: <1066497345.6311.127.camel@kat>
References: <1066146723.9705.111.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>	 <20031014162742.GA22628@accesscom.com> <1066497345.6311.127.camel@kat>
Message-ID: <3F9380C9.1040407@znark.com>

Zot O'Connor wrote:
> 
> Since I use rpm, apt, synaptic and red-carpet, I have to do this a few
> times a week.  Something is not happy.  I am adding and upgrading daily.
> 

There are some known bugs in rpm with locking and rpm.  What version of 
Red Hat are you using?  For RH8.0, make sure you have the most recent 
available version of rpm, 4.1.1.  For RH9, some people suggest the 
experimental release 4.2-1 from ftp.rpm.org or Fedora.  Also, you want 
the most recent version of apt, 0.5.5cnc6.  Finally, check for duplicate 
glibc packages because old bugs would cause the updates to fail and not 
remove the old versions.

I am running RH9 and haven't had any problems recently after upgrading apt.

  - Ian

Subject: [PLUG] DSL Modem & QWEST

Just to throw my two cents in the mix..... I have not had one single ounce
of problems with customers who install ActionTec modems from Qwest.  It
takes a maximum of five minutes start to finish.  Plug the phone line into
the modem, plug the computers into the built in switch, power it on, open up
http://192.168.0.1 and then click basic setup.  If Qwest has finished the
line provisioning and your ISP is half way decent, you're done.

No you don't get your 3 mbits/sec download speed as you do with cable, but
who needs to download their email super fast anyways......

OpenBSD has a great reputation for security, however you might want to 
check out the benchmark site that was posted earlier:

http://bulk.fefe.de/scalability/

OpenBSD came out on the bottom of these tests (Linux 2.6 and FreeBSD 5.1 
came out on top).  (though in practice for 
home use you'll probably never hit these sorts of loads)

I installed OpenBSD on an old PC a year or so ago and while it was more 
work than a Linux install, it wasn't that bad.  Kind of reminded me of 
installing Linux back in '96.

Phil

From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Mon Oct 20 11:23:01 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Mon Oct 20 11:23:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Ahh, mostly figured out my firewall problems...
Message-ID: <1066674077.8081.9.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

I wanted to be able to nmap a gateway from another one going into
the same public subnet.  I made this possible by allowing the
other gateway to probe ports 1 to 65535, though it took a little
thought to come up with that. Figuring out I had to allow the
output to go back took watching the log.  The other mistake I
made was to add my web browsing chains to themselves instead 
of to input and output.  Couldn't figure out why I could get
dns but couldn't web browse.

Now that I have my two gateways working again, I'm still at 
a loss on how to get my clients to dynamically receive two 
routers at two different metrics and switch when the primary 
is off to the secondary without zebra or some other dynamic
protocol.  If I manually configure a Redhat box, I can use 
two static routes to implement two default gateways at 
different metrics.  BTW, does anyone know where a document 
that explains the syntax of that file is?  I hope this
doesn't involve manual configuration of Windows.  Can
dhcp3 distribute multiple routers with multiple metrics?

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Mon Oct 20 12:41:01 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Mon Oct 20 12:41:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RE: BTTV
In-Reply-To: <20031020191020.72628.qmail@web10808.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20031020191020.72628.qmail@web10808.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1066678795.24559.83.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

I just "added" ntfs to a few RH9 systems.  

You still need all the tools for kernel compile.  This just saves a
bunch of time, reduces other issues, and makes it portable (like to
systems that do not have compile tools on them).

The steps are along these lines:
http://groups.google.com/groups?q=ntfs+compile+redhat+rpm&hl=en&lr=&ie=UTF-8&selm=k5af7.17274%24ZM2.1534623%40newsread2.prod.itd.earthlink.net&rnum=2

http://linuxexperience.com/tutorials/redhatntfs.php

The tricks:

Incstall the kernel src.rpm for your kernel (must match).   For me:
rpm -qa | grep kernel
kernel-2.4.20-20.9
kernel-2.4.20-8
kernel-utils-2.4-8.29
kernel-module-alsa-0.9.6-1.fr_2.4.20_20.9
kernel-pcmcia-cs-3.1.31-13
kernel-source-2.4.20-20.9

 uname -a
Linux kat 2.4.20-20.9 #1 Mon Aug 18 11:45:58 EDT 2003 i686 i686 i386
GNU/Linux


So 2.4.20-20.9 is the latest and running:

Then cd /usr/src/linux
  make mrproper
This cleans things up
  make xconfig
Pick "Load Configuration from file", choose the matching CPU flag, for
me, configs/kernel-2.4.20-i686.config

Select the appropriate flags in the kernel config areas.  Make sure they
are modules.

save and exit

edit the Makefile
Remove "Custom" from the EXTRAVERSION line

  make dep
  make modules SUBDIRS=fs/ntfs

The SUBDIRS is for ntfs.  Figure out what you need for bttv.  This saves
a lot of time.

  mkdir  /lib/modules/KERNELVERSION/kernel/fs/ntfs

again change fs/ntfs to whatever you need.  Likely you do not need to.

  cp /usr/src/linux-2.4.20-13.9/fs/ntfs/ntfs.o /lib/modules/2.4.20-13.9/kernel/fs/ntfs
  chmod 0644 /lib/modules/2.4.20-13.9/kernel/fs/ntfs/ntfs.o

Change the kernel versions as appropriate.

    /sbin/depmod -a

Once the file is built and chmoded you drop it on any RH9 machine with
the same kernel.  Most of the problems I had was failure to follow the
steps in order.

I have done this technique a bunch and it works well.  I wish redhat
would just make rpms/tars of the built kernel trees so you could just
drop in the new code and recompile, but this is close enough.

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Mon Oct 20 13:49:02 2003
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Mon Oct 20 13:49:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] email that prompts outgoing FAX
In-Reply-To: <A7GC2VQSTOXSTN4Y1X8T21YXE03V.3f8f70d3@miked>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0310201321090.1449-100000@aluminum.bavariati.org>

On Thu, 16 Oct 2003, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> Is there a way to get an incoming e-mail to prompt an outgoing FAX?
>
> I have a FAX I want to have sent to someone sho sends an e-mail with
> their FAX number in the subject.

Email to FAX gateway?  Sure.  It's gonna involve HylaFAX and maybe some
Perl.  Hrm, let's see what T.F.W. says...

http://www.hylafax.org/howto/faxing.html#ss5.4

 5.4 Email-To-Fax Configuration
  * faxmail - faxmail is a HylaFAX client program which takes an electronic
    mail message on standard input and converts it to PostScript in a form
    that is suitable for transmission as a facsimile. Read the man page:
    faxmail(1). In order to use faxmail as an email-to-fax gateway,
    typically some degree of "sendmail mangling" must be done. See
    http://www.hylafax.org/howto/clients/sendmail-faxmail-mangling.html and
    http://www.hylafax.org/howto/clients/faxmail-nonrandom-host.html for
    more information.
  * email-to-fax with procmail - If procmail is your mail delivery agent
    (MDA), then you can easily configure it to handle outbound faxes by
    setting up a dedicated user account for faxing out and placing
    appropriate recipes in that user's $HOME/.procmailrc file. Outbound
    faxes are then e-mailed to this user account. This is how the
    above-mentioned RelayFax client works, which already has a simple
    generic email-to-fax capability built-in.

It's a shame more folks don't know about HylaFAX.  Heck, I'd run it
myself, if I had a modem, a land-line and a need to handle FAXes.
Maybe it'll get more popular now that Windows no longer comes with
FAXing.  Just another job for your friendly li'l SOHO Linux box...

BTW the ntfs site really should have the instructions for compiling rpm
compliant modules since they do it themselves.  I tried to find it on
there and they have two set of instructions:

1)  Compile your own full kernel.
2)  Use our rpms.

They are the prime example of a device you might want to not use the
stock ntfs module.  They have made some upgrades to the ntfs module. 
Instead they have a you run a script which does a bunch of odd things,
whereas the listed steps are pretty straight forward.

From aschlemm at comcast.net  Mon Oct 20 21:36:02 2003
From: aschlemm at comcast.net (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Mon Oct 20 21:36:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OpenBSD
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0310201050180.29360-100000@onyx.spiritone.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0310201050180.29360-100000@onyx.spiritone.com>
Message-ID: <200310202135.05710.aschlemm@comcast.net>

Keep in mind that unless you're creating some huge corporate firewall 
for 1000s of people, OpenBSD is more than adequate for most peoples 
needing a small firewall. I've used OpenBSD as my firewall of choice 
since 2.9. I don't care about scalability and this isn't a real 
priority for the OpenBSD team either. Adding security and other 
features does take a performance hit but IMHO it's worth it for the 
added security features.

I have a set of "pf" rules I use for my network and I also use "isakmpd" 
for a VPN tunnel to the office where we use a small Netgear FVS318 
VPN/Firewall appliance for our office firewall. I'm looking forward to 
converting our office firewall over to a dual-homed OpenBSD system when 
we have more room in our sever rack for another 1U box. The Netgear 
appliance is nice and all but we're finding we need a bit more 
flexibility that what it provides.

OpenBSD still supports the 386 so I've found it ideal for putting my 12 
year old 486DX33 back into service as a print server in our office for 
our parallel-port only HP laserjet. It's a text-based install with 
text-based configuration files and I find it very easy to install and 
configure. I keep my configuration files in configuration management so 
I can slap them onto a new OpenBSD install and have a working system 
very quickly. It reminds me of Slackware installs I did 7+ years ago. 
It's not flashy but it works and anyone that understands the basics of 
system configuration and doesn't mind using "vi" should be able get 
OpenBSD installed and running IMHO.

Tony

Since we will not be having a Plug meeting Thursday January 1 2004,
may I suggest a small schedule change, perhaps another party for
those of you with a few bottles left over from New Years?

On Tuesday, January 6, 2004, Linus Torvalds will be 2^30 seconds
old.  Depending on time of day he was born on December 28, 1969
in Helsinki, + 3 hrs 37 minutes to PST.

On Saturday, January 10, 2004, at 0537PST the Epoch of Unix
(starting January 1, 1970 UTC) will be 2^30 seconds old.  

A party spanning both these times would be quite an event ... :-)


BTW, On November 2, 2004, Beaverton, Oregon (platted December 26,
1868), the home town of the Open Source Development Labs ( Linus's
employer) will be 2^32 seconds old.  With luck, it will do like an
unsigned int32, roll over, and turn into a swamp again. :-)

These dates computed  with the aid of the Gigasecond Server at
http://www.araneus.fi/gigasecond/

On Tue, 2003-10-21 at 09:42, Rich Shepard wrote:

Yes, I use them for the config files on gibraltar firewalls.  Once the
system is setup for the client, I then copy the config files from the
USB storage device to the clients winblows box.  I've successfully
copied them back as well.  Linux can repartition them as well, and as
long as you leave some sort of FAT file system, winblows will be able to
read and write to it.  FYI, 2k and XP don't (usually) need drivers, but
'98 almost always needs drivers.
> 
>   My new laptop will be setup for USB support. Are their any particular
> brands of "thumbs" or "sticks" to choose or avoid?

So far, I haven't come across one that doesn't work as advertised.

HTH,

Derek Loree




From cstevens at gencom.us  Tue Oct 21 10:15:03 2003
From: cstevens at gencom.us (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Tue Oct 21 10:15:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Rsync Backup Solution over SSH
Message-ID: <1066756533.6430.63.camel@sparticus>

All,

Here's the scenario: you need a backup solution that will make a
complete backup of your server and automatically rotate the backup
snapshots using rsync.

These two scripts will take a snapshot once every four hours (depending
on your crontab entry) and automatically rotate the snapshots
"backward," that is, 'hourly.3' will be deleted, 'hourly.2' will rotate
to 'hourly.3,' 'hourly.1' will rotate to 'hourly.2' and so on. 

Moreover, a snapshot of the server will be taken and the three "dailys"
will rotate in a similar fashion to the "hourlys" at midnight each day.

Here is an excellent article for doing this:

  http://www-106.ibm.com/developerworks/ibm/library/i-metro17.html

 Why rsync? From the article:

* rsync is fast, stable, and mature; it's been around for years and has
served the author well in a multitude of diverse situations.

* rsync was designed to do exactly what we were trying to do -- create
an exact replica of a local data repository on a remote system (or
visa-versa), and keep the two repositories in "sync" with each other.

* rsync is readily available; it ships with most popular Linux
distributions.

While Tom's article is excellent, there's just one catch: this article
talks about performing synchronized backups when an NFS mount is
available. For security reasons NFS was in my case simply not an option.

I adapted the scripts to work via SSH.

Alert: Automating the scripts via cron requires that root on the origin
server be able to log in to the remote server via SSH without a
password. Of course, the origin server must still authenticate itself
with public/private key authentication. The best way to do this securely
is outlined here:

  http://www-106.ibm.com/developerworks/linux/library/l-keyc3/

For your convenience, here is the beginning of the SSH article here:

  http://www-106.ibm.com/developerworks/library/l-keyc.html
  
 To implement the system, perform the following:

1) Install the Korne Shell (ksh) if you do not already have it

2) Copy both hourly_snapshot.sh and daily_snapshot.sh to /usr/bin

3) Configure the origin server to log in as root via SSH without a
password

4) Create a file called /etc/excludes (example below) and add the
directories and/or files you do not wish to back up

5) Modify the REMOTE_SERVER variable in both scripts to point to the
server that will receive the backups and make them executable by root
(chmod 744 /usr/bin/script_name.sh)

6) Modify the SNAPSHOT_RW variable in both scripts to point to the
directory on the remote server you wish the system to backup to

7) Add the following to your crontab: 

  0 */4 * * * /usr/bin/hourly_snapshot.sh
  0 0 * * * /usr/bin/daily_snapshot.sh

Since the scripts are so small I have attached them. I hope you will
forgive me as sending the information as a small file increases the
likelihood of correctness in terms of line breaks, etc. As I mentioned,
an example /etc/excludes file is also included.

I wrote the script for the Korne shell. Why? <\start flame here\>
because ksh is the Cadillac of all shells. It has air conditioning and
power steering. In short, it makes writing scripts really nice.

However, if any of you would like to modify this for Bash, please let me
know; I would be very interested to have that.

I hope you find these scripts useful.


Very Truly Yours,
-- 
--------------------------------------------------------------
| Cooper Stevenson        | Em:  cooper at gencom.us            |
| General Computer        | Ph:  541.924.9434                |
| "Open For Business"     | Www: http://www.gencom.us        |

# This file tells rsync wich filesystems to exclude
# to invoke, add --exclude-from=/etc/excludes in the argument to 'rsync'

mnt/

/dev/shm/

From sechrest at peak.org  Tue Oct 21 10:38:02 2003

Rsync certainly is a useful tool at some level.

We are finding that having a NetApp with hourly snapshots to be a step
above that.

However, the key question to the Rsync process is the reverse process.

suppose that your host is compromised or other wise damaged and
you want to rebuild your system from scratch. What is the path for 
restore from the rsync set up?


Do you have a recipe for that?

 % # ---------------------------------------------------------------------
 % # Original script authored by Mike Rubel
 % # Modifications by Tom Syroid, December 17, 2002
 % # Adaptation for SSH by Cooper Stevenson, October 20, 2003
 % # /usr/bin/hourly_snapshot.sh
 % # ---------------------------------------------------------------------
